caption:

caption:
Thunder tea rice might just be one of the most ancient veggie grain bowls ever. The nutrient-dense Hakka dish was purportedly created during the warring Three Kingdoms period in China to nourish soldiers and keep them healthy. While assorted chopped veg, tofu & rice drenched in a tea and herb soup might not sound like the stuff of which foodie dreams are made, a well made bowl of thunder tea rice is a joy to eat. Fresh, healthful and flavour-packed. Click story link in our profile to find out where to get a great bowl. ğŸ“¹@flofongsg .

caption:
Utterly delicious find: weâ€™ve been hooked on this dairy-free cempedak cake with islandwide delivery from @ollella_singapore (feeds four to six pax). Itâ€™s fluffy and fragrant with pongy, juicy fresh cempedak slices baked into the cake. Tip: heat it up it in your oven/ toaster oven for a bit before you dig in, for maximum shiokness. We got our cake sometime ago, when durian cempedaks (characterised by golden, flattish flesh) were in season. We have since found out from Ollellaâ€™s owner that the type of cempedaks used for the cake vary according to the time of the year you order. Currently, the shop is using cempedak nangka, which has plumper, heavier flesh and does not nestle as neatly in the sponge cake as durian cempedak does. ğŸ“·: @yipjieying_

caption: Beautiful new pastries from Dolcetto @regentsingapore regentsingapore. Give this a 4-5 min toast in the oven before devouring.

caption:
One of the best DIY kits @flofongsg received during the CB is from @buonaterrasg. The texture & flavour of the fresh handmade semolina & saffron pastas are impeccable. Of the 3 options, her fave was the king crabmeat with tomato & tagliatelle. It looked deceptively light but turned out to be an umami bomb, saturating the springy strands of pasta with flavours as deep as the ocean. This was closely followed by the amatriciana with pappardelle - the guanciale (cured pork jowl) and pecorino cheese added a savoury sock to the rich tomato sauce, which clung to the satiny pasta sheets deliciously. Assembly is simple enough - think a more atas version of instant noodle prep with some emphasis on timing & a bit of multitasking: heat sauce in a pan, boil pasta with salted water, throw pasta in sauce along with some fruity olive oil & perhaps cheese, toss, dig in. The necessary ingredients are provided so all you need to do is follow the instructions dutifully & itâ€™s ready to eat in minutes. Yum .

.

.

A B2B company called Glife recently started its own B2C e-commerce line, @greenies.sg, which is like an online supermarket selling fresh fruits, veggies and a limited selection of frozen food, sauces, rice, noodles, eggs and beverages. They also offer â€œbox dealsâ€ for pre-cut veggies and fruits (see pix for its veggie Rainbow Box A and fruit Premium Box D). caption:
Just finished writing about Serangoon Garden Food Centre, the hawker centre VERY far away from me - but I made multiple trips there and was one of the last I went to before the CB started. 
Now if you ask me what I miss most there, it would have to be those Luncheon Meat buns. 
So old school and simple.

I realised there is something that dabao cannot satisfy, that freshness, buttery aroma and the warm soft feeling when you hold the bread in your hands. 
And uncle making those sounds as he closes and opens the plastic shelves. Piak, piak, piak. 
Things I miss, just sitting at the food centre and eating a bun. Haha. Happiness can come in small bites. 
bit.ly/serangoongardenfood 
#DFDHawker

caption:
On the 26th of May 2008, 12 years ago, I started something called â€œDanielâ€™s Food Diaryâ€. Seriously speaking, I didnâ€™t have a plan as friends just wanted me to document what I ate every day. Therefore, â€œfood diaryâ€. I had a curious mind (and appetite) and loved discovering new food places. 
If you asked me what I regretted, it would probably be the very name of the website - I was in a rush to just register something, and url like â€œThe Food Diaryâ€ and â€œSG Food Diaryâ€ were taken. 
I didnâ€™t think I was particularly a good food person, writer or photographer (though not many would know I majored in video and film in school). But Moses Lim told me something, â€œIf you donâ€™t know how this dish of Char Kway Teow is, after eating 20-30 plates of others, you would know.â€ The more you do, the better you get. 
With that in mind, I visited every new cafe in Singapore, tried a different hawker stall every single day. 
There are now more than 4200 posts on DFD.

Eventually all the food invites came - so many it became overwhelming and stressful, then I felt more at ease visiting food places anonymously and paying for my own meals.

Frankly speaking, it is not difficult to start something this day and age, like a blog or business. Startups are celebrated, but people donâ€™t tell you how to sustain it. 
Nobody told me going on, being consistent, and never giving up would be this difficult.

How to keep going? 
Continue learning new things (esp from the young people), never think you are the best, cannot be complacent, and keep a curious mind. And of course, must enjoy what you do. It shows. 
12 years. I still feel fresh and young with so much to learn. Thank you for your support, your patience, and having me as part of your food decisions. 
Through the ups and downs of social media (2008 where got Instagram!), the food industry, to COVID-19 - whether got money or not... just go on, just eat, just write. 
Trends come and go, challenges come and go. â€œTough times never last, tough people do.â€ Happy Birthday @danielfooddiary

caption:
Craving for some â€œFood King Goodâ€ Crab XO Fried Rice, juicy Ang Kar Prawns, Truffle Gyoza, and Crispy Buttermilk Chicken Karaage?

CHICHI Dining is a modern Asian fusion cuisine restaurant recently established along Amoy Street.

The Crab XO Fried Rice is made with Japanese pearl rice tossed in egg, sugar peas, nori (seaweed), and a special XO sauce made in-house.

Highlighting this dish is the soft and delicate topping of sweet lump crab meat, contrasted and complemented with smoky salty tobiko.

When you dabao or get it delivered, the tobiko are packed separately and topped to your own liking.

Islandwide delivery available. 
More here: bit.ly/chichisg

caption:
Mango Pomelo Sago Dessert æ¨æç”˜éœ².

While most would associate this dessert with Hong Kong, do you know that the dessert has its origins in Singapore?

It said to be invented by Lei Garden in 1984 when it opened its first branch in Singapore.

Former Head Chef created the dessert inspired by local ingredients available in here; while another version claims the dessert was invented to make use of leftover pomelo after Chinese New Year.

This is from Hui Lau Shan which made its return to Singapore earlier this year. 
Where is your favourite æ¨æç”˜éœ² from?

caption:
Hardcore fans of Song Kee Fishball Noodles and herh keow (fish dumplings) would be glad to know that they have reopened (again) at 100 Yio Chu Kang Road.

It has closed its outlet at 128 Tembeling Road, Joo Chiat.

Due to its popularity, the wait to dabao at the new Yio Chu Kang outlet can be anything from an hour to two.

@hungryamanda who is a regular commented that the noodles were not soggy after takeaway, though the mee pok seemed to retain the QQ-bite better than the mee kia.

Some people may find the signature herh keow â€œover-ratedâ€, but this fish dumpling has its fans.

The texture was smooth, slimy and slippery that it literally glides down the throat followed by bursts of juices after every bite.

More here: bit.ly/songkeefishballs

caption:
Supreme Pork Chop Rice ä¸€å“æ’éª¨é¥­ is that hidden Taiwanese shop at a basement near Bugis. 
On the menu are items such as Pork Chop Rice, Chicken Cutlet, Chicken Chop, Taiwanese Fish & Chip (each $6 per plate), in which you can switch your rice with noodles, fries, or fried mantou.

The star of the plate is the pork chop â€“ crispy, thinly battered, lean yet tender, not fatty, well-marinated, with a light fragrance of five-spiced powder.

It is not oily and greasy, and you donâ€™t feel guilty having more pieces.

Islandwide Delivery
Supreme Pork Chop Rice is offered islandwide delivery through a 3rd party provider (all delivery fees are paid fully to the drivers.)

caption:
Looking for Thai food delivery?

87 Just Thai has become one of my favourite places for affordable Thai dishes.

Chef Specials include Deep-Fried Century Egg with Hot Basil ($8 â€“ $12), Thai-Style Braised Pork Knuckle ($10), Sea Bass with Thai Spicy Lime Sauce ($25), Stir-Fried Long Beans with Salted Egg with Chicken ($8), and Claypot Tang Hoon with Prawns ($12). I usually go for the Green Curry. 
Delivery
Minimum order of $50 for delivery, delivery charges from $5. (0 to 5km at $5, 5 to 8km at $8, beyond 8km at $10). But avoid peak hours as they can get very, very busy. 
More here: bit.ly/thaifoodsg

caption:
Have you considered making your own New York Style Cheesecake?

This is a simple cheesecake recipe you can follow: New York Cheesecake made with Philadelphia Cream Cheese.

A classic pairing of cheese cake with biscuit crust base, plus deliciously sweetened sour cream layer.

Ingredients
Cream Cheese Block, softened â€“ 250g x 2 blocks
Sourcream â€“ 2 cups
Digestive biscuits â€“ 1 cup
Butter (unsalted) â€“ 1/3 cup or 75g
Brown Sugar â€“ 20g
White Sugar â€“ 150g
Eggs, lightly beaten â€“ 2

Others:
Fresh strawberries sliced, blueberries and mint leaves for garnishing

Steps 
1. Pre-heat oven to 150Â°C
2. Line pan with foil, with ends of foil extending over sides (if you are using a usual baking tray). Alternatively, many cheesecake recipes and hacks suggest wrapping foil outside the baking. This is so as to prevent the outer layer from over-heating, and prevent water from seeping in if using a water bath during bake.
3. Mix digestive biscuits, butter and 20g brown sugar
4. Press biscuit crumbs and butter base onto bottom of pan. Chill.

5. Beat PHILLY cream cheese, 100g white sugar with mixer until blended.
6. Add eggs, 1 at a time, beating on low speed after each just until blended.
7. Pour mixture over crust.
8. Bake 60 min at 150Â°C or until center is almost set.

9. Mix 2 cups sour cream with remaining 50g sugar until dissovled; carefully spread over cheesecake. Bake 10-15 min or until set.
10. Refrigerate 3 hours.
11. Use foil handles to lift cheesecake from pan (if you are using a normal baking pan â€“ see below), before cutting to serve.
12. Top with strawberries, blueberries and mint.

Yeah! More here: bit.ly/dfdrecipe 
#DFDRecipe #DFDHomeCafe

caption:

The signature dish is the Delicious Koka Noodles ($4, $4.50), with variations of dry, spicy, abalone clam and cuttlefish (starting from $4). While I wonâ€™t comment on the noodles, itâ€™s soup was light and pork very tender. 
Are you from Bt Panjang? Do you like this Ke Kou Mian?

caption:
#Recipe â€˜Upgradeâ€™ your favourite Iced Matcha Latte with the sweetness of strawberries. 
Check out @__sy_g â€˜s #songhomecafe on How to make Strawberry Matcha Latte:

1. Decorate your cup beforehand with slices of strawberries.
2. Add 1-2 teaspoons of matcha powder with 2 tablespoons of hot water.
3. Whisk the matcha making sure that there are no clumps.
4. Add your strawberry puree in the cup.
5. Add in some ice cubes.
6. Pour in some fresh milk. The amount of milk would depend on your liking, about say about 100 â€“ 150ml.
7. Pour in the whisked matcha. Enjoy!

More here: bit.ly/dfdhomecafe #DFDHomeCafe

caption:
Chris Kway Chap ç‘åº†ç²¿æ± at Bedok 216 could very well be a top contender for the best Kway Chap in Singapore.

This highly-recommended stall often attracts long line once it opens at 8am in the morning, and till 2pm or sold out.

Hereâ€™s another catch: the stall only operates from Thursday to Sundays.

The secret comes the seemingly bottomless pot, simmering a well-balanced braising liquid â€“ it is both sweet and savoury and carries herbal notes.

All ingredients, from thoroughly cleaned intestines to pork belly, are braised for hours in this potent pot of umami flavour.

Another secret to its success is that Chris is particular about keeping all the intestine and parts clean, and braises them separately (rather than dump them together in a pot). This is also to maintain consistency and so that each item maintains an optimum texture and â€˜cleanlinessâ€™. Some day, some day I shall have this again. 
#DFDHawker

caption:
Wah, only 30 burgers a day. Of course I was curious. 
And I got to order 2-3 days before. I always order anonymously, no special privilege, packaging or free gift. 
I waited anxiously, then I got my confirmation one night at 12:30am. LOL

Dirty Buns is a new burger stall located at City Sprouts at 102 Henderson Road â€“ no signage, no Facebook what-so-ever, yet.

The menu is really straight-forward, with DB Classic Single at $8 or $11 for a set with fries and Coke; Double Patty at $11 or $14 for the set.

Between the two, I would say just go for the â€œDirty Doubleâ€ rather than the single patty.

The meat to bun proportion felt more balanced, and somehow the single patty tasted overwhelmed by the cheese and sauces.

The star of the burger was indeed the meat patties â€“ nothing extraordinary, but good-old juicy, flavourful beef patties. Better than some of the expensive brands, really.

More here: bit.ly/burgersg

caption:
Is this the Best Chicken Rice in Singapore?

Loyal followers would know it is owned and run by a 70 plus year old hawker, an affectionate auntie named Mdm Tan. For more than 40 years, she has served hundreds of diners and now her son, Jay Lim is helping her out.

Hua Kee at 85 Redhill Food Centre is no-frills hawker stall with a red signboard, a favoured lunch spot among locals, has a two-items menu: Chicken Rice ($4, $5) and Poached Chicken ($15 for half, $28 for whole). What gives the chicken meat its mild flavour is the blend of light soy sauce and chicken broth that serves as poaching liquid.

The poached chicken was not overly greasy or saucy, in fact still tasted slightly â€˜coldâ€™, but had this smoothness which was quite alluring that I enjoyed very much. 
Check out other Best Chicken Rice you can find in Singapore 
bit.ly/hainanesechickenricesg

caption:
The Goodburger is one of the few food truck concepts found in Singapore, serving up â€œImpossible Burgersâ€. While its location changes from periodically, it is currently parked outside Coronation Plaza from 11am to 9pm.

Islandwide delivery is available. 
The Impossible meat focused food truck serves up a number of burgers, such as The Classic ($16), Black Tie which includes truffle aioli ($18), a Thai-inspired One Night in Bangkok ($20), and Happy Days ($20) included with BBQ sauce.

Because of the richness of the cheese and aioli, if you take a bite, you may not have thought this isnâ€™t beef.

But if you take the time to slowly savour, then there is that juiciness, â€˜beefyâ€™ bite and deeper flavour missing.

Overall, one of the better Impossible Burgers I tried out there. 
More here: bit.ly/burgersg

caption:
Those who miss Ginza Anzu which was previously from Japan Food Town at Wisma Atria, would be delighted to know that the tonkatsu specialist has reopened at the revamped Great World.

Ginza Anzu is a farm-to-table concept eatery originally from Kyushu, famous for their slabs of Tonkatsu â€“ the Japanese dish of breaded, deep-fried meat usually a pork cutlet.

Not sure how their deep-fried items would fare after dabao though, but Anzu does provide islandwide delivery with a delivery fee of $5, available from 11am to 8pm daily.

Minimum order of $40 is required for delivery.

Customers can order from their online platform for delivery and self pickup by clicking this link: https://ginza-anzu.myshopify.com.

caption:
Make a refreshing Yuzu Espresso Tonic at home. 
Instructions:
1. Add 2-3 teaspoons of yuzu concentrate to a tall glass.

2. Add some ice cubes (say 6-8 cubes). 3. Pour in around 200ml of tonic water.

4. Add in a shot of espresso (which is about 30ml). You may want a stronger mix with double shot.

5. You may want to further garnish with mint leaves, and enjoy this super refreshing drink on a hot afternoon.

Iced coffee pairs so well with citrus fruits and yuzu gives it a unique bitter-sweet flavour. You can also replace with other citron-jam or fruits & zest. 
More at @__sy_g â€˜s #songhomecafe 
Enjoy! #DFDHomeCafe

caption:
Duck Rice can be the ultimate comfort food to many Singaporeans.

You will mainly find two types of duck rice in Singapore, the Teochew style which has a simple prep with a light gravy, and the fancier Hokkien style, which has heavy sauce and may or may not have yam rice to add richness to the dish.

Similarly, the preparation of duck can also vary from roasted to braised, this guide will focus on the braised version. 
Swipe right for the 10 which includes
- Ah Xiao Teochew Braised Duck at Golden Mile
- Heng Gi Goose and Duck Rice at Tekka Food Centre
- Ah Heng Duck Rice åŒæµå‰é˜¿å…´é¸­é¥­ at Hong Lim

- Liang Zhao Ji æ¢ç…§è®° at Whampoa

caption:
No oil added? Goobne Chicken êµ½ë„¤ì¹˜í‚¨ is one of the most popular oven-roasted chicken brand in Korea, and has opened in Singapore at the revamped Great World.

What Goobne is famed for â€“ not a single drop of oil added during the cooking process, and therefore less transfat, carbohydrates, sodium and calories.

So after the chicken is roasted, there would supposedly be a crunchy outer layer with juicy meat.

While I did not experience that â€œcrunchyâ€, this was good, well-marinated, moist, juicy chicken.

Yes, you get all those flavours of the chicken, without the guilt.

caption:
Can you believe this? Braised Ee Fu Noodles with Fresh Mushroom & Truffle, affordably priced at $5.

Named after its Head Chef Ah Foong, Chef Foong Restaurant is one of the zi char eateries in Singapore that fuses modern and traditional cuisines.

I was honestly not expecting restaurant quality food and presentation from a â€˜kopitiam-stallâ€™, but was pleasantly surprised.

Not many people know about this place yet, as it is relatively new (opened in 2019) and located in a more industrial part of Lower Delta.

As the zi char eatery shares space with other stalls in a â€œ1080 Coffee Shopâ€ at Lower Delta Road, customers can order from the range of stalls during the â€œCircuit Breakerâ€ period.

caption:
Throwback to good-old zi char times with the foodie gang. 
Why does this feel ions ago? 
The lesson learnt, not to take simple pleasures like dining out for a zi char meal together for granted. 
How many times have we said â€œsorry busyâ€, â€œno timeâ€ and declined that meal? 
Anyway, this is a Wong Po Lou Meen aka Yellow Cloth Noodles from Quan Ji at Amoy Street Food Centre. 
This off-menu item ($20 per portion, good for 3 to 4 pax) is now almost an open secret.

Made with thin egg noodles â€“ choose between sheng main (raw noodles) and lou mien tossed in oyster sauce and lard, then topped with a silky-soft omelette, plump prawns, and blanched chye sim on the side.

I think what it manages to achieve is fluffy eggy texture, but this probably has to be eaten fresh out of the wok.

Just ordered Quan Ji for takeaway recently. Still good. More at DanielFoodDiary.com

caption:
The one thing that I wanna have after all this ends is... CLAYPOT RICE.

With over 40 years of history, He Ping Claypot Rice located at Geylang serves up Claypot Rice from $8 onwards.

The Claypot Rice is prepared the traditional way with charcoal, so be prepared to wait 30 minutes or more if you did not reserve before hand.

There is something different about the way it was served. The ingredients of chicken chunks, Chinese sausage, salted fish and salted duck egg yolk were removed before the dark sauce and oil were poured in. Auntie helped with the entire process, rather than some stalls which are DIY.

Auntie mentioned this is so that customers can choose and add ingredients, rather than to have it all mixed in.

caption:
Love Lotus Biscoff Cookies and Latte? How about combining the two together.

Instructions:
1. Take out 1-2 tablespoons of Lotus Biscoff Spread and place in a bowl.

2. Place the bowl in a hot water bath to allow spread to melt.

3. Pour the spread into a cup.

4. Add ice cubes (say 6-7 cubes?). 5. Pour in 150ml of milk, followed by one shot of espresso. A single shot of espresso is generally about 30ml. However, the milk to coffee ratio can be adjusted according to personal preference.

6. Top off with some milk foam (or whipped cream), a lotus biscuit and rosemary.

Recipe by @__sy_g at #SongHomeCafe 
#DFDHomeCafe

caption:
One of those dishes that travel well after delivery or dabao is Pig Trotters Bee Hoon.

This came in a rather saucy version yet the bee hoon did not taste too soggy and retained its bite. I do not know what else they added to the base, but the flavours were robust and well-infused within the vermicelli.

Complete with wok-hei.

It is expensive and perhaps some say you can easily cook this up at home, but I can see why people are willing to pay more for this. There is just this extra umami-touch.

Also get their Gula Melaka Chiffon Cake made with extra-virgin organic coconut oil.

They also offer islandwide delivery. More here: bit.ly/circuitbreakersg 
#DFDCircuitBreaker

caption:
This plate of Tofu may look like it is from a restaurant, but actually from a zi char eatery next to a carpark. 
I can understand why families would support this place. Other than the fact that there is ample carparking, they are quite customer oriented.

More often than not, you get free ice-cream, popcorn, cotton candy and tau hway. Even if you order deliveries or takeaway, you would find some drinks (I had barley, green bean soup and liang teh before) given free with your orders.

For residents around Bukit Merah area, Chuan Kee Seafood is also providing free food delivery with minimum order of $30.

Whatsapp +65 9878 9924 for enquiries.

caption:
After all that Korean drama, I had major Korean food cravings. 
Seorae Korean Charcoal BBQ is offering islandwide delivery via: https://seorae.oddle.me/en_SG so that you can have your favourite Korean food delivered to your doorstep.

While delivery fee depends on where you stay, there is FREE Delivery with minimum spending on $39 â€“ which should be not difficult to reach.

If you are nearby and prefer to get takeaways, there is also a 20% OFF pick up orders, using the promo code PICKUP20.

Motherâ€™s Day Set ($68) is quite value-for-money as it is good for 3-4 to share.

It includes a tantalising spread of barbecued meats of Galmaegisal (original, spicy or garlic), Korean Pancake (Haemul Jeon or Kimchi Pajeon), Sundubu Jjigae, Kkochi Platter (mixed, beef or pork), Steamed Rice (x4) and FREE Korean sides.

More here: bit.ly/seoraedelivery

caption:
Chwee Kueh æ°´ç²¿ while being a relatively known breakfast dish in Singapore, is also fast-diminishing.

With the exception of a couple of famous brands opening up branches or franchises around, indie stalls are getting hard to find. This is because the older hawkers are finding it hard for the younger generation to take over this labour-intensive work.

The Teochew dish comprises of steamed rice cake topped with preserved radish known as chai poh, and served with chilli sauce. While traditionally made with pork lard, many stalls are replacing with healthier alternatives.

Here are a couple of places to satisfy your Chwee Kueh cravings, including - Bedok Chwee Kueh
- Jian Bo Shui Kueh
- Ghim Moh Chwee Kueh æè€ä¸‰

- Singapore Shui Kueh æ–°åŠ å¡æ°´ç²¿ at Whampoa
- Xiang Xiang at Bedok and Whampoa
- Tiong Bahru Chwee Kueh at Tangs Market 
More here: bit.ly/chweekuehsg

caption:
Probably one of the best Hainanese Western food in Singapore. 
While the stall only opens at 7pm or so, you may see a line forming here from 6:30pm or even earlier.

Nestled in the Tanglin Halt Hawker Centre, this is one of the most visited stalls for dinner, and for a very good reason.

Their Mixed Grill Platters ($10) are very popular, which offers a serving of pork chop, tender chicken chops, fish cutlet and chicken sausage.

Along with the meats, there was a dollop of coleslaw, baked beans, baked potato and crinkle cut fries. Itâ€™s a lot for one person, so make sure you bring your appetite with you.

Old-school flavours, generous portion, the only thing holding me back is the long queue and longer wait.

Check out some of the favourite Western food stalls here: bit.ly/hawkerguidesg

caption:
Roti Prata is a well-loved hawker food in Singapore. Also known as â€œroti canaiâ€ in other parts of Southeast Asia, the Indian-influenced flatbread dish is usually served with curry or dal.

Roti means â€˜breadâ€™, and Prata or paratha means â€˜flatâ€™ in Hindi language.

It is South-Indian flat bread made by frying stretched dough flavoured with ghee (Indian clarified butter), typically served with fish or mutton curry.

However, you do find more creative savoury and sweet variations, filled with cheese, bananas, or even chocolate.

The prata is typically crispy outside and doughy inside, making it a flexible choice for breakfast, lunch, snack, or supper (I usually have it for breakfast or supper â€“ it just tastes â€˜betterâ€™.) Find out where you can find well-loved Roti Prata places in Singapore for you to dabao from: bit.ly/pratasg

caption:
Is it the older you get, the more you appreciate Teochew Porridge. è€äº†. 

Anyway, Teochew rice porridge dish is often accompanied with various small plates of side dishes. 

The porridge is watery and cooked with minimal seasoning, and I usually order porridge water â€œumâ€ because I can not afford anymore carbs.

Some of the dishes are saltier in nature, like minced meat, braised pork belly, spicy shrimps and salted egg. 

But you can always pair with lighter dishes like steamed egg, steamed fish and vegetables. 

I like my dishes warm and flavourful. Sometimes, some popular stalls are a matter of hits and misses, and what time is the day you go to. 

You like Teochew Muay?

caption:
If you are in for unique gelato flavours and some happiness, then make your way here.

The humble shop at 10 Cavan Road (at Jalan Besar) with limited sitting outside churns out small batch flavours through a constant process of experimentation and refinement.

The Pistachio gelato was indeed rich, indulgent and had a dense consistency, with delicate roasted flavour without that artificial tasting sweetness. Good stuff.

However, when paired with a lavender-flavoured cone, the gelato flavour overwhelmed the faint aroma totally.

They asked me for another flavour suggestion for the cone. I thought maybe black sesame? 

How about you - suggestions for them?! 

bit.ly/icecreamsg

caption:
Talking about BBQ Chicken Wings, more prominent stalls there would have been TKR Yummy Chicken Wings, Wengâ€™s BBQ Chicken Wings, and Chong Pang Huat. 
But I decided to give R&B Express at Newton Hawker Centre a try. Since it has a Michelin recommendation. 
Have to say these were decent barbecued chicken wings â€“ evenly grilled till there was that enticing brown colour, thin and lightly-crisp skin, and moderately juicy on the inside.

The accompanying chilli sauce with its tanginess helped â€˜liftâ€™ up the taste.

But not sure if they are the best around. Most of the BBQ chicken wings around éƒ½å·®ä¸å¤š  more or less the same. No? 
Itâ€™s usually the chilli that makes the difference. 
bit.ly/michelinplate

caption:
Actually one of my favourite cakes is the rustic Carrot Cake. 
No, not chai tow kway.

The Western Carrot Cake, the wholesome bake added with carrots and walnuts, topped with cream cheese frosting.

It is voted as the favourite cake in the United Kingdom once, but I am sure of its popularity in Singapore, especially the good ones which are moist, delicious and beautifully spiced.

My favourites are from Fabulous Baker Boy, Bakery Chef, Baker & Cook, Cake Spade, Little Farms Cafe, Chalk Farm, All Things Delicious and perhaps Cedele. 
Where is your favourite Carrot Cake from? 
#DFDCake

caption:
Jajangmyeon ìì¥ë©´ is a delicious noodle dish topped with a thick sauce made of chujang (the sauce), diced pork, and vegetables, with origins from the Chineseâ€™s Zha Jiang Mian.

We previously wrote about O.BBs Jjajang, Hong Jjajang, Huluruk, Nipong Naepong, Ajummaâ€™s and Taewoo which is unfortunately closed.

This is from Dong Fang Hong. 
There are two styles here â€“ the Dong Fang Hong Jajang ($12) is the more basic bowl, and Bai Nian Jajang ($15) which literally means â€œhundred yearsâ€ and said to contain a traditional and authentic taste.

The Jjajangmyeon is indeed one of the best version I had in Singapore, drenched over in a rich and earthy-tasting thick sauce. If only the sauce could be warmer.

Bookmarking Joomak to go next. Where else?

Oh gosh, I miss Seoul! 
bit.ly/jajangmyeonsg

caption:
Not instagrammable BUT... Satay Bee Hoon is one of those fast disappearing hawker food in Singapore, that only a handful of stalls still serve them as it is labour-intensive to prepare the sauce.

Sin Chew at Bukit Timah Food Centre serves up quite a note-worthy version of Satay Bee Hoon.

Their take on the Teochew dish was sumptuous, included with thin vermicelli (there is brown rice beehoon option too), tau pok, cuttlefish and pork slices.

All is drenched in this luscious, rich peanut sauce with lovely texture of finely ground peanut sauce that had some special spices included.

It is a taste that you donâ€™t get elsewhere. 
More here: bit.ly/sataybeehoonsg 
#DFDHawker

caption:
On the search for the best Ondeh Ondeh Cake in Singapore. 
Found my way to Julie Bakes - one of the contenders as their Ondeh Ondeh Cake is their classic best seller and highly raved online.

Light and fluffy pandan sponge, with layers of crunchy gula melaka and topped with pandan frosting. 
Thank you for those who sent recommendations. Love them and can comment down here.

PS: I am trying to focus on those who bake their cakes in-house or at least from an exclusive supplier (Cos the same cake can appear in many different cafes), and bakery shops or cafes with physical space for people who wanna buy single slices.

caption:
Many good things are coming to the end, this includes Antoinette famous for its gorgeous cakes. 
Known for its elegantly-crafted pastries and Parisian bistro favourites, it will be ending operations on the 30th of June 2020. 
BOTH the Penhas Road and Millenia Walk outlets will be closed, and their online stores will also cease operations.

I remember days of its Salted Egg Croissant, Nasi Lemak Burger and Suan Pan Zi. What will you miss most there?

Beauty of the rose will fade, and we will miss their cakes. 
Sad. 
More 2020 SG Closures here: bit.ly/closedsg

#DFDCake #DFDClosed

caption:
[Closing] The Pelican at One Fullerton which has been around for 8 years, will cease operations on 30 June 2020. 
It is a surf and turf type of restaurant serving up seafood, steaks, an extensive selection of drinks.

Popular dishes included Pelican Classics such as Old-Fashioned Crab Cakes served with pickled vegetables; Ribeye Steak with anchovy butter and fries; and The Pelican Lobster Burger. 
Among the mains, the Snapper Pie was the recommended dish.

Baked to golden brown, this classic pie has a buttery and flaky puff pastry crust.

Other SG Closures here: bit.ly/closedsg 
#DFDClosed

caption:
Isnâ€™t this the weather for Kway Chap?

One of the most popular stalls in Serangoon Garden Food Centre, Garden Street Kway Chap is known for its diners lining up to buy their highly rated kway (rice noodle sheets) and braised meats.

Founded in the 1940s by the late Mr. Koh, it has been run by grandson Jason since 2005.

Jason has occasionally been featured in TV programmes as he was a qualified pilot before deciding to take over the stall.

The boiled flat rice sheets aka kueh were delicately smooth, silky and not unpleasantly too thick.

The brown soup base, made with from a home recipe of 15 ingredients, is boiled for at least 2 hours to develop its robust, herbal taste.

Their kway chap has a noticeably lighter flavour compared to other stalls.

More Kway Chap in SG here: bit.ly/kwaychap 
#DFDHawker (Videos filmed before CB.)

caption:
Helmed by the same people behind Fatty Bom Bom, Abang Gemuk is a halal, Western hawker joint selling food at XXL portions. Drenched in a creamy cheese sauce, The Cheesy Beef Burger ($8.20) has a #thicc burger patty thatâ€™s cooked and seasoned beautifully. Drop by for their popular Brown Sauce Chicken Chop ($7.20), which is served with aglio e olio cooked to al dente, a cold creamy slaw, and a fluffy brioche bun on the side. Get their Half Spring Chicken ($6.90) to take full advantage of their generous portions and affordable prices.
â€”

caption:
Tucked away along a quiet lane in Novena, this homely Japanese bakery serves a slice of Japan in every pastry they have. Their Pork Cutlet ($5.60) sandwich has two thick chunks of pork cradled in a soft bun and topped with a healthy drizzle of tonkatsu sauce. Topped with juicy berries and a crackly layer of sugar, the Blueberry Tart ($4) has a good buttery crust as well. Their Red Bean Butter ($3) bun is like a Japanese version of kaya toast, with its slab of salted butter complementing the sweet red bean paste.
â€”
Read the full review at bit.ly/kamomebakery or link in bio!
â€”
Kamome Bakery
Address: 169 Thomson Road, Goldhill Shopping Centre, Singapore 307621
Opening hours: Thurs-Tues 8am to 6pm
Tel: 8757 8560
â€”

caption:
Run by a fresh-faced hawker in his twenties, Kim Kitchen Braised Duck serves up generous portions of braised duck dishes starting from just $3. Their classic Duck Rice ($3) features tender duck slices infused with a hint of smokiness. The Duck Noodles ($3) soaks up a good dose of the savoury braised sauce, and pairs beautifully with the crispy tau kee slices. Topped with melt-in-the-mouth, fatty pork belly, their Braised Pork Rice ($3.50) is doused in a sweet and smoky braised sauce to make a toothsome dish.
â€”
Read the full review at bit.ly/kimkitchenbraisedduck or link in bio!

caption:
Letâ€™s not rush to dine out so fast, and take some time to practice our cooking skills with these DIY meal kits.

These cute Chili Crab Bao Kit ($15.90) and the Salted Egg Chicken Bao Kit ($13.90) from Bao Makers just need a quick run in the steamer, airfryer, or microwave and theyâ€™re ready to be assembled.

Paradise Dynastyâ€™s DIY Xiao Long Bao Kit ($23.80) set comes with colourful XLB skin, juicy pork filling, and even a bamboo steamerâ€”everything you need to fulfil your XLB dreams at home.

The brown rice-fed Benja Chicken from UFarm is marinated with a fragrant blend of Asian spices, so all you need to do is grill it up. For a quick fix, just order these juicy chunks of chicken in Route 65â€™s newest dish: Boneless Kampung Grilled Chicken Leg.

DIY cooked meals wonâ€™t get simpler than this. The Pasta Kits from Barilla can be prepared in a single pan, and each set comes with a flavourful sauce pouch already prepared beforehand. They have four different flavours, but our pick is the classic tomatoes and basil penne pasta!

Chewy, chocolatey, and filled with Milo, thereâ€™s nothing more to ask from a sweet snack that can be easily whipped up in the kitchen. These pliable Milo Mochi pieces have a molten Milo centre, encased in a soft mochi skin. If you have spare glutinous rice flour from making rice cooker muah chee, this bite-sized dessert makes an easy sugar fix.

Milo Filling:
200g Milo powder
6 tbsp condensed milk

Mochi:
150g glutinous rice flour
90g sugar 
1g salt
220g hot water
1g Milo powder 
Cornstarch
Milo powder

Steps:
1. Prepare your filling by mixing Milo powder with condensed milk. Stir well, then using your hands, bring it together into a dough.
2. Pluck out teaspoon-large pieces of the dough, and roll them into balls. Set aside. 
3. In a microwavable bowl, whisk together the glutinous rice flour, sugar, and salt.
4. Combine Milo powder with hot water. Add the Milo to the mixture of flour, sugar, and salt. Mix well.
5. Cover the bowl with cling wrap and microwave for 90 seconds. Take it out and give it another good mix, before popping it back in the microwave for another 90 seconds.
6. Mix it again in the bowl and let the mochi cool down.
7. On a surface covered with cornstarch, scoop your mochi out and dust it well with more cornstarch. Mould it into a rectangle, and cut the mochi into 12 equal pieces.
8. Flatten each piece of mochi and place a ball of filling in the centre. Pinch the mochi dough together to seal the filling in.
9. Dust the mochi pieces with Milo powder and serve.
â€”
Read the full list of Milo recipes at bit.ly/milorecipes or link in bio!
â€”
ğŸ“·: @jiayan__
â€”
#circuitbreakerrecipe #circuitbreakersg #instantnoodles #wfh #wfhrecipes #wfhsg

caption:
This pretty three-coloured sandwich was inspired by @Maangchiâ€™s famous â€˜Samsaek Sandwichâ€™, a recipe which she recalled from her nostalgic university days. Read on for the recipe to this hearty and visually satisfying sandwich!

Ingredients:
12 slices bread
1 cucumber, finely diced
Â½ tsp salt
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise
Black pepper
4 hard-boiled egg yolks
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise
1 tbsp yellow mustard
4 ham slices
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise

Steps:
1. In a bowl, toss salt and finely diced cucumber and let it sit for 10 to 15 minutes, or until they sweat and release moisture.
2. Using a kitchen towel or clean cotton cloth, pat or squeeze out excess moisture from the cucumber.
3. In a dry bowl, combine the cucumber with pepper and mayonnaise.
4. In a separate bowl, prepare the yellow filling by mixing the egg yolks, mayonnaise, and yellow mustard together.
5. For the red filling, pat the slices of ham dry and finely dice it. Combine the diced ham with mayonnaise.
6. Assemble the sandwich by laying a slice of bread down and spreading an even layer of the yellow filling, followed by a slice of bread and red filling, and another slice of bread with the green filling. Complete the sandwich with a final piece of bread.
7. Using a serrated-edge or bread knife, cut the bread crust off the sides, then cut the sandwich in half.
8. Repeat two more times with the rest of the sandwich fillings.
â€”
Read the full list of sandwich recipes at bit.ly/sandwichrecipes or link in bio!
â€”

caption:
Call it an abomination if you like, but this sweet and salty Milo Fried Chicken was a pretty big thing in KL a few years ago, and was brought over to Singapore last year. Itâ€™s surprisingly easy to recreate this crispy, Milo-coated treat at home, so read on for the full recipe!

Ingredients:
2 chicken breast, cut into strips
Salt
Pepper
Â½ cup flour
2 eggs, beaten
2 cups fine breadcrumbs

Condensed milk
Milo powder

Steps:
1. In a large bowl, season the chicken strips well with salt and pepper.
2. Prepare a tray of flour, a bowl of beaten eggs, and a bowl of fine breadcrumbs. Dredge each chicken strip in flour, then dip them in beaten eggs, and finally coat them in fine breadcrumbs.
3. Preheat a pot of oil to about 190Â°C, or until the oil starts steadily bubbling when a wooden chopstick is dipped in. Fry the breaded chicken strips for two to three minutes, or until golden brown. 
4. Let the fried chicken strips cool on paper towels for a few minutes. Drizzle lightly with condensed milk, then dust generously with Milo powder, coating all sides of each chicken strip.
5. Serve with a small saucer of condensed milk and Milo powder on the side.
â€”
Read the full list of Milo recipes at bit.ly/milorecipes or link in bio!
â€”

â€”

caption:
This microwave Milo mug cake may be a lilâ€™ rough around the edges (pun intended), but itâ€™s still deliciously chocolatey and super simple to make. Instead of having a cup of Milo Peng tomorrow morning, try whipping this up instead!

Ingredients:
2 tbsp flour
4 tbsp Milo powder
2  tbsp cocoa powder
Â¼ tsp baking powder
2  tbsp sugar
2 tbsp milk
Â½ tsp vanilla extract (optional)
2 tbsp vegetable oil
2 tbsp condensed milk
1 egg
1 tsp Milo powder for dusting (optional)

Steps:
1. In a mixing bowl, combine all the ingredients. Whisk well to get rid of all the clumps.
2. Pour the batter into a large microwave-safe mug. Microwave for three minutes.
3. Dust the Milo powder over, and serve the mug cake warm.
â€”
Read the full list of mug cake recipes at bit.ly/mugcakerecipes or link in bio!

caption:
Sharing a hearty dinner of zi char and seafood with the fam is one of the simple pleasures of life.

Uncle Leong Seafood serves all your classic crab flavours, alongside the unique Shimmering Sand Crab Delight (from $68), which is cooked in creamy butter sauce infused with curry leaves. They offer free delivery for orders over $120, so grab a few more of those crabs!

The halal zi char restaurant Yassin Kampung stands out from the crowd with their boldly flavoured dishes. One step above the classic chilli crab, their Sichuan Mala Fried Crab (from $47.08) is a fiery challenge even for spice lovers. They deliver via GrabFood and their own website, where minimum orders vary based on your location.

For a value-for-money option, go for 8 Crabs which serves two medium-sized crabs for $60. Their award-winning Salted Egg Crab is doused in a rich, creamy sauce, and spiked with chilli padi to add some heat. Order over $120 for free delivery, or opt for their Express One Hour Delivery for $18.
â€”

caption:
This Egg-In-A-Hole sandwich looks like a fancy toast from a cafe. A fried egg is encased in crispy bread, sandwiching sliced avocado and fatty bacon. Cut into this stack and let the luscious, runny yolk coat its contents!

Ingredients:
2 bacon strips
Butter
2 slices bread
1 egg
Salt
Black pepper
2 cheese slices
Half an avocado, sliced

Steps:
1. Fry the bacon on a pan over medium heat until they turn crispy. Remove and wipe down the pan.
2. Cut a hole into one slice of bread using a cookie cutter or just a cup and a knife. 
3. Grease a pan with butter and, over medium heat, toast the bread slices on both sides.
4. Crack an egg into the cut-out hole and lightly season with salt and pepper.
5. Top the other slice with cheese and cover the pan. Let both slices cook for about two minutes, or until the egg whites turn white, and the cheese is melted.
6. Assemble your sandwich with the sliced avocado and crispy bacon.
â€”
Read the full list of sandwich recipes at bit.ly/sandwichrecipes or link in bio!
â€”

â€”

Letâ€™s not rush to dine out so fast, and take some time to practice our cooking skills with these DIY meal kits.

These cute Chili Crab Bao Kit ($15.90) and the Salted Egg Chicken Bao Kit ($13.90) from Bao Makers just need a quick run in the steamer, airfryer, or microwave and theyâ€™re ready to be assembled.

Paradise Dynastyâ€™s DIY Xiao Long Bao Kit ($23.80) set comes with colourful XLB skin, juicy pork filling, and even a bamboo steamerâ€”everything you need to fulfil your XLB dreams at home.

The brown rice-fed Benja Chicken from UFarm is marinated with a fragrant blend of Asian spices, so all you need to do is grill it up. For a quick fix, just order these juicy chunks of chicken in Route 65â€™s newest dish: Boneless Kampung Grilled Chicken Leg.

DIY cooked meals wonâ€™t get simpler than this. The Pasta Kits from Barilla can be prepared in a single pan, and each set comes with a flavourful sauce pouch already prepared beforehand. They have four different flavours, but our pick is the classic tomatoes and basil penne pasta!

Chewy, chocolatey, and filled with Milo, thereâ€™s nothing more to ask from a sweet snack that can be easily whipped up in the kitchen. These pliable Milo Mochi pieces have a molten Milo centre, encased in a soft mochi skin. If you have spare glutinous rice flour from making rice cooker muah chee, this bite-sized dessert makes an easy sugar fix.

Milo Filling:
200g Milo powder
6 tbsp condensed milk

Mochi:
150g glutinous rice flour
90g sugar 
1g salt
220g hot water
1g Milo powder 
Cornstarch
Milo powder

Steps:
1. Prepare your filling by mixing Milo powder with condensed milk. Stir well, then using your hands, bring it together into a dough.
2. Pluck out teaspoon-large pieces of the dough, and roll them into balls. Set aside. 
3. In a microwavable bowl, whisk together the glutinous rice flour, sugar, and salt.
4. Combine Milo powder with hot water. Add the Milo to the mixture of flour, sugar, and salt. Mix well.
5. Cover the bowl with cling wrap and microwave for 90 seconds. Take it out and give it another good mix, before popping it back in the microwave for another 90 seconds.
6. Mix it again in the bowl and let the mochi cool down.
7. On a surface covered with cornstarch, scoop your mochi out and dust it well with more cornstarch. Mould it into a rectangle, and cut the mochi into 12 equal pieces.
8. Flatten each piece of mochi and place a ball of filling in the centre. Pinch the mochi dough together to seal the filling in.
9. Dust the mochi pieces with Milo powder and serve.
â€”
Read the full list of Milo recipes at bit.ly/milorecipes or link in bio!
â€”
ğŸ“·: @jiayan__
â€”

caption:
This pretty three-coloured sandwich was inspired by @Maangchiâ€™s famous â€˜Samsaek Sandwichâ€™, a recipe which she recalled from her nostalgic university days. Read on for the recipe to this hearty and visually satisfying sandwich!

Ingredients:
12 slices bread
1 cucumber, finely diced
Â½ tsp salt
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise
Black pepper
4 hard-boiled egg yolks
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise
1 tbsp yellow mustard
4 ham slices
2-3 tbsp mayonnaise

Steps:
1. In a bowl, toss salt and finely diced cucumber and let it sit for 10 to 15 minutes, or until they sweat and release moisture.
2. Using a kitchen towel or clean cotton cloth, pat or squeeze out excess moisture from the cucumber.
3. In a dry bowl, combine the cucumber with pepper and mayonnaise.
4. In a separate bowl, prepare the yellow filling by mixing the egg yolks, mayonnaise, and yellow mustard together.
5. For the red filling, pat the slices of ham dry and finely dice it. Combine the diced ham with mayonnaise.
6. Assemble the sandwich by laying a slice of bread down and spreading an even layer of the yellow filling, followed by a slice of bread and red filling, and another slice of bread with the green filling. Complete the sandwich with a final piece of bread.
7. Using a serrated-edge or bread knife, cut the bread crust off the sides, then cut the sandwich in half.
8. Repeat two more times with the rest of the sandwich fillings.
â€”
Read the full list of sandwich recipes at bit.ly/sandwichrecipes or link in bio!
â€”

caption:
Call it an abomination if you like, but this sweet and salty Milo Fried Chicken was a pretty big thing in KL a few years ago, and was brought over to Singapore last year. Itâ€™s surprisingly easy to recreate this crispy, Milo-coated treat at home, so read on for the full recipe!

Ingredients:
2 chicken breast, cut into strips
Salt
Pepper
Â½ cup flour
2 eggs, beaten
2 cups fine breadcrumbs

Condensed milk
Milo powder

Steps:
1. In a large bowl, season the chicken strips well with salt and pepper.
2. Prepare a tray of flour, a bowl of beaten eggs, and a bowl of fine breadcrumbs. Dredge each chicken strip in flour, then dip them in beaten eggs, and finally coat them in fine breadcrumbs.
3. Preheat a pot of oil to about 190Â°C, or until the oil starts steadily bubbling when a wooden chopstick is dipped in. Fry the breaded chicken strips for two to three minutes, or until golden brown. 
4. Let the fried chicken strips cool on paper towels for a few minutes. Drizzle lightly with condensed milk, then dust generously with Milo powder, coating all sides of each chicken strip.
5. Serve with a small saucer of condensed milk and Milo powder on the side.
â€”
Read the full list of Milo recipes at bit.ly/milorecipes or link in bio!
â€”

caption:
This microwave Milo mug cake may be a lilâ€™ rough around the edges (pun intended), but itâ€™s still deliciously chocolatey and super simple to make. Instead of having a cup of Milo Peng tomorrow morning, try whipping this up instead!

Ingredients:
2 tbsp flour
4 tbsp Milo powder
2  tbsp cocoa powder
Â¼ tsp baking powder
2  tbsp sugar
2 tbsp milk
Â½ tsp vanilla extract (optional)
2 tbsp vegetable oil
2 tbsp condensed milk
1 egg
1 tsp Milo powder for dusting (optional)

Steps:
1. In a mixing bowl, combine all the ingredients. Whisk well to get rid of all the clumps.
2. Pour the batter into a large microwave-safe mug. Microwave for three minutes.
3. Dust the Milo powder over, and serve the mug cake warm.

caption:
Sharing a hearty dinner of zi char and seafood with the fam is one of the simple pleasures of life.

Uncle Leong Seafood serves all your classic crab flavours, alongside the unique Shimmering Sand Crab Delight (from $68), which is cooked in creamy butter sauce infused with curry leaves. They offer free delivery for orders over $120, so grab a few more of those crabs!

The halal zi char restaurant Yassin Kampung stands out from the crowd with their boldly flavoured dishes. One step above the classic chilli crab, their Sichuan Mala Fried Crab (from $47.08) is a fiery challenge even for spice lovers. They deliver via GrabFood and their own website, where minimum orders vary based on your location.

For a value-for-money option, go for 8 Crabs which serves two medium-sized crabs for $60. Their award-winning Salted Egg Crab is doused in a rich, creamy sauce, and spiked with chilli padi to add some heat. Order over $120 for free delivery, or opt for their Express One Hour Delivery for $18.

caption:
This Egg-In-A-Hole sandwich looks like a fancy toast from a cafe. A fried egg is encased in crispy bread, sandwiching sliced avocado and fatty bacon. Cut into this stack and let the luscious, runny yolk coat its contents!

Ingredients:
2 bacon strips
Butter
2 slices bread
1 egg
Salt
Black pepper
2 cheese slices
Half an avocado, sliced

Steps:
1. Fry the bacon on a pan over medium heat until they turn crispy. Remove and wipe down the pan.
2. Cut a hole into one slice of bread using a cookie cutter or just a cup and a knife. 
3. Grease a pan with butter and, over medium heat, toast the bread slices on both sides.
4. Crack an egg into the cut-out hole and lightly season with salt and pepper.
5. Top the other slice with cheese and cover the pan. Let both slices cook for about two minutes, or until the egg whites turn white, and the cheese is melted.
6. Assemble your sandwich with the sliced avocado and crispy bacon.
â€”
Read the full list of sandwich recipes at bit.ly/sandwichrecipes or link in bio!

caption:
Missing the prawn tang hoon from @87justthai that we had in our last Thai episode!! Really a flavour packed dish like @helloshaunsim mentioned. 

If you try out our recommendations, tag us at #FKTagUsTuesday and weâ€™ll repost it! Todayâ€™s one is from @helloshaunsim:

The fianceÌe ordered from @87justthai for Fatherâ€™s Day dinner!

We had the Basil Pork with Century Egg, Claypot Tang Hoon with Prawn, Phad Thai, Clear Tomyum Seafood Soup, Deep Fried squid w/ Thai chilli sauce, Thai Style Kang Kong, Deep Fried Pork with Garlic, Mango Sticky Rice and Red Ruby.

From the plethora of dishes we had, my favourite would be the Tang Hoon! It was very flavourful and well executed. The fried century egg was something I have never tried and I think itâ€™s quite interesting! @foodkingnoc good indeed! The Kang kong was great too!

However, their deep fried items were overly done, imo. The pork was really tough and lacklustre while the squid was overcooked.

But overall, a really decent meal! And I would want to dine in at the place to have the food freshly cooked and piping hot which I suspect would elevate the tastes of the dishes.

The prices are very reasonable too! Head over to @87justthai to check out their menu.

caption:
Missing the prawn tang hoon from @87justthai that we had in our last Thai episode!! Really a flavour packed dish like @helloshaunsim mentioned. 

If you try out our recommendations, tag us at #FKTagUsTuesday and weâ€™ll repost it! Todayâ€™s one is from @helloshaunsim:

The fianceÌe ordered from @87justthai for Fatherâ€™s Day dinner!

We had the Basil Pork with Century Egg, Claypot Tang Hoon with Prawn, Phad Thai, Clear Tomyum Seafood Soup, Deep Fried squid w/ Thai chilli sauce, Thai Style Kang Kong, Deep Fried Pork with Garlic, Mango Sticky Rice and Red Ruby.

From the plethora of dishes we had, my favourite would be the Tang Hoon! It was very flavourful and well executed. The fried century egg was something I have never tried and I think itâ€™s quite interesting! @foodkingnoc good indeed! The Kang kong was great too!

However, their deep fried items were overly done, imo. The pork was really tough and lacklustre while the squid was overcooked.

But overall, a really decent meal! And I would want to dine in at the place to have the food freshly cooked and piping hot which I suspect would elevate the tastes of the dishes.

The prices are very reasonable too! Head over to @87justthai to check out their menu.

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat #DIY Meal Kit from @prepped_sg // I'm not usually one to advocate meal kits, especially if they boost local flavours that are easily emulated at home. But the ease of preparation and the freshness of the meal kits along with a certain air of sponatenity just made for such a convincing sales pitch.

I especially love the Thai chili lime Seabass, out of a bag and on the table in under 15 minutes.  It is steamed with various herbs and spices together with a convivial mix of soy sauce, sugar and lime juice for a feisty tangy and spicy affair that will cause instant salivation. Suggestion: steam some rice vermicelli in the broth below for an all-rounded meal.

Less than 20 minutes to get a picture-perfect semblance of a nutritious homecooked meal on the table, without any wastage or both time and resources.

Highly recommended if not for its taste, then for its reasonable price point. Good job guys.

#SGUnited #savefnbsg #preppedsg #thaichililimefish #food52

caption:
Call me irresponsible for unleashing this sweetness into the family home. Even I fear the consequences of this love affair ~ Peanut Butter Rolls to indulge my love for brown, caramel and shades of coffee.

More than just cinnamon rolls, the blank canvas allows for an exhaustive list of spread interventions. Today, the subject matter is @fixandfogg fruit toast Peanut Butter which is a (@mathieumusnier) fantasy mix of crunchy PB, freeze dried braeburn apples, raisins and sultanas. A good upgrade from the usual smooth peanut butter filling for this scroll.

Peanut Butter Scrolls
Makes 9

Dough
3/4 cup warm water
1/2 cup sugar
7g dry yeast
1/3 cup oil
1/4 cup buttermilk
1 egg
1/2 TSP salt
4 cups of all purpose flour

Combine all 2 cups of flour with the rest of the dry ingredients into a mixing bowl and with your fingers make sure that everything is mixed. Pour in the wet ingredients and on slow speed, mix with a dough hook. Continue to incorporate the rest of the flour bit by bit till a dough ball is formed, one that peels away from the sides.

Leave the dough ball to rest in an oiled bowl for 2 hours or overnight in the fridge.

Filling

120g brown sugar
110g butter, unsalted
180g @fixandfogg Fruit Toast PB

Mix thÃ© Brown sugar and butter till light and aerated. Using a spatula, mix in the peanut butter till you get a smooth paste. Note that it won't technically be smooth since there are sultanas and raisins in the product.

Beat down the dough to expel the air. Roll out into a rectangle on your workbench. Spread the filling out evenly, leaving a margin of about 1/2 inch on the furthest edge. Roll up nice and tight. Trim off the edges. Slice the roll into 9 equal lengths and arrange on a buttered 9 inch square tray. Leave to proof for a second time for about 40 mins or till double in size. May vary in different climate conditions.

Bake for 25 minutes at 180Â°C.

Drizzle a Nutella glaze over (equal part Nutella and milk) to really push this over the edge. DAYUM.

#fixandfogg #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52

caption:
Who remembers outings to NYDC for baked rice and mudpies during your youth. Oh the excitement and the cheap thrills that rings in.

Today's lunch is inspired by those memories, albeit in a bid to enliven those leftover ribs meat that I extracted from last night's meal with @sousvidelicious ğŸ§¡~ : Cheesy Tomato Baked Rice:: and by gosh, with a bit of doctoring, those same flavours will still cling to your tastebuds like crack.

Cheesy Tomato Baked Rice
Makes enough for 2

1.5 cup rice cooked
200g pork ribs, cooked
1 tomato, chopped
1/2 carrot, diced
1 clove garlic, chopped finely
4 rashes of bacon, chopped
2 tablespoon tomato puree/ Passata
1/4 cream/ milk
Black pepper and salt to season
1/2 cup cheese

In a skillet with a little olive oil, render your bacon till slightly crispy. Fry your garlic together. Add your carrots and toss to coat. Cook for a minute on medium-high heat. Add in the tomatoes and fry for another minute. Add your pork ribs or leftover minced pork, you can add in raw pork/beef here too but note to fry if off a little longer. Add in your tomato puree and black pepper.

In goes the rice. Make sure to toss till every grain is imbued with a shy shade of pink from the tomato. Now add in the milk/cream (it's optional, but I really like the rice a bit creamier). Season to taste.

Layer it into a pyrex pan and pre-heat your oven to 180Â°C. Top the rice with cheese and build a little loose tent for your baked rice, making sure that it is tall enough such that it doesn't touch the cheese.

Bake covered for 20 minutes. Remove the foil tent and bake for another 10 minutes till brown and bubbly.

Remove from oven. Cool slightly before digging in.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
I've never discriminated against fried chicken of any style. And today, I'll tell you that this #saltedeggfriedchicken is worth a visit. NOW. If you can manage to find two salted duck eggs in your possession.

Salted Egg Chicken
Makes enough for 2

400g of chicken thigh, boneless, cut into chunks
2 salted duck eggs
1 cup rice flour
2 tablespoon flour
1 Tablespoon rice wine
Salt & pepper
2 tablespoon cornstarch
2 egg yolks

2 tablespoon butter
Handful of curry leaves
80ml evaporated milk, more if you like it saucy
2 cloves garlic, finely minced
2 chili padi, chopped

Steam or boil your salted duck eggs. Boiling should require around 15 minutes. After which seperate the yolks from the whites. Place in a bowl and mash till you get really tiny crumbs.

Marinade your chopped chicken with the rice wine, salt and black pepper and cornstarch. Leave in the fridge for at least  30 minutes. Meanwhile heat up your oil, break two yolks over the chicken and massage it in. Pour the flour mixture over and season with some more salt and black pepper. Really push the dry ingredients into the nooks of the bird. Deep-fry for about 10 minutes till crispy brown. Set aside in a basket to keep it crisp.

Now, in a wok, melt the 2 tablespoons of butter. On medium-high heat, fry the garlic, chili and curry leaves till fragrant. Add in your mashed up salted egg. Things will start to get foamy really fast, that's normal. Lower your heat to a medium-low. Once the yolks has started to cook, add in the evaporated milk and keep stirring to form a smooth sauce. You can add more evaporated milk if you desire more sauce. No one is judging. Toss your fried chicken through the sauce and you're ready.

Oh don't forget the fried egg as well.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #Budget

But as much as the starters are a great distractions to filling you up, the mains are the real deal. Especially the BÃºn thá»‹tÂ - Vietnamese grilled pork dried noodles which shows a casual fortitude in its dressing but delivers a punchgram of flavours with aplomb.

I'm writing this caption post-Saturday lunch slump. It's been a trying sort of morning, kneading, rolling, sizing and layering - but the aftermath of the bubbling stack and the smiles it reaps makes it all worthwhile.

Also, you can try your hand at a quick ragu, but I managed to free a box of 4-hour bolognaise sauce from the depths of my freezer for this happy occasion. Recipe â¡ï¸: https://bit.ly/3i3OCjU
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
Lasagne from the heart
Makes enough for 3

Lasagne sheets

200g flour
2 eggs
Pinch of salt

Do like you do in all the pasta videos you've ever watched in your life. Make a well in your dry ingredients. Break your eggs in the centre. Whisk gently and slowly incorporate your flour in. Slowly work it in till your dough isn't tacky any more. Form a little dough ball, clingfilm and leave it in the fridge for half an hour.

Turn it onto a clean surface and knead for 8-10 minutes till you get a smooth dough. Working in 4 pieces, roll them out thinly with plenty of flour in between till it's thin enough to see your fingers.

String over wooden sticks and leave to dry.

BÃ©chamel

2 Tablespoon of flour
2 tablespoon of butter
400g milk
Black pepper
1/4 cup parmesan cheese

In a skillet, place your flour in and heat up the pan till medium heat. Introduce the butter and combine it with the flour to form a Panada. After about a minute, whisk in the milk little by little. Continue to whisk over medium-low heat till it comes to a slight simmer and a roux is formed. Throw in the Cheese and whisk to combine.
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
In a casserole dish, layer your Ragu, then your pasta strip. Followed by cheese, bÃ©chamel sauce, another pasta sheet, Ragu, cheese, bechamel and repeat. Finally above the final pasta sheet, layer on the remainder of the meat sauce and all the bÃ©chamel. Sprinkle on as much cheese as one can manage.

Put your Lasagne in a pre-heated 180Â°C oven for 40 minutes under a loose foil tent. Remove the aluminium foil for the last 10 minutes to get a nice browned top.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #madewithlove #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
If all Egg White Omelettes could look (and taste) like this... Had some extra whites lying around in the fridge this morning and decided to put them to good use. Avoiding my insipid memories of egg white Omelettes on buffet lines, I set out to achieve some sort of browning. And yes, it's possible.

Egg White Omelette

4 egg whites (Korean #CheonggyewonEgg for the win!)
1 tablespoon parmesan cheese
1/8 TSP Garlic powder
Salt and black pepper
1 small tomato diced
3 stalks coriander, finely chopped
Olive oil

Take your egg whites and whisk it in a bowl with garlic powder and a pinch of sea salt. Put your back into it and whisk for at least 2 minutes till light and frothy and literally no pool of liquid whites exist. It's going to hurt a little especially if you haven't quite warmed up. But it's worth it.

Warm up a skillet with a good glug of olive oil on medium heat. Using a spatula, fold in your parmesan cheese into the egg white mixture. Dice up your tomato and coriander. Set aside.

Once the pan is hot, pour in your egg white mixture. Leave for about 15 seconds before scattering your tomatoes and coriander over. Put a lid on and cook on medium-low for 2 minutes. Season with black pepper. Fold over and flip out onto a plate.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #eggwhiteomlette

caption:
Eggs are a vehicle for good times and you can take it for a spin whenever you like ğŸ¥šğŸš™...like I did at dinner time with tomatoes, for a classic è•ƒèŒ„ç‚’è›‹ Tomatoes and Egg Stir-fry.

3 eggs
3 scallions, chopped
1/2 TSP sesame oil
1 TSP shaoxing rice wine
1/2 TSP salt
3 medium tomatoes, diced in cubes
1 TSP sugar
Salt and white pepper

Whisk your eggs, sesame oil and shaoxing rice wine together with 1/2 TSP salt for a whole minute.

In a wok with 1 tablespoon of oil, Stir-fry the whisked eggs at a very high temperature. Remove from flame and set aside in a bowl.

Add more oil to the pan and fry the tomatoes and scallions for a minute. Add in the water and sugar, as well as the cooked eggs. Give a little scramble and put the lid back on for another minute or two.

Dish out and enjoy with white rice.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #CheonggyewonEgg

caption:
This is how I enjoy my ice cream. In a bowl. No sprinkles, no fancy waffle cone, no buttery sable for dipping nor cup of milk to seal the deal. This way, the subject matter, the ice cream flavour of your interest, gets to shine. And tonight it's the Dark Chocolate Sorbet from @tomspalettesg, a broody little number whose sophistication is revealed in the tiniest of dosages. A little bit goes a long way. This is me.

Sometimes I'm feeling White Chocolate Nori, half traditionalist, half adventurous. Mostly confused but the peculiar combination of umamified seaweed gelato with sweet white chocolate and oven roasted almonds breaks many rules in the most joyous big ways. I might even graduate to two bowls with this flavour. It's brilliant. I finished it before the family even realised it was gone.

@tomspalettesg has relocated in the midst of phase 2 and as they aren't ready to receive lovely guests yet, they have organised pre-order pick-ups times to better facilitate their guests. Details up on their socials.

#SihanSayDaBaoWhat #tomspalettesg #burpple #sweettooth #food52 #eyecandySorted

Growing up, I've had the strangest relationship with Coca-Cola. Being plugged to an inhaler since young and having to do frequent night runs to the ER in search of comfort by ventilator, I wasn't privy to the joy juice till a much later age. By then, surrounding by cousins and other kids who would turn to the red can as their choice reward for completing tasks, I had built this infallible impression of the drink. 'It will the best thing I've drank ever,' I psyched myself as I took my first sip at the age 12. **Pause**, nothing, not even the slightest flutter in my tummy. "That's it?" - I remember myself saying.

So, turns out my love for the beverage has never run deep and it is the same for most carbonated drinks. Rum and Coke? Would it be rude if I decline? ğŸ¤—; That was till I tasted the Coca-Cola chicken at @vascosingapore by @jenniferangelalee. What sorcery. I still think about it from time to time.

Today I poured half a can of coke into a chicken dish and drain poured the other half. Sue me.

Coca-Cola Chicken
Makes enough for 2
Adapted from @thewoksoflife

4 massive drumstick (I used the antibiotic-free, free range ones from @bostockbrothers in NZ)
1/2 can coke
1.5 tablespoon dark soy sauce
1/2 tablespoon light soy sauce
1 tablespoon shaoxing rice wine
Ginger, 4 slices
Dried orange peel - 1
Cinnamon stick - 1

Marinade your chicken in the coke for at least an hour.

In a wok with a little oil, fry off your ginger till fragrant. Toss in the cinnamon stick as well. Remove the chicken from the coke and brown off the drumsticks. Pour over the coke and the sauces as well as the orange peel. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer with the lid on for 18 minutes.

Remove the lid and reduce the sauce a little. Serve with white rice.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #food52

caption:
Not my first rodeo making Scotch Eggs but very well my first time sharing this recipe. It has worked for me a couple times before and trust me, these babies are good, both fresh out the fryer or cold on pique niques. That's why they are called picnic eggs!

Tune in to my stories for some behind the scenes action.

á´›Êœá´€Éª-ÉªÉ´êœ±á´˜ÉªÊ€á´‡á´… êœ±á´„á´á´›á´„Êœ á´‡É¢É¢êœ±

2 eggs
300g pork mince
1 chili padi
Coriander
1 clove garlic
1 tbsp fish sauce
White pepper
1/2 tbsp cornstarch

Egg, flour and bread crumb for coating
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
First of all, place your cold eggs in simmering boiling water for 6 minutes. Immerse those immediately in ice water to stop the cooking process. Proceed to peel after 5 minutes. Set aside.

Mix your mince together with the chopped chili padi and garlic and coriander.  Season with fish sauce and white pepper. Combine well and then incorporate with cornstarch.

Take enough mince to fit over your palm, press it to get an even layer from tip of your fingers to the base of your palm. Place egg in the center of the meat and enrobe the egg, making sure there are no cracks in the ball. Repeat and place both balls in the fridge to set for about half an hour.

Prepare the three baths, first of seasoned flour (just salt and pepper), second of a beaten egg and third of bread crumbs. Meanwhile heat up your oil till about 180Â°C. Run your 'meatballs' through the three baths and set aside as you wait for the oil to hear up.

Fry for 7 - 8 minutes or till golden brown. Leave on wire rack to cool before slicing through and devouring with Thai sweet sauce.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#scotcheggs

caption:
Does anyone else find the incessant downpours this time of year queer? Meantime, it's time to dig deep and churn out the soul foods. I'm thinking è‘±æ²¹é¥¼ (Scallion Pancake). Who's with me?
â€¢
Scallion Pancake
Ingredients
â€¢
200g flour
170g boiling water
Salt
Scallions (at least 5 full stalks, chopped)
Sesame Oil
Five Spice Powder
Sesame seeds (optional)
â€¢
In a bowl, mix flour, salt and boiling water. Using a pair of chopsticks, mix till you get scraggly lumps of dough. When it's slightly cool, knead it in the bowl for a bit then move the affair to a clean board and knead it for another 10minutes. Roll into a ball and cling film - leaving to rest for 20 minutes.

Chop up your scallions. By right, you're supposed to only use the green bits, but in the day and age, there's no call for wastage. I used the whites too.

Knead again for 5 minutes, you should get a really smooth dough, slightly elastic even. Roll into a tube and cut up in 4 equal pieces.

Using a rolling pin, stretch out the dough till almost paper thin. Brush with sesame oil, sprinkle lightly with five spice powder and salt. Cover liberally in scallions. Roll it up and shape into a snail. Leave it covered for another 20 minutes under a sheet of cling film or dish cloth. Continue with the rest of the three rolls.

Pre-heat your pan with a mix of sesame oil and regular cooking oil on medium heat. Just a light sheen. We're pan-frying, not deep-frying here. On a sesame oiled surface, smash down the snail and roll it out flat. Cook the one side for 3 minutes before flipping it over and cooking for another 2 minutes.

Prepare your dipping sauce : 3 tablespoons soy sauce, 3 tablespoons black vinegar, 1 TSP chili oil and a dash of sugar.

Slice your pancakes into quarters and dig in. Don't be scared of the thunder.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#StayHomeWithAscott #comfortfood #è‘±æ²¹é¥¼

caption:
As most people are warming up to the idea of heading outdoors to face 'the new normal', there are still plenty of dine-in options available in the interim.

And while I believe that there's a time for comfort food such as ramen and fried chicken, there should also be an opportunity for delicious peculiarities at the dining table. Nothing that I've tasted thus far have embodied such qualities as the food put out by Chef @woowaileong at @restaurantibid. His takeaway meals beginning with cheese shao bings snuffed in yeasted butter and ending with gooey black rice mochi cake crowned with oolong milk tea ice cream; keeping the family chomping relentlessly albeit with visible question marks floating above head. A renegade sort of cuisine that actually make you feel like you're stepping outside of your comfort zone, albeit at home.

A must order is their lionhead's head meatball over scallion noodles, that when broken into provides a self-saucing solution with HK curry at its heart. This and the Mapo tofu (which i implore you to mix with boiled dumplings if you have leftovers ğŸ¤Ÿ) make the perfect combination for couples. // Note that Restaurant Ibid has opened its doors to diners and will only continue this take-away/ delivery menu till the 28th June.

#savefnbsg #vscofood #sgfoodies #SGUnited

caption:
The kind of tart that make you want to break into dance and song ğŸ” // @tartebycherylkoh remains the stalwart of sweet pastry needs in Singapore and the constant innovation and sourcing is an added bonus for avid fans.

Their recent Korean Mountain Berry tart is a bejewelled beauty that reels in the wolf whistles as the tassels from her silver gown flicker in the breeze. By gosh she's beautiful â¤ï¸ and every buttery crumb giving way to shudders and audible murmurs of bliss. Aside from the fact that these berries are extremely seasonal, high in antioxidants and other health benefits, its slight tartness and explosive juicy releases make them a perfect fit to its pate sucre and custard throne.

Don't sleep in on this.

Thanks @chefolivia of @brandfitsg for sharing this with me!

#savefnbsg #tartebycherylkoh #SGUnited  #food52 #koreanmountainberry

caption:
Supper is a late night finger-licking attempt at flattening-the-bird & curve, skillet chicken at home, as inspired by @ladyandpups. It's a meal for one, upgraded by the pure fact that it begins with a French ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· jaune poulet. A Spring chicken weighing at under 400g, it's small yet goes a long way.

Skillet chicken

1 whole chicken
Salt
Black pepper
2 - 3 cloves garlic smashed

So you flip the chick on her front and approach her from the back. Things are not going to get frisky I can assure you. You might need a pair of heavy-duty scissors for this. Snip down the backbone/ remove it completely and push down heavily on the back to spread the bird into a single layer.

From here on out, a couple more snips are required to get as flat a bird as possible. It's physics, more surface area in contact with the pan, more crispy skin!

So, I remove the breastbone as well but left the wing tips on. Becoz love. Fret not, all bones went into a seperate stock which I will showcase another day.

Flip the chicken over with skin side exposed, by now, it should look like you, poolside on a deck chair after a heavy night of a drinking. Lazy and shapeless. Salt and pepper the skin of the chicken liberally and leave it in the fridge to 'dry-out' for at least 2 hours or overnight if you will.

In a cold pan, lay the chicken skin side down. No oil is required. Turn the heat on to a medium-low and leave a lid on. Leave it to render and crispen up for 20 - 25 mins (this varies extensively on the size of your chicken), at the final 5 mins mark, place 2 smashed garlic cloves in the pan with a little knob of butter.

Flip the bird over meat side and cook for another 2 - 3 minutes. Transfer it to a chopping board, leave to rest for a little while before slicing and digging in.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #SGUnited

caption:
Daddy's day means bringing the beef to the table and instead of just putting a slab on the grill, I decided to pull a #gyudon stunt on the Flatiron from @meatcosg. Slicing thinly against the grain after half an hour in the freezer, you're almost guaranteed tender results.

To accompany the meat, home pickled carrots, miso butter mushrooms , 6 1/2 minute ajitama eggs and rice. Can't be more proud of myself.

GyÅ«don
makes 2 servings

1 large onion, sliced
500g sliced beef (ribeye preferred, but the beautiful Flat-iron from @meatcosg was a perfect fit)
1 TSP sugar
3 tablespoon mirin
3 tablespoon soy sauce
1/2 cup dashi (or chicken stock)
Scallion (chopped)
Sesame seeds

Heat up 1 Tablespoon of oil in a wok and once it reaches medium heat, toss in the sliced onions and cook till translucent but not brown. This will take around 8 minutes. Be patient.

Add the beef slices and the sugar and cook till beef is slightly browned.

Pour in the sauces and the dashi. Bring to simmer, cover and leave for about 12 minutes. Taste for seasoning and add some salt if needed.

Dish out over white rice, making sure to drizzle the sauce over the rice. Top with your ajitama egg, garnish with scallions and sesame seeds.

#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52 #sgfoodies #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat Father's Day edition recommends @bochinchesg 's DIY steak sets which includes hefty pieces of steak vaccum packed with herbs and olive oil to guarantee a power-packed sear even at home.
â€¢
Read on. Things are about to get spicy.
â€¢â€¢â€¢
Steak always spark some sort of a debate in our home and amidst all this table feuds, I'm quick to realise one thing. We should never impose our own eating values on to others and similarly, we should never be forced into ordering something a certain way just because others are. i.e. Make informed decisions instead of being influenced.
â€¢
When I was getting down to cooking the steaks, I casually asked in my most jaunty  voice, "How would prefer your steak done?" - to which they both replied medium-rare please. So I did accordingly, incredibly chuffed at the visual cues of mauve red innards housed within a solid crust. Mind you, my parents are seasoned steak eaters, I'm sure, but perhaps not in the more refined establishments and also always making the safer options for cuts. They nudged their way around the more rare bits with an obvious distasteful look plastered on their faces. "It's raw," - I flew into a rage (on the inside). "Look guys, it isn't raw, it's just medium rare, the way you requested," I replied callously.  Disgruntled, I proceeded to slap the remaining slices on the pan. Using my tongs to press down with vengeance till the entire slice was cooked through. "Wah, much better," they said accompanied with voluntary thumbs up - *cue Face Palm* ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸
â€¢
Granted my frustration at the situation, I became quick to realise that we should never under any circumstances impose our values on others. I love you guys, but for goodness sakes, if you want it well-done. Just say you wanted it so from the start. ğŸ˜Œ Kthxbye.
â€¢
#SGUnited #savefnbsg #steak #bochinchesg
