caption:
I've never discriminated against fried chicken of any style. And today, I'll tell you that this #saltedeggfriedchicken is worth a visit. NOW. If you can manage to find two salted duck eggs in your possession.

Salted Egg Chicken
Makes enough for 2

400g of chicken thigh, boneless, cut into chunks
2 salted duck eggs
1 cup rice flour
2 tablespoon flour
1 Tablespoon rice wine
Salt & pepper
2 tablespoon cornstarch
2 egg yolks

2 tablespoon butter
Handful of curry leaves
80ml evaporated milk, more if you like it saucy
2 cloves garlic, finely minced
2 chili padi, chopped

Steam or boil your salted duck eggs. Boiling should require around 15 minutes. After which seperate the yolks from the whites. Place in a bowl and mash till you get really tiny crumbs.

Marinade your chopped chicken with the rice wine, salt and black pepper and cornstarch. Leave in the fridge for at least  30 minutes. Meanwhile heat up your oil, break two yolks over the chicken and massage it in. Pour the flour mixture over and season with some more salt and black pepper. Really push the dry ingredients into the nooks of the bird. Deep-fry for about 10 minutes till crispy brown. Set aside in a basket to keep it crisp.

Now, in a wok, melt the 2 tablespoons of butter. On medium-high heat, fry the garlic, chili and curry leaves till fragrant. Add in your mashed up salted egg. Things will start to get foamy really fast, that's normal. Lower your heat to a medium-low. Once the yolks has started to cook, add in the evaporated milk and keep stirring to form a smooth sauce. You can add more evaporated milk if you desire more sauce. No one is judging. Toss your fried chicken through the sauce and you're ready.

Oh don't forget the fried egg as well.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #Budget

But as much as the starters are a great distractions to filling you up, the mains are the real deal. Especially the BÃºn thá»‹tÂ - Vietnamese grilled pork dried noodles which shows a casual fortitude in its dressing but delivers a punchgram of flavours with aplomb.

#SGUnited #savefnbsg #sgfoodies #mrspho #gourmetfoodholdings #8dayseat #burpple

I'm writing this caption post-Saturday lunch slump. It's been a trying sort of morning, kneading, rolling, sizing and layering - but the aftermath of the bubbling stack and the smiles it reaps makes it all worthwhile.

Also, you can try your hand at a quick ragu, but I managed to free a box of 4-hour bolognaise sauce from the depths of my freezer for this happy occasion. Recipe â¡ï¸: https://bit.ly/3i3OCjU
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
Lasagne from the heart
Makes enough for 3

Lasagne sheets

200g flour
2 eggs
Pinch of salt

Do like you do in all the pasta videos you've ever watched in your life. Make a well in your dry ingredients. Break your eggs in the centre. Whisk gently and slowly incorporate your flour in. Slowly work it in till your dough isn't tacky any more. Form a little dough ball, clingfilm and leave it in the fridge for half an hour.

Turn it onto a clean surface and knead for 8-10 minutes till you get a smooth dough. Working in 4 pieces, roll them out thinly with plenty of flour in between till it's thin enough to see your fingers.

String over wooden sticks and leave to dry.

BÃ©chamel

2 Tablespoon of flour
2 tablespoon of butter
400g milk
Black pepper
1/4 cup parmesan cheese

In a skillet, place your flour in and heat up the pan till medium heat. Introduce the butter and combine it with the flour to form a Panada. After about a minute, whisk in the milk little by little. Continue to whisk over medium-low heat till it comes to a slight simmer and a roux is formed. Throw in the Cheese and whisk to combine.
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
In a casserole dish, layer your Ragu, then your pasta strip. Followed by cheese, bÃ©chamel sauce, another pasta sheet, Ragu, cheese, bechamel and repeat. Finally above the final pasta sheet, layer on the remainder of the meat sauce and all the bÃ©chamel. Sprinkle on as much cheese as one can manage.

Put your Lasagne in a pre-heated 180Â°C oven for 40 minutes under a loose foil tent. Remove the aluminium foil for the last 10 minutes to get a nice browned top.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #madewithlove #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
If all Egg White Omelettes could look (and taste) like this... Had some extra whites lying around in the fridge this morning and decided to put them to good use. Avoiding my insipid memories of egg white Omelettes on buffet lines, I set out to achieve some sort of browning. And yes, it's possible.

Egg White Omelette

4 egg whites (Korean #CheonggyewonEgg for the win!)
1 tablespoon parmesan cheese
1/8 TSP Garlic powder
Salt and black pepper
1 small tomato diced
3 stalks coriander, finely chopped
Olive oil

Take your egg whites and whisk it in a bowl with garlic powder and a pinch of sea salt. Put your back into it and whisk for at least 2 minutes till light and frothy and literally no pool of liquid whites exist. It's going to hurt a little especially if you haven't quite warmed up. But it's worth it.

Warm up a skillet with a good glug of olive oil on medium heat. Using a spatula, fold in your parmesan cheese into the egg white mixture. Dice up your tomato and coriander. Set aside.

Once the pan is hot, pour in your egg white mixture. Leave for about 15 seconds before scattering your tomatoes and coriander over. Put a lid on and cook on medium-low for 2 minutes. Season with black pepper. Fold over and flip out onto a plate.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #eggwhiteomlette

caption:
Eggs are a vehicle for good times and you can take it for a spin whenever you like ğŸ¥šğŸš™...like I did at dinner time with tomatoes, for a classic è•ƒèŒ„ç‚’è›‹ Tomatoes and Egg Stir-fry.

3 eggs
3 scallions, chopped
1/2 TSP sesame oil
1 TSP shaoxing rice wine
1/2 TSP salt
3 medium tomatoes, diced in cubes
1 TSP sugar
Salt and white pepper

Whisk your eggs, sesame oil and shaoxing rice wine together with 1/2 TSP salt for a whole minute.

In a wok with 1 tablespoon of oil, Stir-fry the whisked eggs at a very high temperature. Remove from flame and set aside in a bowl.

Add more oil to the pan and fry the tomatoes and scallions for a minute. Add in the water and sugar, as well as the cooked eggs. Give a little scramble and put the lid back on for another minute or two.

Dish out and enjoy with white rice.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #CheonggyewonEgg

caption:
This is how I enjoy my ice cream. In a bowl. No sprinkles, no fancy waffle cone, no buttery sable for dipping nor cup of milk to seal the deal. This way, the subject matter, the ice cream flavour of your interest, gets to shine. And tonight it's the Dark Chocolate Sorbet from @tomspalettesg, a broody little number whose sophistication is revealed in the tiniest of dosages. A little bit goes a long way. This is me.

Sometimes I'm feeling White Chocolate Nori, half traditionalist, half adventurous. Mostly confused but the peculiar combination of umamified seaweed gelato with sweet white chocolate and oven roasted almonds breaks many rules in the most joyous big ways. I might even graduate to two bowls with this flavour. It's brilliant. I finished it before the family even realised it was gone.

@tomspalettesg has relocated in the midst of phase 2 and as they aren't ready to receive lovely guests yet, they have organised pre-order pick-ups times to better facilitate their guests. Details up on their socials.

#SihanSayDaBaoWhat #tomspalettesg #burpple #sweettooth #food52 #eyecandySorted

Growing up, I've had the strangest relationship with Coca-Cola. Being plugged to an inhaler since young and having to do frequent night runs to the ER in search of comfort by ventilator, I wasn't privy to the joy juice till a much later age. By then, surrounding by cousins and other kids who would turn to the red can as their choice reward for completing tasks, I had built this infallible impression of the drink. 'It will the best thing I've drank ever,' I psyched myself as I took my first sip at the age 12. **Pause**, nothing, not even the slightest flutter in my tummy. "That's it?" - I remember myself saying.

So, turns out my love for the beverage has never run deep and it is the same for most carbonated drinks. Rum and Coke? Would it be rude if I decline? ğŸ¤—; That was till I tasted the Coca-Cola chicken at @vascosingapore by @jenniferangelalee. What sorcery. I still think about it from time to time.

Today I poured half a can of coke into a chicken dish and drain poured the other half. Sue me.

Coca-Cola Chicken
Makes enough for 2
Adapted from @thewoksoflife

4 massive drumstick (I used the antibiotic-free, free range ones from @bostockbrothers in NZ)
1/2 can coke
1.5 tablespoon dark soy sauce
1/2 tablespoon light soy sauce
1 tablespoon shaoxing rice wine
Ginger, 4 slices
Dried orange peel - 1
Cinnamon stick - 1

Marinade your chicken in the coke for at least an hour.

In a wok with a little oil, fry off your ginger till fragrant. Toss in the cinnamon stick as well. Remove the chicken from the coke and brown off the drumsticks. Pour over the coke and the sauces as well as the orange peel. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer with the lid on for 18 minutes.

Remove the lid and reduce the sauce a little. Serve with white rice.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #food52

caption:
Not my first rodeo making Scotch Eggs but very well my first time sharing this recipe. It has worked for me a couple times before and trust me, these babies are good, both fresh out the fryer or cold on pique niques. That's why they are called picnic eggs!

Tune in to my stories for some behind the scenes action.

á´›Êœá´€Éª-ÉªÉ´êœ±á´˜ÉªÊ€á´‡á´… êœ±á´„á´á´›á´„Êœ á´‡É¢É¢êœ±

2 eggs
300g pork mince
1 chili padi
Coriander
1 clove garlic
1 tbsp fish sauce
White pepper
1/2 tbsp cornstarch

Egg, flour and bread crumb for coating
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
First of all, place your cold eggs in simmering boiling water for 6 minutes. Immerse those immediately in ice water to stop the cooking process. Proceed to peel after 5 minutes. Set aside.

Mix your mince together with the chopped chili padi and garlic and coriander.  Season with fish sauce and white pepper. Combine well and then incorporate with cornstarch.

Take enough mince to fit over your palm, press it to get an even layer from tip of your fingers to the base of your palm. Place egg in the center of the meat and enrobe the egg, making sure there are no cracks in the ball. Repeat and place both balls in the fridge to set for about half an hour.

Prepare the three baths, first of seasoned flour (just salt and pepper), second of a beaten egg and third of bread crumbs. Meanwhile heat up your oil till about 180Â°C. Run your 'meatballs' through the three baths and set aside as you wait for the oil to hear up.

Fry for 7 - 8 minutes or till golden brown. Leave on wire rack to cool before slicing through and devouring with Thai sweet sauce.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#scotcheggs

caption:
Does anyone else find the incessant downpours this time of year queer? Meantime, it's time to dig deep and churn out the soul foods. I'm thinking è‘±æ²¹é¥¼ (Scallion Pancake). Who's with me?
â€¢
Scallion Pancake
Ingredients
â€¢
200g flour
170g boiling water
Salt
Scallions (at least 5 full stalks, chopped)
Sesame Oil
Five Spice Powder
Sesame seeds (optional)
â€¢
In a bowl, mix flour, salt and boiling water. Using a pair of chopsticks, mix till you get scraggly lumps of dough. When it's slightly cool, knead it in the bowl for a bit then move the affair to a clean board and knead it for another 10minutes. Roll into a ball and cling film - leaving to rest for 20 minutes.

Chop up your scallions. By right, you're supposed to only use the green bits, but in the day and age, there's no call for wastage. I used the whites too.

Knead again for 5 minutes, you should get a really smooth dough, slightly elastic even. Roll into a tube and cut up in 4 equal pieces.

Using a rolling pin, stretch out the dough till almost paper thin. Brush with sesame oil, sprinkle lightly with five spice powder and salt. Cover liberally in scallions. Roll it up and shape into a snail. Leave it covered for another 20 minutes under a sheet of cling film or dish cloth. Continue with the rest of the three rolls.

Pre-heat your pan with a mix of sesame oil and regular cooking oil on medium heat. Just a light sheen. We're pan-frying, not deep-frying here. On a sesame oiled surface, smash down the snail and roll it out flat. Cook the one side for 3 minutes before flipping it over and cooking for another 2 minutes.

Prepare your dipping sauce : 3 tablespoons soy sauce, 3 tablespoons black vinegar, 1 TSP chili oil and a dash of sugar.

Slice your pancakes into quarters and dig in. Don't be scared of the thunder.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#StayHomeWithAscott #comfortfood #è‘±æ²¹é¥¼

caption:
As most people are warming up to the idea of heading outdoors to face 'the new normal', there are still plenty of dine-in options available in the interim.

And while I believe that there's a time for comfort food such as ramen and fried chicken, there should also be an opportunity for delicious peculiarities at the dining table. Nothing that I've tasted thus far have embodied such qualities as the food put out by Chef @woowaileong at @restaurantibid. His takeaway meals beginning with cheese shao bings snuffed in yeasted butter and ending with gooey black rice mochi cake crowned with oolong milk tea ice cream; keeping the family chomping relentlessly albeit with visible question marks floating above head. A renegade sort of cuisine that actually make you feel like you're stepping outside of your comfort zone, albeit at home.

A must order is their lionhead's head meatball over scallion noodles, that when broken into provides a self-saucing solution with HK curry at its heart. This and the Mapo tofu (which i implore you to mix with boiled dumplings if you have leftovers ğŸ¤Ÿ) make the perfect combination for couples. // Note that Restaurant Ibid has opened its doors to diners and will only continue this take-away/ delivery menu till the 28th June.

#savefnbsg #vscofood #sgfoodies #SGUnited

caption:
The kind of tart that make you want to break into dance and song ğŸ” // @tartebycherylkoh remains the stalwart of sweet pastry needs in Singapore and the constant innovation and sourcing is an added bonus for avid fans.

Their recent Korean Mountain Berry tart is a bejewelled beauty that reels in the wolf whistles as the tassels from her silver gown flicker in the breeze. By gosh she's beautiful â¤ï¸ and every buttery crumb giving way to shudders and audible murmurs of bliss. Aside from the fact that these berries are extremely seasonal, high in antioxidants and other health benefits, its slight tartness and explosive juicy releases make them a perfect fit to its pate sucre and custard throne.

Don't sleep in on this.

Thanks @chefolivia of @brandfitsg for sharing this with me!

#savefnbsg #tartebycherylkoh #SGUnited  #food52 #koreanmountainberry

caption:
Supper is a late night finger-licking attempt at flattening-the-bird & curve, skillet chicken at home, as inspired by @ladyandpups. It's a meal for one, upgraded by the pure fact that it begins with a French ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· jaune poulet. A Spring chicken weighing at under 400g, it's small yet goes a long way.

Skillet chicken

1 whole chicken
Salt
Black pepper
2 - 3 cloves garlic smashed

So you flip the chick on her front and approach her from the back. Things are not going to get frisky I can assure you. You might need a pair of heavy-duty scissors for this. Snip down the backbone/ remove it completely and push down heavily on the back to spread the bird into a single layer.

From here on out, a couple more snips are required to get as flat a bird as possible. It's physics, more surface area in contact with the pan, more crispy skin!

So, I remove the breastbone as well but left the wing tips on. Becoz love. Fret not, all bones went into a seperate stock which I will showcase another day.

Flip the chicken over with skin side exposed, by now, it should look like you, poolside on a deck chair after a heavy night of a drinking. Lazy and shapeless. Salt and pepper the skin of the chicken liberally and leave it in the fridge to 'dry-out' for at least 2 hours or overnight if you will.

In a cold pan, lay the chicken skin side down. No oil is required. Turn the heat on to a medium-low and leave a lid on. Leave it to render and crispen up for 20 - 25 mins (this varies extensively on the size of your chicken), at the final 5 mins mark, place 2 smashed garlic cloves in the pan with a little knob of butter.

Flip the bird over meat side and cook for another 2 - 3 minutes. Transfer it to a chopping board, leave to rest for a little while before slicing and digging in.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #SGUnited

caption:
Daddy's day means bringing the beef to the table and instead of just putting a slab on the grill, I decided to pull a #gyudon stunt on the Flatiron from @meatcosg. Slicing thinly against the grain after half an hour in the freezer, you're almost guaranteed tender results.

To accompany the meat, home pickled carrots, miso butter mushrooms , 6 1/2 minute ajitama eggs and rice. Can't be more proud of myself.

GyÅ«don
makes 2 servings

1 large onion, sliced
500g sliced beef (ribeye preferred, but the beautiful Flat-iron from @meatcosg was a perfect fit)
1 TSP sugar
3 tablespoon mirin
3 tablespoon soy sauce
1/2 cup dashi (or chicken stock)
Scallion (chopped)
Sesame seeds

Heat up 1 Tablespoon of oil in a wok and once it reaches medium heat, toss in the sliced onions and cook till translucent but not brown. This will take around 8 minutes. Be patient.

Add the beef slices and the sugar and cook till beef is slightly browned.

Pour in the sauces and the dashi. Bring to simmer, cover and leave for about 12 minutes. Taste for seasoning and add some salt if needed.

Dish out over white rice, making sure to drizzle the sauce over the rice. Top with your ajitama egg, garnish with scallions and sesame seeds.

#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52 #sgfoodies #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat Father's Day edition recommends @bochinchesg 's DIY steak sets which includes hefty pieces of steak vaccum packed with herbs and olive oil to guarantee a power-packed sear even at home.
â€¢
Read on. Things are about to get spicy.
â€¢â€¢â€¢
Steak always spark some sort of a debate in our home and amidst all this table feuds, I'm quick to realise one thing. We should never impose our own eating values on to others and similarly, we should never be forced into ordering something a certain way just because others are. i.e. Make informed decisions instead of being influenced.
â€¢
When I was getting down to cooking the steaks, I casually asked in my most jaunty  voice, "How would prefer your steak done?" - to which they both replied medium-rare please. So I did accordingly, incredibly chuffed at the visual cues of mauve red innards housed within a solid crust. Mind you, my parents are seasoned steak eaters, I'm sure, but perhaps not in the more refined establishments and also always making the safer options for cuts. They nudged their way around the more rare bits with an obvious distasteful look plastered on their faces. "It's raw," - I flew into a rage (on the inside). "Look guys, it isn't raw, it's just medium rare, the way you requested," I replied callously.  Disgruntled, I proceeded to slap the remaining slices on the pan. Using my tongs to press down with vengeance till the entire slice was cooked through. "Wah, much better," they said accompanied with voluntary thumbs up - *cue Face Palm* ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸
â€¢
Granted my frustration at the situation, I became quick to realise that we should never under any circumstances impose our values on others. I love you guys, but for goodness sakes, if you want it well-done. Just say you wanted it so from the start. ğŸ˜Œ Kthxbye.
â€¢
#SGUnited #savefnbsg #steak #bochinchesg

caption:
Kitchen off-days call for easy fix-ups such as @ippudosg D-I-Y Ramen kits. // After tackling your way through a hell lotta tiny plastic wrapping, you'll eventually wind up with a bowl of nourishing broth, melt-in-the-mouth char-siu slices and springy noodles. Just as you would outside! All you'll have to do is drop in that magic 6 1/2 minute ajitama egg and garnish with spring onions for a meal that's set to sweep away all the bad omens in your life.

Do check out their hakata style gyoza and char siu sets while you're at it. It's always good fun to mix it up and dish it up 'omakase' style to the fam!
~~~~~
Jammy Eggs
Recipe adapted from @vickiima

3 eggs
3 tablespoon Chinese rice wine
2 TSP sugar
2 tablespoon soy sauce
5 tablespoon water

Boil a pot of water sufficient enough to fully submerge 3 eggs.

Once on a rolling boil, put in your 3 cold eggs straight from the fridge into the water carefully using a slotted spoon. Lower the heat to a simmer.

Set your timing for exactly 6 1/2 minutes and once that's done, remove the eggs and dunk them into ice cold water to stop the cooking process.

Prepare the marinade in a deep bowl. Making sure to try and dissolve the sugar.

Peel the eggs and soak them in the marinade, making sure to turn them ever so often to allow the flavours to sink in. Leave in the fridge from anywhere between 3 hours to overnight.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #ippudoramen #diyramenkit #stayhome #circuitbreaker #food52

caption:
Since I've subscribed to Korean #CheonggyewonEgg, there's no turning back. Our daily consumption of eggs coupled with  the fact that these antibiotic-free eggs are incredibly fresh justifying their prime real estate in my fridge. Best part, they are just a hop and a skip away at my neighborhood Cold Storage.

If you're gunning for an 'imitation' {Egg Slut} at home, here's how it goes.

First crack three eggs straight into a cold pan and throw in a big knob of butter. Don't stinge. Stir the eggs and butter together even before turning on the pilot light. "Almost till it forms like a sauce," says Alvin Cailan. Put the pan on medium heat and continue stirring with your spatula to create a velvety texture. Be sure to constantly scrape the bottoms of the pan and fold your eggs over to create loose layers. When the eggs start to bind, remove from the heat. These babies are ready. Sprinkle your chives over and spoon lovingly over your toasted buns.

#coldchainsystem #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisaster #eggslut #food52

When I can't contain my excitement...

Liu Sha Bao
Makes enough fillings for 5 buns

2 salted duck eggs steamed
40g butter, melted and cooled
12g icing sugar
4g cornflour
20g milk powder
14ml fresh milk

Steam your duck eggs and squish with a fork. Blend in your butter with a tiny whisk and continue to blend in icing sugar, cornflour and milk powder till a paste. Whisk in fresh milk and making sure there are no lumps. Set aside in the fridge it freezer till set. You'll want to portion out 20g of filling per 40g Dough ball.

caption:
And out of all the lunch items that graced our lunch table today, the humble sounding Kimchi pancake is that one that we end up talking about for days.

Kimchi Pancake
Makes one large pancake

1 small onion, thinly sliced
2/3 cup kimchi, chopped with your handy kitchen scissors (@wealllovekimchi being my chosen subject today for its subtle sour and nutty notes)
A bunch of at least 4 scallions, chopped

Pancake batter
1 cup of flour - 4 tbsp flour (remove from)
1 tbsp cornstarch
1 TSP gochujang
1 tbsp kimchi juice
2/3 cup ice water

Prepare all your ingredients before hand, slicing everything and setting aside.

For the batter, dissolve gochujang and kimchi juice in the water. Give it a good stir, then slowly incorporate it into the dry ingredients, whisking to make sure there are no lumps. Do not overmix.

In a large bowl, mix the two together till everything is evenly spread out.

Warm a skillet with a tablespoon of oil on medium-high heat. once hot enough, pour in all your batter and using a spatula, spread out across the pan to get a flat layer. Cook for at least 4 minutes on one side before attempting to flip. Cook for the same amount of time on that side then flip again. Cook till brown on both sides. Slide it on to a plate as best a you can and serve with dipping sauce (equal parts soy sauce, water and a days of vinegar).
~~~~~~
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #StayHomeWithAscott #food52#wealllovekimchi #kimchipancake #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Braising or Bracing for this weekend? As everyone let's loose their pent-up frustrations from the #circuitbreaker, I'm going to be cocooned at home and cooking up a couple of recipes. Stay with me?

Taiwanese Braised Pork Noodles
æ»·è‚‰é¢
Makes enough for 4

500g pork belly
Oil
2 tsp caster sugar
6 shiitake mushroom
1/4 cup shaoxing wine
3 tablespoon light soy sauce
3 tablespoon dark soy sauce
2cm ginger minced
5 cloves garlic minced
1 small onion, chopped finely
1 TSP Szechuan peppercorn
1 cinnamon stick
3 star anise
6 cloves
1 TSP five-spice powder
500ml water

400g laksa noodles or white rice noodles
Green leafy vegetables
~~~~~
Slice the pork belly to 1 inch slices and poach in boiling water for about 2 minutes. Soak your shiitake mushrooms in boiling water for 20 minutes and slice into tiny pieces.

Prepare the rest of your ingredients. If you have a tea sachet, put the peppercorn, cinnamon stick, star anise, cloves into it. In a wok, fry off the onion first till soft then add in the minced ginger and garlic. Add in your shiitake mushrooms and finally the blanched pork belly pieces. Brown on high heat. Add in the light soy, dark soy sauce and the shaoxing wine and the water. Bring to a boil and add in the bag of spices together with one teaspoon of five spice powder.

Bring heat back down to a simmer and leave to slow-cook for at least 2.5 hours. At the end, remove the spice packet and reduce the sauce by leaving the lid open.

Blanch your noodles and greens and toss it into the sauce. Dish out into bowls.

#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
If you're looking at making a little pick-me-up for dad this coming Father's Day. This is an easy one that he will think took mammoth effort to reproduce. Bonus: it's mighty fun to make for those itching for a little bit of self-worth enhancing, hands-on action in the kitchen.

Kueh Ondeh Ondeh
Makes about 25 - 30

250g glutinous rice flour
1 tbsp brown sugar
250ml water blended with 5 pieces of pandan leaf chopped up
1 tbsp oil

100 gula melaka

150g grated coconut
Pinch of salt

Go ahead and steam your grated coconut combined with the salt for about 10 minutes. Remove and let cool.

Meantime make your dough by blending water together with the pandan leaves and putting that through a fine sieve. Making sure to press out all the pandan juice. Heat that in a pot till almost simmering.

Combine your glutinous rice flour and brown sugar. Making a well in the middle. Pour in the warm pandan juice and work it using chopsticks to form a paste. As larger crumbs start to form, pour in the oil and continue to work it till it's cool enough to maneuver with your fingers. Knead the dough till smooth and less sticky to the touch. Rest the dough underneath a damp towel.

Go ahead and chop your gula melaka into  tiny chunks. Set aside and please resist the urge to snack.

Measure out 13 - 15g pieces of dough. Roll into a ball and using your thumb, press out an indentation in the center which you'll then fill with gula melaka. Pinch the seams to seal the sugar in and roll out again into a  smooth ball.

By this time, you should have a pot of water on a rolling boil ready. Plop your balls into the water and leave them in there till they start to float (6 - 7 mins) and using a sieve, rescue them and roll them around in the bowl of steamed coconut you had set aside just now.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

#SihanSayDaBaoWhat for Father's Day || ğŸ¥©, that's an easy one. Be brave and order the Tomahawk from @morganfieldssingapore, it's got the goods to trigger that 'jaw-dropping' reaction from dad. Which is exactly what you want, isn't it?

caption:
Technically, there are no hacks to putting caviar on your breakfast menu. It's a good fit with any form of carbs, waffles, tater tots, pancakes, you name it and it's been there.

One of new-found favourite ways to consume your morning dose of posh roe is on crisp rÃ¶sti dollop with crÃ¨me fraÃ®che. Enjoy with a mimosa, or a coffee (if you're the hoi polloi like me) with your pinkie up, because you are fancy now.

RÃ¶sti for one

1 large russet potato
1 Tablespoon of ghee
Salt, pepper, cayenne pepper
Creme fraÃ®che
Caviar (@caviarcolony Amur for a touch of nuttiness)

Par-boil your potato in slightly salted waters for a good 12 minutes. Fish out and set aside on a plate in the fridge.

Forget about it for at least 2 hours.

Grate the potato coarsely and salt it immediately. After about 10 minutes or so, drain out the water, lightly squeeze the potato strips to rid of excess moisture - this will ensure a crisper rÃ¶sti. Toss with cayenne pepper and ground black pepper. Heat your mini pan up with a little ghee (butter is fine too) until sizzling. Stack your grated potatoes in the pan and press down lightly to squash the sides for as flat a surface as possible.

Cook for a couple of minutes then gently free the sides. Drizzle a little ghee on the top surface. After about 8 minutes. Invert the pan on to a plate and then slide that back into the pan to cook the other side. Continue to cook for another 8 minutes till nice and crispy.

Wait at least 5 minutes for the rÃ¶sti to cool before topping with your creme fraÃ®che and caviar. Devour with panache.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #caviarcolonysg

caption:
True friends are with you the good times, the bad and the very plebian times in between. There are friends who evoke warmth with just a brief encounter, friends who influence everyone around them like a ray of sunshine. Some friendships go stale when they're canned, or when (feelings are) bottled up. It's a simple truth, you'll always find a bosom buddy at the bottom of a bone broth. Trust me on that one. Screw the shelved versions.

Slowcooker Beef Bone Broth
Makes enough for 4

800g beef bones
1 large yellow onion
2 cloves of garlic, smashed
1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar
2 tablespoon light soy sauce
1 Tablespoon white peppercorns
1 TSP coriander seeds
3 cloves
1 star anise

Pre-heat your oven to 250Â°C. Place your bones on a baking sheet and roast bones till browned. About 20 mins.

Place roasted beef bones, drippings and all other ingredients with about 6 - 7 cups of water into a slow cooker / crock pot. Cook on low for 8 -12 hours.

You can go the extra mile to put this in the fridge and remove the solidified fat from the top of the chilled broth if you prefer a cleaner soup. I however relished in its oleginaous disposition. *Slurp slurp*

Serve with fresh rice noodles, thinly sliced raw beef, beam sprouts, lime wedges and cilantro for that perfect rainy day treat.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott

Comprising of Brazilian arabica beans and a hint of chicory, the result is a surprisingly smooth and nut-laced brew that would go perfectly with a glug of milk. caption:
Of the many missed opportunities in my life, not actively volunteering to cook with my popo before she passed on (with her legacy of curry puffs and oxtail stew under her sleeves) may be one of my biggest regrets. That alongside, not agreeing to go out on a date with @mathieumusnier the first time he ever asked me. ğŸ˜‰.
~
 Meanwhile, the Covid-19 induced home kitchen business is on a roll. Many of them riding on the backbone of age old recipes from the older generation, bankrolled by the loving kids. It's heart-warming and deeply accented when the final product exudes love and back-breaking work. You just know.
~
@ahmayamcake is one such fine example. The aluminium trays holding fine specimens of silky steamed yam cake littered with salted prawns, pork and mushrooms. It's a party on its own but achieves great-gatsby genre with a quick stir-fry with minced garlic and broken egg. // Visit their socials to place your orders and DO NOT pass up on their hae bee hiam chili. That shit is dope.

Stir-fried Yam Cake with egg

500g yam cake, cubed
1 clove garlic, minced
2 eggs, beaten
Scallion, chopped
1/2 tbsp sambal chili
Fried shallots

Beansprouts (optional)

1 tbsp kecap Manis (If you prefer the dark carrot cake version)
1 TSP oyster sauce
1 TSP light soy sauce (both not needed in the case of using above mentioned yam cake, but if you're using a generic brand, seasoning is required)
Sesame oil

First in a wok with a little bit of oil, fry up the garlic till fragrant then add in the cubed yam cake and bump up the heat to high. Add the seasoning in (if required) and then allow the cake to crispen evenly. Make a little space for the eggs, you might want to add a little bit more oil and then allow the eggs to semi set first before scrambling it with the yam cake. Add in your chopped scallions and give a couple of tosses.

Serve with fried shallots and a drizzle of sesame oil.
~
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat #SGUnited #savefnbsg #ahmayamcake #sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen

caption:
Got caught in a little bit of a sharp shower  doing groceries this morning and decided, what the heck, to intoxicate my lunch with wine as well. Made a {Coq au vin blanc} which makes it hella more sexy than the rudimentary sounding Chicken in white wine sauce, but in true essence, she's all that.

Coq au vin blanc or Chicken in creamy white wine sauce
Makes enough for 3 - 4

600g boneless chicken thigh
3 garlic cloves
4 rashes of bacon, sliced
1 brown onion, finely sliced
1 cup dry white wine
250g oyster mushroom, sliced
1/4 cup pork stock
Sprinkle of dry sage
Black pepper
100ml crÃ¨me fraÃ®che

Finely chopped parsley (I used Korean perilla leaf)

Preheat your oven to 180Â°C. You'll want to be working in a cast iron skillet that's oven safe. If not, I would suggest cooking in a skillet and then transferring everything to a casserole dish.

Heat a little olive oil in a skillet. Fry your bacon till slightly crisp. Set aside. In the same pan, brown off your chicken, skin side down until golden brown. Turn to the other side and cook for 1 minutes. Remove from pan and set aside in the casserole dish.

In the same pan, reduce heat to a medium, melt a knob of butter an soften your onions. Add in the garlic and fry till fragrant. Then toss in the oyster mushrooms and bacon. After about a minute, deglaze the skillet with white wine, making sure to scrap the bottom of the skillet for the desirable brown bits. Add stock and bring to a simmer. Season with dried sage and black pepper.

Pour over the arranged browned chicken thighs. Making sure to arrange the chicken skin side up on the surface of the dish.

Put the lid on and bake for 45 minutes with lid one. Bake for another 10 - 15 minutes with the lid off to achieve crispy brown skin.

Move the chicken to the side of the dish, incorporate crÃ¨me fraÃ®che by stirring it in to get a creamy sauce. YAS.

Serve with fresh bread, pasta or cheesy mashed potatoes. Either way, trust that you'll have no regrets.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
comments: ['Looks so mouthwatering ğŸ¤¤', 'I really love the name', 'Creamy and delicious! Yum!!', 'Oh my. This looks so so good!!!', 'Did you make with Riesling?ğŸ˜', 'Love a good coq au vin']

caption:
Not too late to get your babka dough mixed and tucked away in the fridge for some sleep. Sure, round up a Balvenie Old Fashioned as your cheerleader and chug through that 15 - 20mins of prep time tonight. Trust me, the overwhelming response of warmth you'll receive after the second proof makes everything worth it.

And if you've missed the recipe the first time, here goes.

Chocolate Babka
makes 3 mini loaves

350g all purpose flour
67g sugar
7g dry yeast
2 eggs
80g lukewarm water
1/2 TSP salt
100g butter, cubed

200g gianduja paste or Nutella
60g chocolate, chopped

In a stand-mixer with a dough hook, combine the flour, sugar and yeast. Add in the eggs and the water and mix to form a dough. Once it starts to come together, sprinkle in the salt and start to feed the dough, cubes of butter, little by little. Keep the machine going for 10 mins or till the dough starts to peel away from the sides.

Put the dough in a lightly oiled bowl and cling-wrap the top to ensure it's air tight. Leave in the fridge overnight or for at least 8 hours. This will help with the ease of rolling out in the morning.

Divide the dough into 3. Roll each one to about 7.5 x 6 inches. Spread chocolate all over, leaving about an inch gap at the end. Scatter chopped chocolate. Roll it up to form a log. With the seamed side down, use a knife and slice it right through the center. Squish down one end and then work the two logs into a simple 2-ply plait with the chocolatey innards showing outwards. Fold and shape the braid and fit it in those buttered up loaf tins. You can refer to my drawings â¡ï¸ if you like.

Leave to proof in a warm place for 45 mins. Take the time to whisper sweet nothing to them, they like that. Bake in a 190Â°C oven for 26 minutes. Take them out and brush over a simple syrup. Cool and conquer.

#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #f52grams #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Never you mind where the evening might find us. Distance can't take what's safely hidden away in my chest â¤ï¸.
~~~~~~~~~~
Been a month since I cooked æ»·è‚‰é¥­ for the Frenchie and I could tell straight away from our afternoon/get-up exchanges that he misses it fondly.

For a dish that reverberates love with every bite. Cook this ğŸ‘‡:
~~~~~~~~~~
æ»·è‚‰é¥­
Makes enough for 4

500g pork belly
Oil
2 tsp caster sugar
6 shiitake mushroom
1/4 cup shaoxing wine
3 tablespoon light soy sauce
3 tablespoon dark soy sauce
2cm ginger minced
5 cloves garlic minced
1 small onion, chopped finely
1 TSP Szechuan peppercorn
1 cinnamon stick
3 star anise
6 cloves
1 TSP five-spice powder
500ml water

Slice the pork belly to 1 inch slices and poach in boiling water for about 2 minutes. Soak your shiitake mushrooms in boiling water for 20 minutes and slice into tiny pieces.

Prepare the rest of your ingredients. If you have a tea sachet, put the peppercorn, cinnamon stick, star anise, cloves into it. In a wok, fry off the onion first till soft then add in the minced ginger and garlic. Add in your shiitake mushrooms and finally the blanched pork belly pieces. Brown on high heat. Add in the light soy, dark soy sauce and the shaoxing wine and the water. Bring to a boil and add in the bag of spices together with one teaspoon of five spice powder.

Bring heat back down to a simmer and leave to slow-cook for at least 2.5 hours. At the end, remove the spice packet and reduce the sauce by leaving the lid open. Dish out over white rice with blanched greens and ramen egg.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Easing into Mondays the only way I know how - scrambled eggs. Much needed, after some jittery swells from good news received from the Frenchie about borders being opened on the 1st July in the wee hours of the morning. These news however plagued with uncertainty in the specifics.

Cracking open 3 eggs, I beat them with my indispensable tiny beater with a pinch of sea salt until bubbles form on top. Then I leave this weaves of whites and yellows to mingle for 15 minutes on the counter top (top tip for tender eggs as salt dissolves the proteins and assists in creating a tighter moisture-binding network) as I get on with the morning coffee. Heating up the pan, I add in a dash of milk and a chunk of butter to the eggs. I then cook the eggs over a low flame, stirring constantly. The result is a cascade of fluff, soft on the verge of custardy scrambled eggs.

Caviar on Monday. Why not?

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #scrambledeggs #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
Applying the same logic behind kimchi fried rice, I took the rebellious child on a pasta run and gosh the results wound up being something that might edge out even my next revisit to good ole' Carbonara. Creamy, tangy and laced with smoky fats, it's the sort of combination that makes you embrace 'fusion' all over again.

Kimchi Tagliatelle
Makes enough to feed 2 peckish eaters

120g dried tagliatelle
1/3 cup kimchi (@wealllovekimchi)
1 clove garlic, minced
6 TSP kimchi juice
1 TSP gochujang or doubanjiang
1 knob of butter
4 strips of bacon
A handful of shredded Edam cheese/ cheddar cheese
Scallions sliced on a diagonal

Slice your bacon into tiny slices and set aside. In a bowl and using a pair of nifty scissors, slice the kimchi into tiny slices; in the Korean kitchen, it's an indispensable tool âœ‚ï¸. Mince your garlic. Prepare your sauce, in a seperate bowl, combine the kimchi juice and TSP of gochujang together.

Cook your tagliatelle or your choice of pasta about 2 minutes less than the package recommends. I cooked mine for 6.5 mins. When you're into 2 minutes of the cook, heat up a skillet with olive oil, fry bacon for about 2 minutes, add in the Garlic and fry it till slightly brown. Now add in the chopped kimchi and keep stirring.

Once the pasta is ready, drain it and reserve some of the pasta water. Introduce your kimchi juice sauce and about 1/4 cup of pasta water into the pan. Toss in the pasta. Add in a healthy knob of butter to loosen the mixture. Add in cheese if it's at your disposal (I like that subtle inflections of foreign influence here) then with the flame switched off, toss to emulsify and dish out piping hot.

Garnish with spring onions and a #CheonggyewonEgg fried egg.
~~~
@Welovekimchi are small batch kimchi makers that guarantee fresh, preservative-free bottles of probiotic goodness. Pre-orders for 20th June have just started in limited quantities so head on over to their socials for order info!

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #stfoodtrending #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Taking a break from the kitchen this afternoon with some meats stacks from @wildfireburgers.sg. Unlike a year ago when over-the-top monsta creations were invading front pages, now there's a new vogue for value-for-money yet quality online purchases. And so far, Wildfire is at the top of their game.

A mindful mixing of flavours from char to sweetness of caramelised onions and heat from chipotle mayo deny the necessity for volume by double meat patties. That also ensures the burgers transport well. I don't have to twist your arm to tell you to order the Shabu Burger - black Angus beef shabu cooked in yakiniku sauce, shimeiji mushrooms and goma sauce. It reads like a dream and taste like a gyÅ«don had put on a spanking brand new suit. Both the @snakeriverfarms wagyu burger and Shabu burger are priced at $13 whilst the eggstarter (a glorious take on the bacon egg roll) is just $9.

A therapy, or affordable luxury that you just might need occasionally during these times.

#SihanSayDaBaoWhat #SGUnited #savefnbsg #burpple #stfoodtrending #food52 #burgersaremynemesis #weaccidentallyaburger

caption:
Who misses weekend Dim Sum lunches? I do. Whenever I'm seated at one of those large tables, engaging in chopsticks war with the family, {Siu Mai} is my standard order. Delicious irresistible morsels of plump prawn and pork revealed in its steaming glory.

To say that these are the best I've ever had, would be grossly patronising, but to have the liberty to top it with whatever pleases you, now that deserves the accompaniment of some champagne. Today's crowning glory courtesy of @caviarcolony.
â€¢â€¢â€¢
Siu Mai
Makes 20

Egg wanton wrappers (get the round ones, I struggled a little with the edges of the square)
120g prawns, de-shelled
280g pork mince, the fattier the better
1 TSP soy sauce
1 tbsp Chinese rice wine
1/2 TSP salt
2 TSP sugar
3 scallion stalks, just the base, finely minced
3 dried shiitake mushrooms

Garnish: XO sauce + Caviar if you're feeling like a baller.

Soak your dried mushrooms in hot water for 20 mins. De-stem and slice the caps into tiny pieces.

Mix the pork mince with soy sauce, Chinese rice wine, salt and sugar in a bowl. Using your fingers and rotating in a single direction till it starts to form a paste. Chop your prawns into 1/2 cm pieces, toss that in with the minced pork, chopped scallions and mushrooms. It's a party. Combine.

Prepare your perforated wax paper by cutting holes in non-stick baking paper and mounting it into the bamboo steaming baskets. Heat up water in your wok till it's at a rolling boil.

Start filling your egg wrappers. You'll want to use your thumb and index finger to form an 'o' then using your middle finger as a base, push the meat mixture into the 'o', filling up the base edges to get an even package. It take practise but you'll eventually get the hang of it. 
Top the dumplings with a little bit of XO sauce (optional) at this point. You can also top with chopped carrot or peas for colour. Put the lid on and steam for 7 - 8 minutes.

Top with @caviarcolony Amur caviar, pop those piping-hot parcels into your mouth instantly. Regret a little, hang your mouth open and commence eating with a 'humph'. So good.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52
#caviarcolonysg #foodporn #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
Keeping things unfamiliar is the best way to be rewarded with unexpected surprises. Admittedly some not so pleasant at times but today's little experiment worked out just fine.

Baked Halibut on cauliflower puree

250g Halibut (from @superseafoodsg)
Half head of cauliflower (about 250 - 300g)
1 cup milk
Scallions (2, including the white part)
1/2 red onion (sliced thinly)
1 tablespoon raisins
2 tablespoon red wine vinegar
Salt and pepper
Coriander, sliced
Olive oil

Preheat the oven to 150Â°C. Coat the dish in olive oil and season with salt. Bake the fish for 30 minutes. Checking once the timer hits 25 minutes.

Meanwhile, prepare your red onion dressing. Slice up the red onion and mix with raisins and red wine vinegar. Season with black pepper and set aside.

Place your cut up cauliflower florets in a pot with milk and chopped up scallions. Cook over medium heat for 15 minutes and blend it to give a smooth puree. Season with salt and pepper and a shaving of nutmeg if you have.

Plate up and enjoy whilst its hot!

#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #superseafoodsg

caption:
Eggs are the standard workhorses of breakfasts around the world. Today I travel to ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Korea with their ubiquitous street snack - Gyeran-Bbang - a savoury sweet treat that straddles the ranks of bread and pancake.

#CheonggyewonEgg Korean eggs fanned out over a simple batter to drive the Korean roots deeper.

Korean Egg Bread
Makes 4 muffins

1/3 cup flour
2.5 tablespoon caster sugar
5/8  TSP baking powder
1/8 TSP salt
1 egg
40g milk
40g butter, melted
4 #CheonggyewonEgg eggs
Cheese (optional)
Dried Sage (optional)
Black pepper
Sea salt for the top

Preheat your oven to 180Â°C. Brush your muffin tins with butter.

Sift the flour, caster sugar, baking powder and salt in a bowl. In another bowl, whisk the egg, milk, melted butter together.

Combine the two of them, whisking to make sure there are no lumps. Fill each muffin tin up to 1/3 full and break an individual egg over the top. At this stage, you might want to add sliced ham, cheese, sage, even bacon. Whatever you've got the feels for this morning.

Bake for 20 - 25 minutes. Cool tray for 3-4 minutes and enjoy it while it's still warm.

#CheonggyewonEgg #egg #coldchainsystem #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #sskitchendisasters #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
It's a thankless job sometimes cooking lunch on a workday for the family, and i wouldn't wish an elaborate recipe upon anyone's midday.

Luckily I've got a few tricks up my sleeves when it comes to dealing with salmon fillets. Quick and easy, the end product is still a show-off.

Creamy Salmon Pasta
Makes enough for 3

250g salmon fillet, skin-on (we got ours from @superseafoodsg)
2 cloves garlic finely chopped
1/2 onion, sliced thinly
1/2 cup milk
Big knob of butter
200g dried pasta
1 TSP lemon juice

Peas, spinach, optional

Sear your salmon fillet, skin side down first. Salt the fillet and cook for about 4 minutes on each side. Set aside.

While the salmon is cooking, boil your pasta in salted waters for 7 - 8 minutes. Drain and reserve a bit of the pasta water for later.

Heat up some a splash of olive oil in a sauce pan. SautÃ© your onion till soft and then add in the garlic and fry till slightly brown. Pour in your milk and slide in the knob of butter. Emulsify with 2 tablespoon of pasta water, the present thickeners in the pasta water forming some sterling relationships with whatever hot fat hanging out in your pan. Let simmer a little while. Add in the pasta and toss to coat. Reintroduce your salmon, breaking it into smaller pieces and mixing it through the pasta. Season to taste and serve hot.

#sskitchendisasters #burpple #stfoodtrending #fundamentallyflawedkitchen
#superseafoodsg

caption:
Cheesy roll-ups for a gloomy morning. Here's a food idea that I stumbled upon that the kids will not only love to eat but it's incredibly fun to make as well. Designed to appeal to the little munchkins who love to pick out the crust on their grilled cheese sandwiches - even the adults will want in on these.

Grilled cheese roll-ups

2 regular slices of loaf bread (this recipe doesn't discriminate against sunshine or gardenia ğŸ¤Ÿ)
Cheese slices (I see thinly sliced Greek  Graviera cheese from @classicdelisg, but you can use gruyÃ¨re, Colby, muenster, etc)
Butter and olive oil

Using a small rolling pin, roll out the bread slices. Really flattening them out. Trim out the edges using a knife. Roll the cheese within the slices and form tight scrolls.

Warm your pan to medium heat with some butter and olive oil. Place both your scrolls in the pan and slowly start to crispen them up. Rotating them slowly so that they achieve even browning.

Slice into tiny bites and serve. I would a nice Passata alongside this for dipping but they are plenty good on its own.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
I'm a little obsessive about keeping the random jars of condiments in my fridge to a bare minimum. Who here thinks that that department is getting a little out of hand?

So when I received my order of Korean flower clams from @superseafoodsg, I instinctively turned to my fridge for inspiration. Sure I would have love to do a stir-fry with doubanjiang and garlic, unfortunately I was not about to adopt another bottle with little real estate to spare. So here's one recipe that I created on the fly and I could tell it hit the spot - just based on the fact that my dad was dredging vegetables through that sauce at the final leg.

Miso stir-fry clam
Makes enough for 3

500g clams
3 cloves garlic minced
2 chili padi, sliced thinly
4 stalks of scallions cut into 3 inch lengths
1 cm of ginger, cut into thin slices

1 tbsp white miso
1 tbsp Chinese rice wine
1/2 TSP sugar
1 TSP tahini - courtesy of @mathieumusnier
2 tbsp water

Mix up the sauce first in a bowl. Set aside.

In a wok with some oil. Toss in the ginger slices and fry till fragrant. The garlic goes in next and on medium high heat, fry till almost brown before adding in the chili padi. There will be lots of choking at this point but stay strong. Add in your clams at this point and the sauce that you've set aside. Toss gently to make sure all the clams are coated before putting a lid on and steaming for about a minute or so till most of the clams have opened up.

Remove the lid. Throw in the spring onion and toss through. Once the sauce has thickened slightly, plate up.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #seafooddiet #savefnbsg #superseafoodsg #food52

caption:
The number of chiffon cakes I've baked in my life can be counted with the fingers on my hands. It's daunting, I admit. As much as you write it off as just a tall airy cake and lightly fragrant, the path to achieving a great one is tainted with many booby traps. The intrepid in me is in love with the flavours and nostalgia. But refusing to clean up the mess of a failed attempt, I usually outsource this happiness.

One recent chiffon cake that I've been smitten with is @absolutefluffy 's super-XXL-sized-cloud-of-pandan-orgasm-in-the-mouth Chiffon cake. Picture this, your room pre-Marie Kondo state, then instead of having to throw away your favourite fluffy jersey from primary school days, you get to squirrel it away into a state-of-the-art, magic wardrobe. Best part, it rolls snugly under your bed.

YES, it is both collapsible satisfaction and stowed-away secrets in every bite. //Order details up on their social @absolutefluffy. ~~~
#SGUnited #savefnbsg #chiffoncake #SihanSayDaBaoWhat #absolutefluffy

caption:
Egg(s) in purgatory: you can almost feel the egg's frustration as it is left stranded in the bubbling seas of red tomato sauce.  Pretty sure it was named by the Catholic nuns to evoke fear of being a lost soul. And as morbid as my breakfast's name rolls off the tongue, it was mad delicious.

Eggs in Purgatory
Makes for one lonely soul

1/2 cup chopped tomatoes
1 clove garlic, thinly sliced
Extra virgin olive oil
Salt and pepper to taste
Grated parmesan
Knob of butter
Red pepper flakes
1/4 TSP dried sage
1 egg
Sliced toasted bread (I used Altamura bread from @braci.sg because I'm sticking to the ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹ theme)
â€¢â€¢â€¢
In a small skillet, heat up a swig of olive oil. Scatter in your garlic and chili flakes. Stir for about half a minute.

Tip in your tomatoes, stir in the dried sage and let it come to a bubble. Season to taste.  Let it bubble for another 5 minutes. Using a spatula, gently nudge a tiny indentation for the egg to sit in.

You can add in your butter at this point because just like any other sinful endeavour, it belongs in hell. ğŸ”¥ğŸ˜ˆ Okay, where were we. Crack your egg(s), sprinkle parmesan around the sides and bring the heat down to low. Allow the egg(s) to gently poach for another 5 minutes, enough time for you to contemplate life and toast some bread.

Remove from the heat, sprinkle over a little more parmesan if you wish. Dig in.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #eggsinpurgatory #CheonggyewonEgg #food52

Something definitely worth mopping all those artisan bread into.', 'I love the name! And your caption of it! Mad fan of you now â¤ï¸', 'Love your rendition ğŸ˜‚ will definitely try this , looks delicious ğŸ˜‹', 'this looks amazingğŸ¤¤', 'Bomb!! ğŸ˜']

caption:
I would like to think that the #circuitbreaker is making me a better cook for my future children. There are days that I picture kids wringing shredded cucumber out of their bowls or pushing vinegary chicken off their plates. Then this dish comes along and blows things out of the water. Kids, they are gonna love this.

Chopped steaks and gravy on rice
Makes enough for 1 hungry kid

150g ground beef
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1/2 tablespoon dark soy sauce
1 tablespoon ketchup
1 TSP garlic powder
1 TSP onion powder
Salt and pepper to taste
1 cup sliced mushrooms (I used oyster)
1 small onion, sliced thinly
1 cup beef broth
Oil
1 heaping tablespoon flour

Heat oil in a skillet till hot. Sear the beef patties for about 2 minutes in each side till a nice crust is formed. Set aside on a plate.

In the same skillet, add the onions, mushrooms. Sprinkle over the flour and stir it in, making sure to cook out the starches for about a minute.

Add in the beef broth, ketchup and soy sauces and scrape out the brown bits from the bottom of the pan. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for about 5 minutes till thickened.

Add the patty or patties back to the pan and simmer for 5 more minutes.

Serve over white rice and I assure you, you've got a happy camper.

#sskitchendisasters #food52 #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #comfortfood

caption:
My fascination with eggs at breakkie continues with the Taiwanese Egg Crepe Roll or è›‹é¤… Dan Bing.

It's a full 10 mins worth your time and effort. ğŸ” Look at dat. I think I just lit a fire under your ass. And the best part is, I've adjusted the recipe to make just one lonely egg crepe. No scrambling with excess batter.

è›‹é¤…
Makes one

3 tablespoon a.p flour
2 TSP cornstarch
Pinch of salt
60g water
Scallions, chopped (I did about 5)
1 egg, lightly whisked. Make it 2, if you're an egg fanatic.
Sesame oil for frying

Dipping sauce
1 TSP spicy fermented bean paste
1 TSP soy sauce
I also added some chili oil in there. Totally optional

Give your sauce a stir. Set aside.

Whisk flour, salt and cornstarch together. Whisk in the water a little at a time, making sure there are no lumps. Chop your scallions into the mix using a pair of scissors. Heat up your pan with some sesame oil on medium heat. Whisk your egg in another bowl and set aside.

Pour in all your batter at one shot and attempt to spread it out evenly by giving the pan a playful swirl. Cook for half a minute until the pancake looks half cooked. Pour over the egg mixture.

At this point, you're free to throw in cheese, tuna flakes and whatever you please into the mix. Go crazy.

Continue cooking till the egg looks set and the with the aid of a spatula and perhaps a pair of chopsticks, start to roll the pancake.

Add a little more sesame oil to the pan. Turn up the heat and try to crispen the rolled up pancakes on both sides. Be sure not to overcook as the result can be quite tough if the egg scroll over stays its welcome on the pan.

Slice up and serve with the dipping sauce.

#sskitchendisasters #BudgetTenDollars #food52 #fundamentallyflawedkitchen

caption:
æ£’æ£’é¸¡ Bang Bang Chicken or ::Szechuan Chinese Chicken Salad:: as I call it,  is the sort of dish you would imagine as a cold appetiser dish at a Chinese family's Super Bowl Party. Salty, sweet, spicy and just a tad tangy from the sauces smothered over. It can be tossed together much earlier in the game, the blank canvas of chicken breast providing the perfect platform for the æ€ªå‘³ "strange flavour" sauce to shine. Its name is derived from the sound of the rolling pin bearing down as it flattens the poached chicken and paving the way for easy shredding. Alternatively you can do it the good old fashioned way, with your finger tips if you're not one to favour the ruckus.

Bang Bang Chicken (Szechuan style)
Makes enough for 4

A 225g chicken breast poached in 2 cups of water with 3 slices of ginger and 2 scallions knotted together (simmer on a rolling boil for 6 mins, turn off the heat and leave, covered in pot for 15 mins. Remove from pot into ice bath)
1/2 cucumber (julienned) - I used a zucchini
1/2 cup chicken stock (reserved from the poaching chicken liquids earlier)
2 tablespoon light soy sauce
1/2 tablespoon dark soy sauce
2 Tablespoon black vinegar
1 tablespoon chili oil + dried chili
1 tablespoon sugar
1 tablespoon sesame oil
2 tablespoon toasted sesame seeds
1 TSP Sichuan peppercorns, grounded
1/2 TSP salt
2 scallions, chopped

Poach your chicken as instructed above. Shred or bang bang if you prefer.

Lay your julienned cucumber on the bottom of the dish followes by the chicken shreds. Prepare the sauce in a small pot, chicken stock, sugar, sauces, sesame oil, seeds and scallions. It's gonna look like a mad tasty party already.

Pour over the chicken and cucumber. Toss to coat when you're ready to eat. Rice or cold noodles, it's all very complimentary and also perfect for the sweltering weather.

Recipe adapted from the awesome folks at @thewoksoflife ğŸ¤Ÿ

#sskitchendisasters #vscofood #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #burpple #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Solidly engineered kimchi from @lees_kimchi_sg finds a place in today's lunch menu - Korean pork kimchi stir-fry. It is a mess of a dish; juicy strips of pork nicely balanced with gentle hits of acidity from the fermented cabbage. Still slightly crunchy onions provide occasional respite from the rather 'soft' textural plight.

A dish that takes me back to my days of living in Strathfield in Sydney instantly. Those were times of beer towers, late night fried chicken and cheap Korean fringe trims. Good times.

Kimchi Pork stir-fry
Makes a mountain good to feed 4

300g thin sliced pork (you can use belly, I did the shabu shabu pork from @yakiniku_plaza)
400g kimchi
1 onion, sliced thinly
1 Tablespoon red miso
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1 TSP paprika
1 TSP chili powder
1 tablespoon sugar
2 tablespoon of water
Spring onions and sesame seeds for garnish

In a wok, fry up the pork in a little bit of oil. Combine the red miso, soy sauce, chili powder and paprika to make a sauce. Alternatively you can use a heaping tablespoon of gochujang if you have at home. Add that to the wok with your kimchi and stir fry till 60% cooked. Throw in your sliced onions and sugar and stir it a little. Add some water to the pan and put the lid on for about 1 minute. Fry for another minute and plate up. Garnish with sesame seeds and spring onions and serve with white rice or lettuce leaves as wraps. From wok to the table in just under 6 minutes. What's not to like?

#sskitchendisasters #food52 #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
While attempting to empty the fridge yesterday, I conceived an anything-but-the-kitchen-sink Swiss roll. It's a scratchy list of things that tried to make their debut on there: salted caramel, butterscotch sauce, lingonberry jam and gianduja spread - bits and bobs from deliveries past. Whatever it is, the red carpet of spreads turned out glorious. Hip hip hooray!

Easy-peasy Swiss roll
Requires one 13 X 9 inch pan

70g plain flour
13g cornstarch
1/4 TSP baking powder
3 large eggs (I used the awesome #CheonggyewonEgg ones) - seperated
80g caster sugar
2.5 tablespoon vegetable oil
2 tablespoon milk

Filling - raid your fridge

Preheat your oven to 180Â°C. Line a rectangle pan 9 X 13 inch with baking paper. Let the sides stick out.

Sift the flour, cornstarch and baking powder into a bowl.

In your mixing bowl, whisk yolks, oil and milk with 40g caster sugar till light and fluffy. It will take about 6 minutes on the highest speed to achieve pale yellow state.

Fold in the flour mixture gently till there are no visible lumps.

Using a clean bowl, whisk the whites and 40g of sugar till stiff peaks.

Fold in the whites into the yolk mixture in 3 parts. Gently please. It is okay to see streaks of whites at this point. Continue till you get a homogeneous mix. Light and airy

Spread it out on your lined baking pan, making sure it's as even as you possible master (we're not perfect). Give it a light tap on a flat surface to expel the large bubbles. Place the tray on a larger tray with a cup of water poured in and bake that for 15 minutes.

Remove the cake from the oven once 15 minutes is over. Pry at the overhangs and flip out on to a new baking paper almost immediately. Slice off the edges. Spread whatever you want on the underside and proceed to roll up tightly with the aid of the baking paper. Allow to cool in its wrapped state for 15 minutes before slicing and eating.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Seven o'clock this morning with blurry eyes, I toasted slices of altamura bread splashed with extra virgin olive oil on a warm griddle pan. My gentle suggestion of eggs on toast met with luke warm responses at first, but by seven-thirty, all that greet me are yolk stained skid marks on white ceramic plates. I chased this with a bonus toast enlivened with nutella. Who says you can't have dessert at breakfast too?

Bread has always been my carb ride or die and I'm blessed throughout this circuit breaker to traverse the doughy realms from ultra soft milk buns (@sulyntan) to chewy bagels (@breadyard) . @Braci.sg's traditional Altamura bread is a Italian classic from the Puglia region with a PDO status (products with protected designation of origin) - a humble 4 ingredient bread; It is highly intolerant of poor handling. The dark crusted beauty that emerged from Braci's oven is a notch above the rest, though I admit my inexperience may have swayed my opinion. Nutty from the chew and just porous enough to smuggle oil and other delicious sauces.

Top tips: if you've got loaves you can't quite finish fast enough. Slice them immediately and freeze. Their shelf lives improve dramatically, at least 3 months, me thinks or till your carb monsters claim their last victim.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #SGUnited #savefnbsg #bracisg #BraciACasa #altamurabread #SihanSayDaBaoWhat

caption:
When it comes to my father's favourite afternoon snackages, it's easy to zero in on the big three: bubur cha cha, ondeh ondeh and Kueh salat. Notice the similarities? ğŸŒ´ // So this afternoon, away from prying eyes, I set my sights on making these elusive treats (which I now know better to purchase instead). The aftermath was all but empty plates and little grunts of gluttony that ensued. Worth it getting green dough underneath your finger nails? Yes. You might want to solicit some help though.

Kueh Ondeh Ondeh
Makes about 25 - 30

250g glutinous rice flour
1 tbsp brown sugar
250ml water blended with 5 pieces of pandan leaf chopped up
1 tbsp oil

100 gula melaka

150g grated coconut
Pinch of salt

Go ahead and steam your grated coconut combined with the salt for about 10 minutes. Remove and let cool.

Meantime make your dough by blending water together with the pandan leaves and putting that through a fine sieve. Making sure to press out all the pandan juice. Heat that in a pot till almost simmering.

Combine your glutinous rice flour and brown sugar. Making a well in the middle. Pour in the warm pandan juice and work it using chopsticks to form a paste. As larger crumbs start to form, pour in the oil and continue to work it till it's cool enough to maneuver with your fingers. Knead the dough till smooth and less sticky to the touch. Rest the dough underneath a damp towel.

Go ahead and chop your gula melaka into  tiny chunks. Set aside and please resist the urge to snack.

Measure out 13 - 15g pieces of dough. Roll into a ball and using your thumb, press out an indentation in the center which you'll then fill with gula melaka. Pinch the seams to seal the sugar in and roll out again into a  smooth ball.

By this time, you should have a pot of water on a rolling boil ready. Plop your balls into the water and leave them in there till they start to float (6 - 7 mins) and using a sieve, rescue them and roll them around in the bowl of steamed coconut you had set aside just now.

Watch this babies disappear like lightning. //Swipe â¡ï¸ for the video! ~~~
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #BudgetTenDollars #ondehondeh

caption:
A burger a day keeps the doctor away. ğŸ” I think. // And this time, feeling bougie, I decided to up the ante on the already delicious Pulled Pork from @sousvidelicious and house them in burger buns (recipe in the previous post) slathered with garlic aioli with a simple coleslaw.

I may not have achieved my 100% #homemade ambitions here but why try so hard when you can weigh in on the experts (@sousvidelicious ğŸ˜‰). Quote [SIHANCOOKS] to enjoy 15% off your order.
~~~
Coleslaw
Makes enough for 3 burgers

1/3 head of cabbage, finely shredded
1 carrot shredded
2 TSP apple cider vinegar or red wine vinegar
Ground black pepper
1 huge TSP of Dijon mustard
2 tablespoon mayonnaise
Sea salt to taste
Swig of olive oil

Shred up your veggies. Feel free to mix red cabbage and white. Combine it with the the apple cider vinegar, black pepper, olive oil and Dijon mustard. Use your hands to really incorporate it in. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Also add your mayonnaise and toss to combine.

I like to prepare my coleslaw an hour prior to assembling the burgers, leaving it in the fridge till ready to use. That way the flavours really get to know each other.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #burgersaremynemesis #weaccidentallyaburger #StayHomeWithAscott

It's a sizable round of soft cake garnished with crispy filo and cocoa nib lace that disappears outrageously quickly.

Order via www.braci.sg/casa. I would steer you towards the DIY options for more hands-on, fun, sexy times in the kitchen prior to a stellar meal. Scampi tagliolini, yes please.

caption:
Bok! Bok! Bitches! Satisfying my fried chicken cravings this afternoon with what  seems like a party platter for 2 of {Salted Egg Chicken}, all to myself. It's one of those things that I've caught on @timtimtokyo 's insanely delicious story feed that has been bugging me for ages. Well, I think those salted duck eggs have served their time on my kitchen counter. Today is the day.

Salted Egg Chicken
Makes enough for 2

400g of chicken thigh, boneless, cut into chunks
2 salted duck eggs
1 cup rice flour
2 tablespoon flour
1 Tablespoon rice wine
Salt & pepper
2 tablespoon cornstarch
2 egg yolks

2 tablespoon butter
Handful of curry leaves
80ml evaporated milk, more if you like it saucy
2 cloves garlic, finely minced
2 chili padi, chopped

Steam or boil your salted duck eggs. Boiling should require around 15 minutes. After which seperate the yolks from the whites. Place in a bowl and mash till you get really tiny crumbs.

Marinade your chopped chicken with the rice wine, salt and black pepper and cornstarch. Leave in the fridge for at least  30 minutes. Meanwhile heat up your oil, break two yolks over the chicken and massage it in. Pour the flour mixture over and season with some more salt and black pepper. Really push the dry ingredients into the nooks of the bird. Deep-fry for about 10 minutes till crispy brown. Set aside in a basket to keep it crisp.

Now, in a wok, melt the 2 tablespoons of butter. On medium-high heat, fry the garlic, chili and curry leaves till fragrant. Add in your mashed up salted egg. Things will start to get foamy really fast, that's normal. Lower your heat to a medium-low. Once the yolks has started to cook, add in the evaporated milk and keep stirring to form a smooth sauce. You can add more evaporated milk if you desire more sauce. No one is judging. Toss your fried chicken through the sauce and you're ready.

Oh don't forget the fried egg as well.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Okay, let's talk buns. These pillowy ones start off with tangzhong starter, or a water roux starter. It's the byword nowadays for bread bakers aspiring towards elevated bread rolls and tender cinnamon buns. // Here's how a little bit of cooked starch makes a difference: By pre-cooking a % of the flour and liquid together, it pre-gelatinizes the starches in the flour meaning that the dough can absorb more water. With more water absorbed, the overall dough is less sticky and hence easier to work with. You could work more liquids into the dough - high hydration therefore equating to moister rolls that will stay fresh for longer.

Without further ado,

Perfect Burger Buns
Makes 8
Recipe from @domestic_gothess

Tangzhong:
20g bread flour
100ml water

Dough:
350g bread flour
7g dry yeast
1 TSP salt
50g caster sugar
1 tbsp milk powder (optional)
125ml milk
1 large egg
50g softened butter

Make the tangzhong first. In a small saucepan, combine the two ingredients and whisk over a medium flame till you get a paste consistency. Set aside to cool.

Place the flour, yeast, salt, sugar and milk powder in a mixing bowl. Whisk together. Fit your stand mixer with a dough hook and make a well in the center of your dry ingredients, add in the egg, milk and tangzhong. Mix until a dough is form. Making sure to scrap the bowl every now and then. Bit by bit, incorporate the softened butter bits. Keep mixing for at least 15 minutes. Scraping down constantly. You'll achieve a tender dough that peels away from the sides.

Transfer the dough to a lightly greased bowl and cling-film the top. Leave to rise until double in size. It will take about 1 hour in S'pore's weather.

Divide the dough into 8 pieces, ~ 90g/piece. Shape each dough to get a smooth ball. Spread them out across your lined baking tray. Leave to rise in a draft-free place for 1 hour. I recommend putting it in the oven and accompanying with a bowl of freshly boiled water for some steamy boosters.

Preheat the oven to 200Â°C (do make sure to remove your buns first). Egg wash them with beaten egg and milk before sprinkling on some sesame seeds.

Bake for 20 minutes.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat Tang Shui edition // this #circuitbreaker, I admit to being somewhat of a Nazi when it comes to feeding my parents. No bread at home? I'm kneading a batch. Missing out on your laksa action? Nvm, I'm cooking it at home.

But there are several things that do not fall within my knowledge bracket and it's usually the more classic items that I do not have a penchant for in daily life... Till I had @TheChinesePotion 's No. 3 - a jovial mix of papaya, candied winter melon and White lotus seeds. It's pleasantly sweet, with the papaya possessing just the right amount of bite to compliment the knobs of White lotus seeds and goji Berry. I'm not one to understand the ins and outs of balancing one's Qi through your diet but one thing's for sure, you'll instantly feel rejuvenated after a bowlful of this. Definitely a much healthier option than reaching out for a handful of cookies.

Order now to enjoy $2 off their delivery fees.

caption:
Melty Cheese draped over drippy creamy eggs this morning on sriracha mayo loaded dream rolls from yesterday's baking experiment. B L I S S. A copy-cat of the iconic Fairfax #EggSlut sandwich except I forgot to layer on the caramelised onions which I had painstakingly gotten out of bed 30 minutes early to toil and tear over. Damm.

You can find the recipe on @timeoutlondon but I'm going to talk more about those eggs which begin in a cold pan.

First crack three eggs straight into a cold pan and throw in a big knob of butter. Don't stinge. Stir the eggs and butter together even before turning on the pilot light. "Almost till it forms like a sauce," says Alvin Cailan. Put the pan on medium heat and continue stirring with your spatula to create a velvety texture. Be sure to constantly scrape the bottoms of the pan and fold your eggs over to create loose layers. When the eggs start to bind, remove from the heat. These babies are ready. Sprinkle your chives over and spoon lovingly over your warmed buns. Yes, you know what I'm talking about...
~~~
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #weaccidentallyaburger #eggporn

caption:
Disquieted by the unrest and chaos in other parts of the world, I take to baking to quell the anxiety.

Banana, date, pecan muffins it is and Carole Walter's recipe is a God-sent. If you've never tried this combination before, you are in for a treat.

Banana, date, pecan muffins
Makes 14

2 ripe bananas
1 3/4 cups flour
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1 TSP baking powder
1 TSP ground cardamom
1/2 TSP cinnamon
1/2 TSP salt
1/2 TSP baking soda

1/2 cup dates, pitted and chopped into bits
1/2 cup pecans, coarsely chopped
110g butter, melted and cooled to room temperature
1/2 cup dark brown sugar
1/2 cup plain yogurt
2 large eggs, beaten
1 TSP vanilla extract

Heat your oven to 190Â°C. Slice the bananas and proceed to mash them up to a pulp.

In a large bowl, whisk together all the dry ingredients. Chop your pecans and dates. Toss them through the dry ingredients and taking the time to seperate the pieces of dates with your fingertips.

In another bowl, whisk the butter and brown sugar together. Stir in the bananas, yogurt, eggs and vanilla.

Stir the banana-egg mixture into the dry ingredients. Making sure not to overmix. A few streaks of flour is fine. Using an ice cream scoop, ladle about 1/4 cup batter into each muffin tin.

Bake for 25 minutes.

Tip: if you don't have yogurt, just squeeze a quarter of a lemon into 1/2 cup of milk and leave to sit on the counter for half an hour.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #BudgetTenDollars #quarantinekitchen #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
Old school Coffeeshop feels visited this morning with kopitiam eggs and kaya toast. â˜•ğŸ¥š. Splurged on these #CheonggyewonEgg (CGWE) eggs from Korean, because, why not enjoy life's better pleasures in their gold standard form when cooped up at home?

Reaping the benefits of #coldchainsystem, these eggs are incredibly fresh - hence, best demonstrated in kopitiam eggs. Who agrees?

I miss 'Killiney Kopitiam' Eggs
Makes a selfish portion of 2

2 eggs at room temp
500ml water
Soy sauce
White pepper

Bring 500ml of water to boil in a pot with a tight fitting lid. Once on a rolling boil, kill the heat and immediately add in a splash of water, 30ml, if you've a stickler for measurements.

Quickly lower the eggs in, gently, with a spoon. Then put the lid on and set the timer for 7 minutes. Remove the eggs from the water once the timer is up and place it in room temp water to stop the cooking.

Crack the eggs into saucers and slurp it up. Alternatively Kaya toast make the perfect dippers. ~~~
These CheonggyewonEgg, supported by Korea Agro-Fisheries & Food Trade Corp have just arrived on our shores and can be now purchased from Cold Storage! You'll have to look into the chiller section to find your loot. A tad more expensive than your usual eggs but well worth it if you're intending to work on those ramen eggs or onsen tamago. // To celebrate the launch, @brandfitsg is giving 100 lucky individuals 3 cartons of eggs each for FREE. Head on over their IG and comment on their most recent post for a chance to win.

#cheonggyewonegg #sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #koreaneggs #CGWE #sp
