caption:
With the current circumstances, you might not be able to go cafÃ©-hopping just yet, but you can bring @littlefarms into your home.
.
From breakfast goodies to sharing sets perfect for the whole household, thereâ€™s something for everyone here. I really enjoyed the Chicken & Avocado Sourdough (S$14), a hefty sandwich packed with flavour.
.
Sandwiched between two thick slices of fluffy, chewy sourdough, the cheese, tomato and chicken came together beautifully on the palate. Think: savoury, piquant notes, complete with the creamy mouthfeel of melted cheese.
.
A drizzle of honey mustard completed it, adding a zing to this really filling sandwich. Iâ€™m not kidding when I say I couldâ€™ve split this into breakfast and lunch!
.
Little Farms CafÃ© also serves up other breakfast dishes like the Ham & Cheese Croissant, Spinach, Mushroom & Goat Feta Quiche. If youâ€™re ordering for the family, sharing sets like Rotisserie Cajun Chicken Family Set â€“ it comes with a whole roasted chicken!
.
Little Farms CafÃ© offers island-wide delivery of cafÃ©-quality dishes, all made with the highest quality produce. With a minimum order of S$30 and free delivery for orders over S$100, you can indulge in a lovely meal with your family. #sp ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
If you are missing your favourite Sunday brunch meals, well don't fret - @threesacrowdcafe might help tide you over till the Circuit Breaker ends. With nostalgic and familiar flavours, your sweet tooth will certainly be satisfied.
.
One of the waffles to look forward to would certainly have to be the Horlick Waffles (S$9) that's covered with a shower of almond crunch and a dusting of malty Horlicks powder. Crisp on the outside and pillowy in the centre, these waffles looked as good as they taste!
.
No waffles are complete without scoops of ice cream, and Three's A Crowd is known for its unique and special flavours. Their Legacy (S$4.50) is a dark chocolate ice cream that's also a tribute to the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew.
.
Three's A Crowd offers pick-up and delivery, so remember to #tapauplease if you would like a little reminder of Sunday brunch! ~ @bunny2302

caption:
Much as I enjoy tinkering about the kitchen, some days Iâ€™d love to take a break from cooking and just dig into a feast. And with @alpinespringcatering, I get to do just that.
.
Can you believe that for just S$68, you can enjoy this sumptuous spread from the Zi Char menu for 5 pax? I have to admit, my family ended up saving the leftovers for dinner too â€“ there was just so much delicious food!
.
The Zi Char menu features staples like Braised Ee Fu Noodles with Baby Abalone and Wok Fried White Pepper Clams, and more unconventional dishes like Signature Salted Egg Yolk Beancurd.
.
But my favourite has got to be our local signature dish, the Chilli Crab (add-on S$15). Drenched in a thick, rich chilli crab sauce that has egg strands in it, this was a massive crab. The crab claws are cracked beforehand, so itâ€™s simply a matter of scooping out the sweet, juicy crabmeat. Truly, the star of the show.
.
If youâ€™re feeling hungry, drop a WhatsApp message to +65 9828 3280 for same-day delivery within 3 hours. Yes, itâ€™s that simple. Order away, and dig in! #sp ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
Located at Suntec City, @supersubsingapore first opened its doors to the public in September 2019. The subs came in cardboard boxes which reminded me of those you might spot at a food festival. Each sub came with a side of plain nachos, in case you want to dip into the bountiful toppings sitting atop your sub.
.
Super Sub had a plethora of gourmet options, and I decided to try some of their more famous toppings. Super Subâ€™s Fiery Chic Bolognese (S$7.80) is one of their best-sellers, and for good reason. Topped with lettuce, cherry tomatoes, jalapeno, mayonnaise and cheddar cheese, this tomato-based sub may look rather unassuming at first glance as compared to the others.
.
However, this turned out to be my favourite. The slightly spicy meat sauce was absolutely delicious and it went extremely well with the chicken hotdog. Have you tried hotdog subs in Singapore? ~ @stercei

Add a dollop of cream, and a generous serving of jam â€“ youâ€™ve got bakes for a lovely afternoon tea. Donâ€™t forget to brew a pot of piping hot tea to complete the picture. Fluffy and chewy with a crisp top, these scones were lovely indeed.

caption:

caption:
Anybody craving some Taiwanese food and a refreshing cup of bubble tea? You can now indulge in the best of both worlds with @emosnackssg. Located at Geylang Road, this eatery boasts a myriad of authentic Taiwanese dishes.
.
If you love heat and you're not afraid to chow down on some dangerously spicy food, dive right into their Mala Chicken (S$4.50). Trust me, you'll be hooked on this tasty and feisty dish. Simple, yet incredibly comforting, relive your memories in Taiwan with their delectable dishes.
.
Be sure to #tapauplease as they are currently offering a 20% discount for self pick-up orders and free islandwide delivery for a minimum purchase of S$55! ~@jermtard

caption:
â€˜Circuit Breakerâ€™ got you feeling down? Turn that frown upside down with yummy fuss-free meals, courtesy of @onandondiners.
.
If youâ€™re too busy to cook or youâ€™d like to treat your family to a scrumptious spread, On & On Diners is here for you with 7 dishes for S$68. Packed with a bounty of fresh seafood such as plump clams, succulent prawns and a huge crab with savoury roe, this is the dish for seafood lovers. I particularly enjoyed the rich, flavourful soup, which went really well with the springy beehoon.
.

[Oddle Eats] - Founders of F&B e-commerce platform Oddle have launched @oddleeats - a new personalised food directory featuring over 500 of Oddleâ€™s restaurant partners. Diners can now browse the online platform for a diverse range of food choices from local Singaporean dishes to western cuisine, and click through to land on the restaurantâ€™s page to order directly from them for island-wide delivery, without middlemen or hidden costs. We had the Salted egg yolk custard bun, Mee Suah Kueh and Baked BBQ Pork pastry from Swee Choon, as well as the Original White Bee Hoon from the White Restaurant.

Since 2014, Oddle has brought online ordering systems to thousands of restaurants around the region â€“ onboarding more than 500 new restaurants and F&B groups in Singapore in April 2020 alone. Born of the three co-founders' love for the industry, Oddle makes it easier for restaurants to manage and grow their business through its affordable e-commerce service.

caption:
[Ippudo] - @ippudosg recently launched their new IPPUDOâ€™s DIY Ramen Meal Kits, frozen Japanese gyozas and pork belly chashu! You can whip up your very own Hakata-style ramen in under 20 mins and enjoy it anytime with their convenient Shiromaru Motoaji Ramen Kit ($15.30/pack) and Akamaru Shinaji Ramen Kit ($16.35/pack). Each individually packed ramen kit comes with thin, silky strands of ramen noodles, creamy tonkatsu soup base that has been simmered for 18 hours to achieve its well-loved umami goodness, pork belly chasu slices, and marinated black fungus that can be whipped out in just 17 minutes. The Akamaru DIY Ramen Kit comes with additional IPPUDO's specialty miso paste and fragrant garlic oil to create a moreish bowl with greater depth. 
IPPUDO's  Home Cooking DIY Ramen Meal Kit, and frozen items are available from 13 June 2020, and can be purchased online at www.ippudo.oddle.me or in stores at various IPPUDO Singapore outlets (excluding Marina Bay Sands outlet).

caption:
[Route 65] - For the first time ever, @route65sg is releasing a time limited Bak Chang Burger from 15-30 June in conjunction with Dragon Boat's festival! Bring your Bak Chang up a notch this season with their Pork Bak Chang Rice Burger and the Shoyu Beef Bak Chang Rice Burger, featuring soft and sticky glutinous rice sandwiching flavourful savoury fillings in between. Route 65 Chef Anthonyâ€™s mother has been making bak chang and gifting them to her family, neighbours, and friends for over 20 years and even more so during this pandemic. As the nation overcomes the crisis as a collective, Chef Anthony was looking for innovative ways to help tide through Route 65 business, and his motherâ€™s continuous spirit of giving bak chang has inspired him to deconstruct her traditional version into recreating his own contemporary bak chang.
.

Upgrade to a Bak Chang burger set which comes with Black Lemon Tea with Lychee Boba with a top up of $9.90. You can also enjoy 2 free traditional Bak Chang specially handmade by the Chef's mum for orders above $50. Islandwide delivery is available with free delivery for orders above $50, and $5 delivery fee for orders above $30. You may place your order at order.route65sg.com

caption:
[Paradise Dynasty] - @paradisegrpsg has just launched the Fun DIY Xiao Long Bao Kit, so you can savour the Paradise Dynasty's famed steamed dumplings right in the comfort of your home. The convenient kit comes with a bamboo steamer basket, bamboo steamer liner, disposable gloves, pork filling (original flavour) and 2 sets of eight pastry skin made with natural colouring. It's the perfect stay home fun activity to bond with your family, as you can now recreate their signature xiao long bao in just 7 steps! We also had the Prawn & Pork Dumpling in Hot Chilli Vinaigrette, which came in a frozen pack, but is also extremely convenient to prepare by just cooking for 6-7 minutes in boiling water before pouring the hot chilli vinaigrette sauce over the cooked dumplings. You can enjoy free Prawn and Pork Dumpling in Hot Chilli Vinaigrette with orders above $70.
.

caption:
[Ippudo] - @ippudosg recently launched their new IPPUDOâ€™s DIY Ramen Meal Kits, frozen Japanese gyozas and pork belly chashu! You can whip up your very own Hakata-style ramen in under 20 mins and enjoy it anytime with their convenient Shiromaru Motoaji Ramen Kit ($15.30/pack) and Akamaru Shinaji Ramen Kit ($16.35/pack). Each individually packed ramen kit comes with thin, silky strands of ramen noodles, creamy tonkatsu soup base that has been simmered for 18 hours to achieve its well-loved umami goodness, pork belly chasu slices, and marinated black fungus that can be whipped out in just 17 minutes. The Akamaru DIY Ramen Kit comes with additional IPPUDO's specialty miso paste and fragrant garlic oil to create a moreish bowl with greater depth. 
IPPUDO's  Home Cooking DIY Ramen Meal Kit, and frozen items are available from 13 June 2020, and can be purchased online at www.ippudo.oddle.me or in stores at various IPPUDO Singapore outlets (excluding Marina Bay Sands outlet).

caption:
[Route 65] - For the first time ever, @route65sg is releasing a time limited Bak Chang Burger from 15-30 June in conjunction with Dragon Boat's festival! Bring your Bak Chang up a notch this season with their Pork Bak Chang Rice Burger and the Shoyu Beef Bak Chang Rice Burger, featuring soft and sticky glutinous rice sandwiching flavourful savoury fillings in between. Route 65 Chef Anthonyâ€™s mother has been making bak chang and gifting them to her family, neighbours, and friends for over 20 years and even more so during this pandemic. As the nation overcomes the crisis as a collective, Chef Anthony was looking for innovative ways to help tide through Route 65 business, and his motherâ€™s continuous spirit of giving bak chang has inspired him to deconstruct her traditional version into recreating his own contemporary bak chang.
.

Upgrade to a Bak Chang burger set which comes with Black Lemon Tea with Lychee Boba with a top up of $9.90. You can also enjoy 2 free traditional Bak Chang specially handmade by the Chef's mum for orders above $50. Islandwide delivery is available with free delivery for orders above $50, and $5 delivery fee for orders above $30. You may place your order at order.route65sg.com

caption:
[Paradise Dynasty] - @paradisegrpsg has just launched the Fun DIY Xiao Long Bao Kit, so you can savour the Paradise Dynasty's famed steamed dumplings right in the comfort of your home. The convenient kit comes with a bamboo steamer basket, bamboo steamer liner, disposable gloves, pork filling (original flavour) and 2 sets of eight pastry skin made with natural colouring. It's the perfect stay home fun activity to bond with your family, as you can now recreate their signature xiao long bao in just 7 steps! We also had the Prawn & Pork Dumpling in Hot Chilli Vinaigrette, which came in a frozen pack, but is also extremely convenient to prepare by just cooking for 6-7 minutes in boiling water before pouring the hot chilli vinaigrette sauce over the cooked dumplings. You can enjoy free Prawn and Pork Dumpling in Hot Chilli Vinaigrette with orders above $70.
.

You can place your order at: https://paradisedynasty.oddle.me/en_SG/ Enjoy 15% off self-pick up orders made via online orders. Free island-wide delivery is available with orders above $100, and $5 island-wide delivery fees with orders above $50.

caption: Fall-off-the-bone 4-Ingredient USDA St.Louis ribs from @meatcosg. Simply generously rub the rack of ribs with salt, Worcestershire sauce,  curry ketchup (you can use normal ketchup) & mesquite spice blend from @helaspicesingapore.  Wrap in foil and bake for 2 hours at 160C. Then unwrap, brush a layer of desired sauce (I used curry ketchup) then bake for another 1 hour uncovered. The ribs should be sticky, tender, juicy and falling off the bones. Use SHEEATSSHECOOKS10 for a discount @meatcosg

caption:
[ğŸš‡ #StormscapeStayHome]
MONDAY PURPLE?!
Turning all Monday Blues into purple because Monday is over! Adding more ice to my butterfly pea today because of the hot weather! .
Steps
1ï¸âƒ£ Prepare Butterfly pea by adding 8 petals to 100ml of hot water and seep for 5 mins
2ï¸âƒ£ Pour the butterfly pea into the ice cube tray and leave it overnight
Fill an entire glass with butterfly pea ice cubes
4ï¸âƒ£ Fill up 90% of the glass with butterfly pea drink in the same ratio in 1ï¸âƒ£

MATCHA ESPRESSO ICE CUBES?!
The weather is getting really hot lately and since adding ice to coffee usually dilutes it, I decided to freeze the espresso shots to preserve the flavour and intensity with some matcha!
.
Steps
1ï¸âƒ£ Prepare Espresso Shot (40ml) from the Nespresso machine and freeze it overnight. This is so convenient and saves time to make coffee every morning
2ï¸âƒ£ Each Nespresso Ice Cube Tray is 30ml so 9 of them requires 270ml of espresso shot
3ï¸âƒ£ Add your desired number of espresso ice cubes prepared in 1ï¸âƒ£ into empty glass
4ï¸âƒ£ Fill up the glass with whisked matcha (1g matcha powder to 100 ml hot water)
5ï¸âƒ£ Iâ€™m using Ceremonial grade Matcha which interestingly turned out sweet when milk is added
6ï¸âƒ£ Fill up the glass with 150ml of Fresh Milk
.

[ğŸš‡ #StormscapeStayHome]
HARD FOAM LATTE?!
Celebrating World Environment Day (5 June) tomorrow with Nespresso (@Nespresso.SG) who has partnered with National Geographic (@NatGeo) this year in their support for farmers in places such as Uganda, Colombia and Zimbabwe to sustainably source coffee and make a difference which also helps to revive the war-torn regions
.
This Hard Foam Latte is no different from other lattes, but this simple cup of coffee can help to make a positive difference:
1ï¸âƒ£ Prepare 1-2 shots of Espresso from the Nespresso machine to yield 40ml of Espresso (Iâ€™m using double shots 80ml)
2ï¸âƒ£ Using Nespresso Aeroccino, pour 100ml of Fresh Milk and give it a short press to create Hot Milk Foam (Long press for 2s for Cold Milk Foam)
3ï¸âƒ£ Scoop the Hot Milk Foam onto the espresso shot prepared in 1ï¸âƒ£
4ï¸âƒ£ Let the Milk Foam settle for 3 minutes exactly
5ï¸âƒ£ Pour 100ml of Fresh Milk at one spot in the middle of the cup so that the hardened milk foam will rise evenly
6ï¸âƒ£ Sprinkle some cinnamon powder or cocoa powder for extra indulgence
.
ğŸ“ Nespresso X National Geographic

caption:

3 INGREDIENTS STRAWBERRY SANDWICH?!
Missed travelling to Japan so much that I decided to create a simple Japanese snack! Reminiscing the Fruit Sando I had in Japan, think:
.
3 ingredients:
1ï¸âƒ£ 100ml Whipping Cream
2ï¸âƒ£ 15g Castor Sugar
3ï¸âƒ£ 100g Mascarpone cheese
.
Steps
1ï¸âƒ£ Pour 100ml of whipping cream into a clean bowl on top of ice water to keep it cool
2ï¸âƒ£ Add 15g of castor sugar to the whipping cream (this is about 60% sweetness in terms of BBT standard)
3ï¸âƒ£ Whipped it until it starts to peak
4ï¸âƒ£ Add in 100g of Mascarpone cheese
5ï¸âƒ£ Continue whipping for another 6-7mins to form a cream texture
6ï¸âƒ£ Put a clean wrap on table top before putting your bread on it
7ï¸âƒ£ Visualise how your cross section will look like and arrange your fruits
8ï¸âƒ£ â€œBuahâ€ the cream prepared in 5ï¸âƒ£ onto your fruits generously and â€œKiapâ€ it with another slice of bread
9ï¸âƒ£ Cling wrap it and put into your chiller for 30mins before slicing
.

caption:
Hereâ€™s something we did before but itâ€™s so easy to do - Honey Glazed Garlic Chicken Wings. The recipe as follows.

Pat dry chic wings before you begin. Dust them liberally in a coating of plain flour, salt and pepper and set aside.

Make the glaze with two teaspoons is light soy sauce, two teaspoons of cheapo honey, three teaspoons of plain water, one chopped cloves of garlic. For added spiciness, you can choose to add chilli or Szechuan pepper or both if you choose to turn the heat levels up.

Pan fry the coated wings in a pan of oil for roughly 5 minutes. Once they are properly browned, transfer to an oven tray lined with baking paper and roast the wings for about 15 minutes at 180 deg Celsius. Take them out to glaze the the wings on both sides with the soy honey glaze, and return to the oven for another 10 minutes.

Serve with sides of your choice. Here, we have them sitting a bed of homemade mashed potatoes and boiled spinach, and cherry tomatoes. For this plate you see here, the cost of ingredients is less than $10 to feed easily two :)))))
comments: ['Delicious', 'Delicious ğŸ‘']

caption:
Sualor Risotto.

Start with 8 or 10 sualor prawns from @lyhseafood for 2 persons. Deshell and devein the shrimp and separate them. Fry the shells and heads in a pot with butter until they turn pink. Add a pot worth of water to make a stock and simmer for 20 minutes. 

In a pan of oil, lightly sauteÌ the prawns on each side for a minute or 2. Remove the prawns and in the same pan, add a knob of butter and enough Arborio risotto rice for 2.

Toast for a few minutes before adding a dash of white wine. Burn off the wine for a few minutes before adding 3 ladles of prawn stock at medium heat and stir. Once the broth has been absorbed by the rice, add another ladle and stir again. Season with 1 tsp salt.

Keep repeating until the rice puffs up and is not too hard nor too mushy, about 20 minutes or so. Around 15 minutes, add some green peas. Once the rice is fully cooked, turn off the flame and add in a 2 thick slabs of butter, grated parmesan or parmigiana.

Stir well to emulsify the butter and toss to get it super creamy and delicious like seen in the video. To serve, spoon risotto into the center of a plate and shake the plate to let the rice naturally spread out to form a circular disc shape.

Add the sualor prawns on top and enjoy! It should be creamy and lava like, and when you get this right, itâ€™s super comforting :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
comments: ['YUMMM. Miss your risotto!', 'wowğŸ˜ğŸ˜‹amazing', 'Looks awesome! I love a good risotto', 'Super creamy!!! Soo goodğŸ¤¤ğŸ¤¤ğŸ¤¤']

caption:
Sweet Potato Buns, one of the easiest bread to do.

Steam 100g of sweet potato for 20 minutes. After which, mash them with a fork. Add the mashed potatoes into a bread maker, followed by 250g bread flour, 30g brown sugar or caster sugar, 120ml milk, 25g butter, half tsp salt and 1 tsp instant yeast.

Set your bread maker to bread dough mode and let the machine do its magic. When it is done, pour the dough onto a flour dusted table. Cut the dough into 9 equal portions. 

Roll each dough onto a ball shape and arrange all 9 dough balls neatly into a baking tray in a 3 by 3 formation. Rest the dough for 30 minutes. Make a solution of 2 tbsp milk and 1 tbsp maple syrup, and stir well. 

Apply the solution on top of each dough ball and sprinkle some black sesame seeds on top as well. Bake the bread in a pre heated oven of 170 Celsius no fan mode for 15 minutes.

And thatâ€™s it! So easy and fast. And perfect as breakfast rolls or simply as a snack :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Soup night is a simple and tasty chicken bean soup that has been slow cooked for at least 8 hours.

Two deskinned chicken thighs, one chopped carrot, 2 strips of chopped bacon, some French beans together with some mixed beans and 5 tbsp of tomato pureÌe in a slow cooker slowly but surely brewing away.

Remember to skim off the excess fat before consuming. Not only delicious, but highly nutritious :)))))

Amazingly Simple Mushroom Bacon Rice Cooker.

So simple even a baby can do this. Ok, maybe not a baby, but even the most non cook will be able to pull it off.

In a rice cooker with one cup of washed and rinsed rice, add chopped mushrooms. You can choose whatever mushrooms and do not worry about the quantity, the mushrooms will shrink during cooking so add as much as you like.

Add 2 slices of chopped bacon for some meaty influence, and green peas for colour and crunch. Add one cup of water seasoned with a tsp of light soya for flavour.

Put everything in the rice cooker and let it cook on normal mode until itâ€™s done. When itâ€™s cooked, open and season with fresh black pepper and serve.

Enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
So easy to make Cheese Twists using @borgcraft puff pastry packets.

We have some leftover puff pastry from making our pot pie, so never being one to waste food, we put it to good use.

With the balance puff pastry sheet, apply some egg wash on one side. Then sprinkle some grated cheddar cheese before folding in half. Then cut it into thin lengthy strips.

Twist each strip until you form a cheese twist shape. Then place them on a baking tray lined with baking paper. Sprinkle more cheddar before baking them in oven at 200 Celsius no fan for 18 to 20 mins.

This is great as a snack or like what we did today, a breakfast paired with a dip and some fruits and yogurt :)))))

caption:
Whatâ€™s good with white rice, Kung Pao Chicken of course. Hereâ€™s how to do it again.

Marinate about 250g chopped to chunks chicken with 1 tbsp corn flour, 1 tbsp light soya and 1 tbsp Chinese wine. Mix and coat everything evenly.

Make a sauce by mixing 1 tbsp sugar, 1 tbsp corn flour, 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark vinegar and 3 tbsp water in a bowl and set aside.

Heat up a wok with oil at medium flame. Once the oil is hot, fry a handful of chopped dried chilli and a handful of Szechuan peppercorns until they are fragrant.

Add the marinated chicken and stir well. Once the chicken is cooked in a few minutes, add 2 stalks of chopped scallion, 4 cloves of garlic that have been peeled and cut into halves and 6 slices of ginger. Toss and stir well again, it should smell incredibly aromatic by now.

Next add the sauce which will give the chicken a shiny gloss like the livery on an F1 car. Keep tossing. The last part is to simply add baked or cooked cashew nuts for a lovely crunch.

To serve, you can pour it on a sharing plate or do what we did here, that is to spoon the chicken onto a bowl of piping hot white rice. So so good that we really hope you give this a try :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Simple Ee Fu Noodles.

Blanche ee fu noodles in a pot of boiling water for 2 minutes, then strain. In a wok of oil, sauteÌ 1 chopped garlic and half of a chopped leek until fragrant.

Add one sliced portobello or 2 or 3 button mushrooms. Add 100g of chopped chunks of pork, we using a leftover shoulder here. Stir well.

Season with 1 tbsp light soya and 1 tbsp dark soya and some white pepper. Add some of the noodle water followed by the ee fu noodles. Let the noodles braise for a few minutes.

Once the liquid is mostly absorbed into the noodles, turn off the flame and drizzle a dash of oil and season with black pepper and give it one last toss. And itâ€™s done.

Serve onto a plate and enjoy this classic wedding banquet dish :)))))

caption:
Easiest Baked Rice.

Seriously, one of the simplest recipes around. Start by placing one cup of washed and rinsed uncooked rice in a baking dish. Spread evenly around the dish.

Add one sliced onions and cover evenly. Then add 3 chopped garlic on top. Add some freshly chopped parsley before adding 3 portobello mushrooms, thinly sliced. You can use any fresh mushrooms too.

Pour in one cup of chicken or meat or vegetable stock seasoned with one tsp of salt. Then cover thoroughly with both mozzarella and parmesan or parmigiana cheese. Sprinkle a dash of black pepper.

Bake in a pre heated oven at 190 Celsius no fan for 45 minutes. After about half an hour, if the top is already golden brown, cover with an aluminium foil to cook the balance of remaining time to prevent burning the cheese crust.

After 45 minutes, the rice should have puffed up and fully cooked. Remove and simply enjoy the simplest of baked rice :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
We made the silky smooth Velvet Congee again today, but had it with century egg and pork balls, similar to those at the â€œJewelry greenâ€ outlets hehe.

The simple trick to getting this broken rice like texture is very easy. Itâ€™s using a combination of rice, three parts normal rice (preferably Japanese or Taiwanese rice) to one part glutinous rice. So for 2 persons, you need half cup rice in total, so mix well 3/8 cup of normal rice to 1/8 cup glutinous rice. Then you always need 8 times more water, in this case 4 cups of water or stock for even a better flavour profile.

So add the 2 types rice and water into the rice cooker. As we are using garoupa as our protein later, we flavour this congee with one slice of dried abalone and a few pieces of dried scallops for that ocean taste. Then set your rice cooker to cook for 3.5 hours for maximum congee joy.

An hour into cooking, add a few slices of ginger and some white bits of scallion. Marinate 150g mince pork with 3 slices ginger, 2 chopped garlic, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp Chinese wine, 1 tsp sesame oil, 1 tsp 5 spice powder, 1 tsp plain flour and a dash of white pepper. Mix well and let it rest for 5 minutes.

Half an hour before the congee time is up, simply add the pork balls and sliced century eggs into the rice cooker. And once the congee is fully cooked, season with one tsp salt. You can add more if you prefer a stronger taste.

To serve, pour into large round bowls and garnish with more slices of ginger and the green bits of scallion. Then it should look similar to those you find at you know where. The texture should be silky and velvety, and the rice fairly broken down from the long cooking time. It should taste thoroughly comforting too :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Egg Mayonnaise Prosciutto Wrap.

A tasty breakfast favourite of ours, this takes half an hour to do and less than half that time to eat.

Bring 3 eggs to a boil, then turn off heat. Cover with a lid for 10 minutes until it is hard boiled. Drain water and run the eggs under tap water to shock the eggs. Peel eggs and place eggs in a bowl.

Use a fork to mash the eggs. Add 2 large tbsp of Greek yogurt and mix well. Then season with half tsp salt and some black pepper. Break some basil leaves to give it a lovely herb fragrance. Mix well again.

On an aluminium foil sheet, place one wrap and add 2 pieces of lettuce. Add 2 slices of prosciutto though you can easily substitute with sliced or shaved ham as well.

Spoon enough yogurt egg mayonnaise on top to cover the prosciutto. Then fold the wrap similar to a spring roll or popiah. Fold the foil also to cover the wrap entirely.

Cut the wrap into half to reveal the colourful cross section and then, enjoy a delicious breakfast. Best with some fruit :)))))

caption:
Sua Lor Prawn Aglio Olio, updated recipe of one of our favourite pasta dishes with a few improvements.

Start with 6 sua lor prawns from @lyhseafood for 2 persons. Deshell and devein the shrimp and separate them. Boil tagliatelle from @barilla for exactly 5 minutes and strain. Keep the pasta water.

In a pan of oil, lightly sauteÌ the prawns on each side. Prawns cook very fast, so it will take only a minute or so to cook. Remove but use the same pan to cook the heads until they turn pink. Then add 2 ladles of pasta water and simmer for 5 minutes. Strain and keep the prawn stock.

In a pan, drizzle enough extra virgin olive oil to create a thin film of bathing oil. Add 2 cloves of thinly sliced garlic and 6 cherry tomatoes, halved. Let them bathe in the oil to make an aromatic garlic oil. Next add some chopped basil, be sure to keep another batch of same amount of basil for the finishing later.

Add a tbsp butter and let it monte the pan. In French cooking, monte usually comes at the end to make the sauce more rich and luxurious, but we are using butter to add flavour and richness. As the butter is melted, add the prawn stock to make the final sauce.

Once the sauce is boiling, add the pasta and quickly stir to get the pasta to absorb all the prawn and basil goodness. If you can toss the noodles, even better. The secret here is to make the pasta absorb the saucy liquid until it reduces to a creamy consistency.

To finish, turn off heat and add the prawns and the balance of basil and another tbsp of butter and monte or mantecare one last time. Stirring and tossing adds air to emulsify the butter into the sauce, giving it a rich creamy and glossy finish.

To serve, refer to our videos to see how it can be plated nicely. Trust us, you will only eat this at home even after the crisis is over :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Today is Dragon Boat Festival! Here is our recipe for this again in the event you are thinking of making this today.

Start by soaking 500g glutinous rice, 12 chestnuts and bamboo leaves overnight. Also, soak about 6 dried mushrooms for 2 hours.

Marinate 250g pork shoulder or belly with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce, 3 minced garlic, 1 chopped shallot and some 5 spice powder. Add a dash of white pepper also.

In a wok of oil, fry 3 minced garlic and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the glutinous rice and mix well. Season with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce and some 5 spice powder. Stir until the rice is evenly coated, then set aside and let it cool down.

In a fresh wok of oil, fry another 3 minced garlic, a handful of dried shrimp and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the marinated pork, dried mushrooms and chestnuts. Fry and stir until everything is properly mixed. After about 5 minutes, set aside and let it cool down.

For each dumping take 2 bamboo leaves and fold at the center to form a triangle cup as seen in the video. Spoon some rice to fill one third of the capacity. Add a chestnut and a piece of pork.

Then add a chestnut, half a mushroom, some braised peanuts (from can) and half a salted egg yolk. You can also add an abalone as an option.

Fold the the flap of the lead to cover the base of the dumpling and fold in any other flap. Ensure it is tight and there are no gaps to form a taut pyramid shape.

We tie the dumpling strings to a hangar, but you can improvise with whatever is convenient. Use the string to tie around the dumpling and ensure it is tight. Make 12 dumplings with this recipe.

Then boil the dumplings in a wok of water for 45 minutes and it should be done. If you didnâ€™t leave any gaps, the dumpling should look firm and neat.

We still need more practice with our dumpling tying skills, but this way is certainly more affordable than buying commercial ones outside. And equally as tasty :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Homemade Popiah.

One of our family favourites, this takes some time to make but well worth the effort to make this at home. 
Shred 2 jicama in a blender until you get thin strips. Fry a tau kwa until both sides are golden brown. Then cut it into thin strips.

Fry 4 chopped garlic and 1 chopped shallot in a wok of oil until fragrant. Then add one carrot that has been julienned or thinly sliced. Stir well.

Then added the shredded jicama together with about 10 sliced French beans. Mix well again and add some water if it gets too dry. Season with 1.5 tsp salt and some white pepper.

Fry some prawns, about a dozen of them in a pan until they are cooked. Just a few minutes will do. Next prepare all the rest of the ingredients and condiments. You will need black sweet sauce, peanut butter, chilli paste or cilicuka, dried sole powder, lettuce and parsley. And popiah skin of course.

Start with 2 popiah skins and one might be too thin and break easily. Spoon some sweet sauce and chilli paste or cilicuka in the center first.

Then add some peanut butter, we using our homemade one. Add some pieces of lettuce. Then take a few spoonfuls of jicima and layer on top, enough to form a spring roll. Add a few prawns, then some parsley and a dash of sole powder.

Roll from the bottom at the longer side and about halfway, fold in the sides before continuing to fold forward until you form a popiah. Cut into slices for easier consumption.

And there you have it, a delicious homemade popiah :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Potato Leek Cream Soup without using actual cream.

Here is a simple rustic classic soup thatâ€™s so easy to do. And totally delicious and wholesome.

In a pot of oil and butter, sweat 1 stalk and 3 or 4 medium sized potatoes, chopped into small chunks so as to cook faster. After about 5 minutes or so, add half a cup of washed lentils and cook for a few minutes.

Add enough chicken or vegetable stock until half the pot is filled. If your salt is salty, do not add any salt. Else one tsp salt will do, though itâ€™s best to adjust according to your own taste. Break a few basil leaves into the pot also.

Bring to a boil and let the soup simmer for at least 15 minutes. Once the potatoes are soft, you can remove from the stove.

Use a hand blender and blitz the soup until it turns smooth and creamy like seen in the video. Then simply ladle the soup into soup bowls and garnish.

We added a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil and paprika powder, along with few slices of our toasted homemade baguette.

Soups like these are so classic and thereâ€™s a reason they remain so. They are just so good to come back to again and again :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
comments: ['Mmm yeh trying to eliminate the need to go out and get cream too.', 'Good for rainy days!', 'Delicious']

caption:
A Simple and Heavenly Fish Pot Pie.

Just make sure you have some ready to bake puff pastry, we using the excellent one from @borgcraft.

Measure your baking dish or pot and cut out enough puff pastry to cover the top and slightly over the edge.

In a pot with oil and a tsp butter, turn heat on until the butter is sizzling. Add in 1 chopped carrot? 2 chopped garlic and 2 chopped shallots with half a stalk of chopped leek. Sweat until the vegetables are fragrant and slightly soft.

Add 2 tsp of plain flour and stir well until the flour is fully cooked. Add in 2 cups of milk and cook until a roux of a thickened milk sauce is formed. Season with 1/2 tsp salt and some black pepper.

Chop a cod fillet onto thick chunks and like them inside the dish. Add some chopped broccoli and cauliflower as an optional extra, it will give a much needed crunch also. Spoon enough of the milk sauce to cover the fish and vegetables.

Cover the top of the dish with the cut puff pastry. Cut 2 slits at the center to allow the ingredients inside to steam properly. Apply an egg wash on the pastry. Then bake in a preheated oven at 180 Celsius fan mode for around 25 minutes.

Once the pastry has a beautiful golden brown crust, remove from oven and let it cool down for 10 minutes before eating. The puff pastry should be crispy and flaky, and inside, a delicious cod sweetened creamy sauce. Yums :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Homemade Otah Otah.

Nothing beats a homemade rendition of this delicious coconut fish cake, when you can be generous with the fish and the ingredients you lavish with it.

Today we using the superb batang fish from @lyhseafood to make the fish paste, about 450g worth will make about 6 otahs.

Blitz 1 onion, 3 garlic, 2 shallots, 5 candle nuts, 4 slices galangal, 1 stalk of lemongrass,1 fresh chilli, 3 dried chilies and 1 slice of belachan until you get a rempah paste. Fry the paste in a wok of oil until itâ€™s super fragrant.

Cut the batang fish into slices and send them to the blender. Add the rempah, 1 tbsp corn flour, 1 tsp sugar, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, 1 egg, 150ml coconut milk and 2 kaffir lime leaves. Blitz until you get a smooth paste.

Wash and cut banana leaves for the otah. Spoon enough fish paste onto the center of the lead and fold at the longer sides inwards to cover and form the otah shape.  Secure the ends with toothpicks.

Then bake in oven at 200 Celsius no fan for 15 minutes and you will have delicious homemade otah! These will be way more tasty than commercial ones :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
comments: ['Looks good', 'Wow ğŸ˜', 'So much love goes into it ğŸ˜']

caption:
Porkballs Sweet Potato Rice Cooker.

Continuing our rice cooker one pot series, today we are doing a simple and tasty meatball sweet potato combination with a touch of snow peas.

Marinate 150g mince pork with 3 slices ginger, 2 chopped garlic, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp Chinese wine, 1 tsp sesame oil, 1 tsp 5 spice powder, 1 tsp plain flour and a dash of white pepper. Mix well and let it rest for 5 minutes.

In a rice cooker, add a cup of washed and rinsed white rice. Take the mince pork and make into a small porkballs and add them all around the rice.

Then add half of a chopped sweet potato and a handful of chopped snow peas. Pour in a cup of water. Cook in rice cooker mode until itâ€™s done.

And thatâ€™s all to it, simple pimple. When itâ€™s cooked, just use a spatula to stir up the rice a bit, then serve and enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption: Otah Hot Pockets made with homemade otah which we will put later :) You can use any otah you can get your hands on also, just heat up the otah, wrapped it with a tortilla wrap and use a panini presser like the one from @tefalsingapore and presto! A fresh otah hot pocket :)))))

Basting Steaks, using the lovely tenderloins from @thegoodmeatstore.

Hereâ€™s a quick recap on how to cook beautiful steaks with a golden brown crust and medium rare doneness.

First, you need to have a good cut - ribeye, striploin or tenderloin would be best. Avoid spending money on expensive Wagyu for this, an Aussie angus will do nicely.

Next, make sure your steak is at room temperature before you cook it, and pat dry on both sides so that there is no excess moisture. Then, season liberally with sea salt or course salt. Do likewise with black pepper.

The issue with most home cooked steaks is usually the pan is not hot enough, and you donâ€™t get that golden crust. So make sure you heat up your pan with a shallow film of oil for a few minutes before you put the meat in.

You must get a beautiful sizzling sound when the beef hits the pan, and just leave it. You only need to turn once. After about 2 minutes, turn and you should get a nice golden brown crust. Add a tbsp butter and baste, which means using a spoon and quickly take some butter juice and pour over the top of the steak repeatedly as seen in the video. Cook for another 2 minutes.

For most ribeye and striploin cuts, the entire steak can usually cook in just the pan, but tenderloin and thicker cuts may need an extra time in the oven. If so, send the steak to the oven at 180 Celsius for another 2 to 3 minutes.

Once the steak is cooked to medium rare, you need to rest it for another 3 minutes or so. Make sure you donâ€™t forget this as if not, your steak will not be as juicy. Once itâ€™s properly rested, take a sharp knife and you should easily cut through the steak like butter.

You should get a ideal pink medium rare, and a juicy and tender texture. The basting will give it a lovely buttery beef flavour, and every bite should be nirvana for steak lovers :)))))

caption:
Homemade Nasi Lemak.

Hereâ€™s our little take on this popular breakfast classic. Itâ€™s quite straightforward, just some effort to make the individual components.

First cook the coconut rice by adding some chopped pandan leaves, half cup of cream, 1 cup water to 1 cup of basmati rice. Normal rice will do also. Then let the rice cook until itâ€™s done at normal rice cooker mode.

Fry some dried anchovies or ikan bilis in pan of oil until they are crispy delicious. Similarly, use the same pan to fry some raw peanuts until they are crispy on the outside too. Set both aside.

In a fresh pan with oil, sauteÌ one sliced red onion until the onions are soft. Then add a few tbsp of sambal chilli or belachan. We happen to have our mum in law homemade one, and will share a recipe for this in a later post.

Fry until The onions and sambal are utterly aromatic. You can choose to add a few of the fried ikan bilis inside too. Add some tamarind juice and a tsp sugar and mix well. Once the juice has been reduced, your sambal paste is ready.

Cook a sunny side up egg as an accompaniment. Make sure only cook until the whites are set and leave the yolk creamy yolky.

To plate, simply pour some rice into a small bowl and flip it onto a plate or better, a banana leaf lined plate. Then simply add the egg on top of the rice, and the sambal, peanuts, ikan bilis and some sliced cucumbers by the side.

And itâ€™s done! What we enjoy is the lovely lemak notes from the rice, beautifully contrasted with the kick of the sambal and the crunch of the ikan bilis and peanuts.

A fried chicken wing would be great too, but for us, this simpler version is just a joy to eat :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
A Doriyaki Hotdog.

Using the same Doriyaki pancake recipe, we did a simple hotdog using a Doriyaki pancake as a wrapper.

You need 80g plain flour, 40g sugar, honey, baking powder, 2 eggs, oil and water.

Make the batter first by adding the sugar into a bowl and add one tbsp honey. Break two eggs and whisk like thereâ€™s no tomorrow hehe. This is to introduce air into the mixture and after a few minutes, the mixture will start to foam and turn paler, and will have more liquid. This is a much better way to use your whisking muscles than to make some diabetic Korean kopi C which we will also never make here hehe.

Once the egg mixture is foamy and has a nice viscosity, add the 80g flour and half tsp baking powder and stir subtly until it foams into a nice yellow and eggy batter. Refrigerate for 15 minutes and after taking it out, add one tbsp plain water just to loosen the batter.

In a non stick pan, pour a ladle of egg batter into the centre and let it naturally spread out to form a round pancake shape. It will cook very quickly in a minute or two, so use a spatula to loosen the edges and get ready to flip.

Once itâ€™s dry on the bottom side, quickly flip and cook the other side, which will tend to cook faster as the pan gets hotter.

Once done, simply wrap a pancake around a sausage of your choice and there you have it! A Doriyaki Hotdog :)))))

caption:
Stir Fried Pork with Baby Spinach and Potatoes.

We wanted something light and simple to eat with porridge as seeing today is rather a chilly day throughout.

Marinate 250g pork chopped into chunks with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp Chinese wine and some black pepper. We using pork loin though you can use any pork, even minced pork for this simple dish.

Cut a potato or 2 into thin slices or discs. Then in a wok, add a tsp butter and some oil and heat it up until the butter fizzles. Add the potato and fry until they are soft.

Then add the pork and cook until the meat is mostly cooked. Then add some water and starch slurry solution to make a thickened sauce. Add a tsp of dark soya also.

Then add some baby spinach and cook and mix until the vegetables are soft, which is about a minute or so. Then add some black pepper and serve.

This is best with a warm bowl of porridge to drizzle the umami sauce all over the porridge :)))))

caption:
Sua Lor Fried Noodles.

Some days itâ€™s too cumbersome to do the full Hokkien Mee recipe, we decided to do a shortened version. We finally got our hands on sua lor prawns also from @lyhseafood and they make the best broth for this, and the meat is so crunchy and qq.

Deshell 14 prawns and fry the shells and heads in oil in a pot until they turn reddish pink and smells amazing. Then add water and simmer for at least 20 minutes.

SauteÌ the prawns themselves in a wok of oil for one minute each side and quickly remove them. In the same wok with the aromatic prawn oil, sauteÌ a chopped garlic until its fragrant.

Then add some minced pork, we using the leftover xlb filling from @paradisegrpsg from lunch. Once the minced is cooked, add yellow noodles. We using the ones from @fortunefoodmfgsg.

Then add 3 ladles of the prawn stock and use a pair of tongs to separate the noodle strands as they will be clumped together initially. If can, toss the wok as it will help the noodles to absorb the broth faster.

Once it gets dry, add more stock and repeat this for a few times until the noodles turn creamy and luscious. Then season with a tsp light soya, white pepper and as an optional, coriander powder or 5 spice powder.

Then add some leafy greens like the nai bai we using today and toss some more to cook  the vegetables quickly. Then turn off the flame, and add some oil or lard oil and black pepper. Give one final toss to emulsify the noodles into a shiny creamy noodley goodness.

Then pour into a bowl and enjoy! We always like sua lor over the more sexy looking tiger prawns for flavour and texture :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets. #fortunecookschallenge

caption:
Xiao Long Bao DIY Kit from Paradise Dynasty @paradisegrpsg.

Now you can try your hand at making the same xlb you get at paradise dynasty, which happens to be our favourite xlb joint too.

Each kit comes with a set of wrappers, pork filling and a bamboo steamer similar to the ones at their restaurants. You can make up to 16 dumplings and this comes at a price of $23.80 which you can order directly from online platforms or as a takeaway.

As the wrappers are already made, all you need to do is just thaw the ingredients in advance and make each dumpling by hand. Spoon some filling into a wrapper and make 18 folds at the top. Pinch and close the dumpling and thatâ€™s it.

Make 8 different coloured ones as each steamer can hold up to 8 dumplings. Simply steam them for 7 minutes and itâ€™s done! Easy. Just need to practice the folds though, as it needs a little of a nimble set of hands and some getting used to.

This would be fun to do at home with the family and it tastes and looks just as good as the ones in their restaurants :)))))
comments: ['Are the wrappers different flavours?ğŸ˜®', 'Wah those look tasty man', 'the colors! ğŸ˜', 'Wow!!!']

caption:
Easy Squeasy Egg Muffins for Breakfast.

Stay safe folks if you are heading out, but we will continue to cook at home for now as we make an easy egg muffin this Friday morning.

Fry some sliced potatoes in a pan of oil until soft. Then add chopped sausage of your choice, tomatoes and baby spinach. Mix well and set aside.

Make the egg mixture by combining 2 eggs, 2 tbsp milk, grated cheddar cheese, black pepper and half tsp salt. Use a fork to whisk and mix everything well.

Then using a muffin mold set, spoon some of the potato sausage filling into each mold, should be enough to make 4 muffins. Then pour the egg mixture until is almost full. 
Then bake at 200 Celsius no fan for 15 minutes and voila, a tantalising looking eggy breakfast to start phase 2.

The lovely plates and cups by @olivetheshop :)))))

caption:
Tenderloin Angus Chilled from New Zealand, as an idea to celebrate Dad Day this weekend.

These are really affordable tenderloin steaks from @thegoodmeatstore and we are thoroughly impressed with the flavour and texture, and endorse this wholeheartedly.

Make the potato fondant by cutting a potato into a rectangular block and pan fry them in butter both sides for a few minutes each side. Then bake them in an oven at 180 Celsius no fan for 35 minutes.

Make a truffle soy by adding one tsp light soya, one tsp dark soya and some water in a saucepan and bring it to a boil. Then reduce by half itâ€™s amount. Then slowly add small amounts of  unsalted cold butter and whisk until the butter melts.

Then repeat the process of adding and whisking butter until an emulsion is formed. Add few tsp of truffle pate from @shinsengrocer and black pepper.

Season the steaks with sea salt and black pepper. Then in a pan of very hot oil, pan sear the steaks about a minute plus each side. When you flip the steaks, add a slab of butter and baste the steaks with a spoon.

To finish cooking, send the steaks into the oven at 180 Celsius no fan for another 3 minutes to get that medium rare texture.

To plate, just add some pickled cucumber ribbons, the potato fondant, a spoon of the truffle soy and finally the steak. You can choose to slice the steaks too, just make sure you rest them for about 3 minutes first.

This is simple, elegant yet refined. And which dad wonâ€™t love a juicy steak cooked perfectly :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Red Emperor Assam Pedas.

Understandably, some of us are still apprehensive about venturing out to eat, especially this Dad day weekend, so we thought of showing you a few dishes you can do to celebrate this Sunday.

We got this lovely red emperor snapper from our favourite fish source, @lyhseafood and thought of doing the classic nanyang dish.

Prepare the tamarind juice by dissolving 2 tbsp tamarind water in a cup of water. Strain the juice free of the seeds and set aside.

Make the rempah paste by blitzing 4 garlic, 3 shallots, 1 lemongrass stalk, 1 fresh chilli, 1 dried chilli that have seeds removed and 1 block of belachan paste with some water.

In a wok of oil, fry off the rempah until the kitchen is abundant with belachan pungency, which will turn amazingly aromatic in time. Then break some kaffir lime leaves over the paste and add them into the mix.

Next, add a handful of chopped okra and one chopped tomato. Stir well. Then add the tamarind juice and another cup of water. Try not to buy those bottled tamarind juice as they wonâ€™t taste as good.

Bring everything to a boil and let it simmer for 5 minutes. Then add the red snapper fish cut into chunks. You can use any fish for that matter, but red snapper is just amazeballs here. Add some lemon juice and fresh parleys or Vietnamese mint.

Let the fish cook for around 10 minutes or until the meat is fully cooked. Then simply pour everything into a bowl and served with white rice. For a proper family celebration, you can pair with other dishes from some of our previous recipes.

This will make a memorable Dad day during a period when going out is not necessarily the best option, and having a homecooked meal will be more meaningful :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Healthy and Pretty Yogurt Fruit Sandwich.

Hereâ€™s a recap of how to prepare this delicious, pretty and healthy breakfast.

Before going to bed, take two slices of bread for one sandwich. Spread some probiotic goodness of Greek yogurt on both slices. Than add fruits of your choice in a deliberate pattern on one slice. You can sketch it out on paper also as you should consider a symmetric pattern when you cut into half the next day.

Simply spread some more yogurt on top and cover with the other slice to make a sandwich and wrap tightly with cling wrap, put it in a sandwich box like the one seen in the video. Refrigerate it overnight.

The next morning, take it out and slice it in halves. When you look at the cross section, it should turn out to form a pretty colourful pattern.

A healthy fruit sandwich :)))))

caption:
Hiyashi Chuka, cold ramen salad.

This is another way of having ramen, in an appetising manner with fresh vegetables and a soy ginger dressing.

Start by grating some ginger. Then prepare the dressing by mixing 5 tbsp light soya, grated ginger, 3 tbsp rice vinegar, 3 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsp water, 1 tbsp sesame oil and 1 tbsp sesame seeds in a bowl. Stir and mix well until you get a savory and sweet soy ginger dressing. Refrigerate for at least an hour before using.

Cut thinly or julienne one zucchini or cucumber, one whole tomato and 2 big pieces of ham.

In a pan, add 2 beaten eggs and let them form a round shaped omelette. Cook both sides until they are firm. Then fold the omelette on a chopping board into halves, then cut thinly into egg strips.

Cook your ramen, which you can get ready ones from @shinsengrocer in boiling water for about 2 minutes. Then immediately soak into a bowl of ice water to shock the noodles and make it icy cold. You can also use other similar egg noodles and cook them according to their boxed instructions.

Now to plate, place the cold noodles in the center of a plate. Then place the egg strips, tomatoes, cucumbers and ham around them like seen in the video.

Apply the dressing on top and you are done. To eat, simply toss everything together machiam like yusheng and you will get a healthier appetising ramen salad like dish :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Hot Plate Tofu with Minced Pork and Snow Peas.

If you are thinking what to make with white rice, this is one simple pimple dish to make. We using a cast iron pan as a substitute for hot plate.

Make a crabmeat sauce by adding half cup of crabmeat to a saucepan, followed by a little water. Add a dash of black pepper, and once the crabmeat is cooked, add a starch flurry solution to thicken and create a sauce.

In the cast iron pan, add one chopped garlic and sauteÌ in oil until fragrant. Add 150g minced pork and mix well. Season with one tsp light soya and stir again.

Once the pork is sufficiently cooked, add some snow peas and let them boil inside the pan. Next, cut a rounded tofu packet from @fortunefoodmfgsg into thick discs and place them all around the pan and let them steam.

After a few minutes, add in two beaten eggs to form an omelette base at the bottom of the pan. Wait until the eggs are set, then add in the previously cooked crabmeat sauce. And you are done.

Sprinkle fresh black pepper and serve. We will simply eat directly from the cast iron pan as it makes a great hot plate sort of presentation. Not our prettiest dish but it sure is tasty :)))))

caption:
Mapo Tofu Rice Cooker.

We were still craving for our original Mapo tofu dish and decided to produce a shortcut version today hehe. You can scroll back to see the full version but this one can be great for folks who need a quick hack.

Toast some Szechuan peppercorns and when they have cooled down, crush them inside a plastic bag with rolling pin until they turn into a powder.

Marinate 150g minced pork with 1 tbsp dou ban jiang/spicy black bean paste, 2 tsp light soya and 1 tbsp Chinese wine. Add 3 garlic and one shallot that have been finely chopped. Mix well with your hands.

Use a packet of Chinese tofu, today we are using the ones from @fortunefoodmfgsg. Donâ€™t cut or slice, just leave it whole.

Add one cup of rice into a rice cooker and place the minced pork in clumps around the rice. Add the whole slab of tofu in the center. Add one cup of water. Set to rice cooker mode and let it cook till it is finished.

Once the rice is cooked, open the lid and add the Szechuan peppercorn powder and use a spatula to stir and mix all the ingredients well. Sprinkle some chopped scallion and it is done.

Simply scoop into rice bowls and enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
While itâ€™s obviously good news that we are moving to phase 2 by this weekend, it is still wise to take going out to dine and socialise gradually. Especially come this Friday, where a number of places might be packed with eager ones cooped up at home for months.

At the same token, many of us have already gotten used to cooking at home, and we should continue to make this a habit and not an exception, and many of us have enjoyed cooking and will become less dependent on eating out.

Give it a few weeks and we ourselves would venture for food outside like how we used to, as the last thing we want now is to cheong outside and worry about a second wave and worse, a second breaking of circuit :)))))

caption:
Tagliatelle Chilli Crab using homemade pasta.

Truth be told, we are never the biggest fans of chilli crab as most commercial ones use ketchup, and we prefer fresh sauces. So the next best thing is to do a chilli crab sauce with freshly made tagliatelle.

Blitz one shallot, 2 garlic and one chilli with some water in a blender until you get a nice moist paste. Then prepare the fresh pasta which is in our earlier post this morning.

Fry the chilli paste in a pan of oil until itâ€™s amazingly aromatic. Then add a tsp of tau chui or fermented bean paste. If you donâ€™t have this, just replace with a tsp salt or a tbsp light soya to give it savouriness.

Stir and mix well. Then add 5 tbsp tomato pureÌe. You can use a few tbsp of ketchup to substitute but seriously, fresh tomato flavours are better. Stir well again.

Add a few ladles of unsalted stock or water and bring to a boil. Then add a tbsp of butter and stir until the butter melts. Sprinkle some coriander powder if available. Add in 150g of crabmeat or roughly a cup worth and let them all simmer for around 5 minutes.

As this is fresh pasta, we prefer to just blanche it right before putting in the pan of sauce. A quick boil of 20 seconds in boiling water will do, then immediately transfer to the pan of chilli crab sauce.

Mix well and toss and the saucy crab sauce will disappear into the pasta very quickly. Once itâ€™s almost dry, turn off the flame and add in a tbsp of butter and give one final toss to get it utterly creamy. And you are done.

Simply twirl the pasta on a plate and garnish with some chopped scallion on top. It will be spicy creamy crabby delicious and prove to be highly addictive until the last strand :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Drunken Sesame Ginger Chicken with Black Fungus, a family favourite.

Start by slicing 2 handfuls of ginger very thinly and frying them in a wok filled with sesame oil until they turn crispy. It will turn into thin ginger fries.

In the same wok, add sliced ginger pieces and fry them until they are fragrant and starts to turn soft. Then add black fungus pieces that have been presoaked in water for at least an hour. Stir well.

Once the black fungus has slightly softened, add 300g of chicken pieces. We are using boneless chicken leg though any cut will do also. Stir well.

Season with 2 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp light soya, half cup of water and half cup of Chinese wine. Bring to a boil and let it simmer for a few minutes. Ensure that the chicken is properly cooked by this time.

Add some white pepper and thicken up the broth with some starch flurry solution. Then turn off the flame and add a drizzle of fresh sesame oil for fragrance.

Simply serve into a bowl or claypot and enjoy this savoury chicken dish with white rice. Garnish on top with the fried ginger fries also for that lovely crispy crunch :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Making fresh tagliatelle again today for a dinner dish later tonight. Hereâ€™s the fresh pasta recipe again.

Pour 2 cups of plain flour onto a table and make a well in the center. Crack 3 small eggs into the well and use a fork to whisk the eggs. Donâ€™t worry if they leak out of the well, simply mix the flour with the egg mixture a shaggy wet dough starts to form.

Once enough flour and eggs are incorporated and it gets mode solid, start using your hands to knead the dough for about 6 minutes or so. You will end up with a drier smoother round ball dough after all the flour has been absorbed.

Cover with a cling wrap and let it rest for 20 minutes. After resting, place the dough ball back onto the table and cut into 2 equal halves. With each half, you can make a person worth portion of tagliatelle.

First flatten the halved dough with your palm into a pancake thick shape. Then use a rolling pin and start rolling out into a wider and thin sheet. You will know when it is thin enough when the sheet becomes slightly translucent and you can barely see through it to see the table underneath.

Then fold the bottom third in, then the top third over the other two thirds. Take a dough cutter or a knife, simply cut into tagliatelle sized noodles.

After that, simply spread and loosen the noodles. And let them rest for a few minutes before cooking them. Dust a bit more flour to prevent them from sticking.

To cook the pasta, simply salt the boiling water and let them cook for about 4 minutes and retain the starch from the pasta water to make a sauce :)))))

caption:
Lasagne, Garfield the Catâ€™s favourite food.

Start by making the pasta sheets. Pour 2 cups of plain flour onto a table and make a well in the center. Crack 3 small eggs into the well and use a fork to whisk the eggs.

Once enough flour and eggs are incorporated, start using your hands to knead the dough for about 6 minutes or so. You will end up with a drier smoother round ball dough after all the flour has been absorbed.

Cover with a cling wrap and let it rest for 20 minutes. After resting, place the dough ball back onto the table and cut into 2 equal halves. With each half, you can make one lasagne.

Use a rolling pin to roll out the pasta and measure with your baking dish to cut out 3 sheets that will cover each layer of lasagne.

You can use our previous Bolognese recipe for the filling, or simply use 2 packets of wagyu Bolognese from @shinsengrocer.

Make a bechamel sauce. Create a simple roux with one tbsp butter and 2 tsp plain flour in a saucepan. Turn on at low flame and slowly wipe the butter around flour filled pan to absorb all the flour.

You will end up with a yellow thick paste. Add fresh milk slowly and let it mix with the roux. The milk will quickly thicken up. Just keep adding until you get a sauce like consistency like what you see in the video. Add grated cheddar and parmesan. Season with black pepper.

Start layering the baking dish with a layer of Bolognese, followed by a pasta sheet. Boil the sheet for 10 seconds prior to placing in the dish. Then add mozzarella cheese and spoon enough bechamel sauce to cover the layer.

Then repeat the same meat, pasta, mozzarella and bechamel layer. For the last layer, add the meat and pasta sheet first. Then add the bechamel layer before adding the mozzarella and some parmesan.

Bake the lasagne in a preheated oven at 180 Celsius no fan for 45 minutes. Once itâ€™s done baking, remove from oven and rest for 20 minutes before eating.

You should get a heavenly golden brown cheesy crust and aroma. And when you cut into it, you should get a multi layered divine lasagne deliciousness :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Oxtail Stew.

You will need oxtails, one celery, one onion and one carrot are the basic ingredients. Red wine, one third can of cherry tomatoes, water and flour round up the rest.

Always brown your meat, in this case, oxtails in a cold pan under low heat. You donâ€™t need oil as the beef has enough fat, and this will render the fat as well.

In a large pot, make a mirepoix, a fancy French word for çˆ†é¦™, using diced onion, celery and carrot. Keep sauteÌing until they are soft and aromatic, hence the â€œXiangâ€ aspect. Add the seared oxtails into the pot and stir if you want to, though you donâ€™t have to. Just look kinda chefy in case an immediate family is curiously looking on wondering what that gorgeous smell is.

Then add enough red wine. Now never ask a French cook how much, and I will never know, just add until you think it is enough. It is one of those things that it will have that magical wine notes at the end no matter what.

Now add enough water to cover the oxtails. If you have beef stock, better. But where to find beef bones to make stock, but if u do, I will be your best friend now.

Add a third of a can of cherry tomatoes, though plump ones will do as well. Try using Italian ones if possible, cos Italian produce just rocks.

Thatâ€™s the hard part. Now all u need to do is bring everything to a boil, then lower it to simmering rolling boil. Which means the broth can see only one or two bubbles rolling away, and this is the ideal time to try the Iphone 11 slo mo video shot.

Be sure to check every half hour and top up water, donâ€™t want this delicious dish to burn. I find watching Netflix sitcoms like Big Bang theory or modern family best for the intervals, or if u have an Apple Watch, set that timer which u never thought was useful.

Just an hour or less before that four hours cooking time, add 3 tbsp of plain flour to thicken the sauce and give it a nice glossy look.

Once 4 hours are up, and you have made it thru 8 episodes, plate and serve and enjoy this hearty tasty beef dish :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption:
Decided to take a break from cooking lunch today and have @simonroadhokkienmee118 signature Hokkien Mee instead.

Indeed, the Simon Road uncle has been frying this for decades and itâ€™s one of only 3 hkm which we frequent. His is the dry version which is, we feel, the right way to eat this classic. We hardly touch those super wet and moaty ones.

Fried noodle dishes need to absorb all the stock into the noodles so that the noodles are properly flavoured. Thatâ€™s why we dislike the soupy ones as they tend to lack that perfect alchemy of flavours, and some can still taste the kee or lye taste of the yellow noodles.

Simon road uncle will always fry and braise the noodles until their tasty broth is fully incorporated, along with the rest of the egg and garlic fragrance, and tinged with a wok hei aroma, itâ€™s quite sensational from first bite till last.

His son, Youri has been learning the ropes and has since picked up most of his dad frying skills, and trust us, it is something that takes time to get this good. Those who have tried our own rendition of hkm will appreciate the efforts just to prepare.

And combined with practice, this is one of our truly iconic Singaporean dishes. And thatâ€™s why we wholeheartedly endorse the Simon road stall.

If you live near Kovan, you can visit for tabao now. Else, visit this link for home deliveries ... https://take.sg/s/6582302300 :)))))

caption:
Pulut Inti, Glutinous Coconut Rice Wrapped in Banana Leaf.

A classic dessert this, and oh so good. Start by soaking 1.5 cups of glutinous rice overnight. Next day, transfer to a bowl for steaming. Add 1 packet of coconut milk and half tsp salt. Cut some strips of pandan leaves and spread on top.

Steam for 20 minutes. Open the lid and use a fork to fluff up the rice. Steam for another 5 minutes. Then set aside.

In a pot, add one block of gula melaka or palm sugar, roughly 50g and 60ml water. Add 100g of grated coconut and some more strips of pandan leaves. Stir until the sugar is melted.

Once the sugar is melted and the coconut is coloured an orange, slightly brown colour thoroughly, add a knob of butter and a flour slurry solution. Stir well until you get a coconut paste.

Cut each banana leaf 24cm by 14cm. Then use a ramekin to measure each kueh size, and add glutinous rice in it and flip it onto the leaf. Add some coconut topping on top.

As seen in the video, fold in the longer sides of the lead inward to cover but leave a gap at the center to expose the coconut. Then fold the sides underneath to form a neatly shaped kueh shape, almost like a rice dumpling.

And thatâ€™s it, a simple yet tremendously delicious classic dessert that the kids will utterly enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

Fried Smelt Fish with Baby Spinach Beetroot Salad.

We got these from our favourite fish supplier, @lyhseafood and these beauties are a joy to eat fried.

Simply coat each one with a flour batter seasoned with salt and pepper. And in pan with shallow oil, do a shallow fry each side until they turn golden brown. Roughly a minute plus each side.

caption:
Pumpkin Rice Cooker, or butternut squash.

For 2 pax, use one cup of rice and wash thoroughly. Add the rice to the rice cooker.

Season roughly 150g chicken breast with one tsp salt, a dash of coriander powder and ginger powder. Mix well and spread them into the rice cooker atop the rice.

Add some chopped pumpkin, about a small bowl with. You can add as much you like as well, and slice 2 button mushrooms and add them into the mix.

Add a cup of water into the rice and let the rice cooker cook it at normal mode until it is done. Once the rice is cooked, open the lid and add a knob of butter and cover for a few minutes.

Once the butter has melted a bit, add chopped scallion and mix everything well. Then, simply spoon into bowls and enjoy. It will have a lovely pumpkin fragrance and sweetness, and a buttery earthiness from the mushrooms. Kids will love this :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Teriyaki Confit Trout from @shinsengrocer.

One of the best ways to cook fish is using the confit method. It is essentially a gentle poach in flavoured oil that results in a very moist and tender flesh, and looks almost uncooked in a way.

Essentially the fish protein is cooked yet retains almost all the moisture and it will have a wondrous texture to the fish. Today we are using a teriyaki marinated trout from @shinsengrocer. As always, pat dry the fish prior to cooking.

Start by pouring enough oil to submerge the entire fish in a saucepan. Add a few sprigs of thyme, a few garlic cloves and some slices of lemon. Then heat it up slowly until it reaches 60 Celsius. You will need a kitchen thermometer to measure this.

Once it reaches 60 Celsius, put the trout inside the pan, and ensure the entire fish is covered in oil. Turn the heat to its lowest flame. The temperature should be maintained between 60 to 65 degrees during the cooking duration. Cook for 10 minutes.

Once the fish is cooked for 10 minutes, remove from the pan. As there is still sufficient teriyaki marinate left to make a sauce, we can use this.

Make a roux by adding one tbsp butter to 2 tsp plain flour in a clean saucepan. Let the butter absorb all the flour before slowly adding the teriyaki sauce and slowly stir until a saucy consistency is reached.

To serve, boil some nai bai as a side. Spoon some sauce at the bottom of the plate. Then add the nai bai, followed by the cooked trout. Quenelle some white truffle paste from @shinsengrocer and add some lemon zest on top to finish.

The joy of eating confit fish is the amazing texture, and you can cook thick red fish like salmon this way too. Enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Potato Gratin, a simple and delicious French classic.

This is so ridiculously easy to do at home, and will taste so good you wonder why you havenâ€™t tried this earlier.

Start by slicing thinly 4 potatoes and 1 onion. Make a simple roux with one tbsp butter and 2 tsp plain flour in a saucepan. Turn on at low flame and slowly wipe the butter around flour filled pan to absorb all the flour.

You will end up with a yellow thick paste. Add fresh milk slowly and let it mix with the roux. The milk will quickly thicken up. Just keep adding until you get a sauce like consistency like what you see in the video. This is known as a bechamel sauce. Season with a tsp salt and black pepper and set aside.

In a baking dish, layer the onions first on the base of the dish. Then cover the onions fully with a layer of potatoes. Make sure itâ€™s neatly packed.

Spoon the bechamel sauce over the potatoes, and make sure the sauce has fully covered the potatoes also. Then repeat another layer of onions, potatoes and bechamel sauce.

After pouring in the last of the sauce, and ensuring the potatoes are fully submerged in bechamel, sprinkle grated parmesan to fully cover the potato and sauce. We using parmigiana reggiano as itâ€™s just so so good.

Then bake in the oven at 180 Celsius no fan for around 45 minutes. You should get a deliciously tempting golden crust and an accompanying gorgeous aroma to go along with it. If your potatoes are still not soft enough and you are afraid the crust will burn, simply cover the top with an aluminium foil.

Once itâ€™s fully done, take it out and garnish with chopped parsley and fresh pepper. The inside should be creamy once the sauce has been reduced and the combination of potato, onion and meltingly crusty cheese should be undeniably additive :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Red Bean Pancakes, here is the recipe again for those who missed it the first time.

You will need 50g rice flour, 50g plain flour, one egg white and 1 tsp salt. Thatâ€™s about it, and a good non stick pan.

Mix the two flours, egg white and salt in a mixing bowl and whisk gently until you form a smooth batter.

In a non stick pan, do not oil the pan like most recipes suggest, we find it oil can break the crepe batter easily, but you do need practice in getting this part right. Do not turn on the flame at this point.

Use a ladle and spoon a ladle worth of batter and pour it in the center of the pan and tilt the pan until it fills up every corner, and making sure the batter is still thin enough. Try not to add additional batter in empty spots as this will make the crepe uneven.

Then turn on the flame at its lowest setting and slowly cook the crepe. Will take a few minutes for the batter to dry and the crepe to form. When itâ€™s cooked, it will have a rubbery texture at the edges, use a thin spatula and gently roll and fold the crepe into an empty popiah. Then roll it off onto a plate.

Rinse the pan to cool down and repeat until your batter is finished. Then, with each crepe, add some red bean paste in the centre and fold at each of the 4 sides into a parcel, and flip over.

Now to deep fry. In a wok of boiling hot oil, gently slice each parcel into the oil and deep fry until golden brown, only a few minutes each side.

Remove when done and drain the pancakes of any excess oil and they are done! It should taste crispy and eggy, and delicious for an afternoon snack. Ideal for an afternoon workout for us staying home now :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption:
Hereâ€™s something we did before but itâ€™s so easy to do - Honey Glazed Garlic Chicken Wings. The recipe as follows.

Pat dry chic wings before you begin. Dust them liberally in a coating of plain flour, salt and pepper and set aside.

Make the glaze with two teaspoons is light soy sauce, two teaspoons of cheapo honey, three teaspoons of plain water, one chopped cloves of garlic. For added spiciness, you can choose to add chilli or Szechuan pepper or both if you choose to turn the heat levels up.

Pan fry the coated wings in a pan of oil for roughly 5 minutes. Once they are properly browned, transfer to an oven tray lined with baking paper and roast the wings for about 15 minutes at 180 deg Celsius. Take them out to glaze the the wings on both sides with the soy honey glaze, and return to the oven for another 10 minutes.

Serve with sides of your choice. Here, we have them sitting a bed of homemade mashed potatoes and boiled spinach, and cherry tomatoes. For this plate you see here, the cost of ingredients is less than $10 to feed easily two :)))))
comments: ['Delicious', 'Delicious ğŸ‘']

caption:
Sualor Risotto.

Start with 8 or 10 sualor prawns from @lyhseafood for 2 persons. Deshell and devein the shrimp and separate them. Fry the shells and heads in a pot with butter until they turn pink. Add a pot worth of water to make a stock and simmer for 20 minutes. 

In a pan of oil, lightly sauteÌ the prawns on each side for a minute or 2. Remove the prawns and in the same pan, add a knob of butter and enough Arborio risotto rice for 2.

Toast for a few minutes before adding a dash of white wine. Burn off the wine for a few minutes before adding 3 ladles of prawn stock at medium heat and stir. Once the broth has been absorbed by the rice, add another ladle and stir again. Season with 1 tsp salt.

Keep repeating until the rice puffs up and is not too hard nor too mushy, about 20 minutes or so. Around 15 minutes, add some green peas. Once the rice is fully cooked, turn off the flame and add in a 2 thick slabs of butter, grated parmesan or parmigiana.

Stir well to emulsify the butter and toss to get it super creamy and delicious like seen in the video. To serve, spoon risotto into the center of a plate and shake the plate to let the rice naturally spread out to form a circular disc shape.

Add the sualor prawns on top and enjoy! It should be creamy and lava like, and when you get this right, itâ€™s super comforting :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
